zh: 聪明的格蕾特尔
en: Clever Grethel

zh: 从前有一个女厨子叫格蕾特尔，她穿着红色玫瑰花饰的鞋子，每当她穿着它们出门的时候，她就转过来转过去，心里想：“你真是个美丽的女孩！”当她回到家里，心里一高兴，就要喝上一口。由于喝的酒激起了她的食欲，她就把自己做得最好的饭菜吃了，直到酒足饭饱，说道：“厨师必须得要知道自己做的食物是什么味道的。”
en: There was once a cook named Grethel, who wore shoes with red rosettes, and when she walked out with them on, she turned herself this way and that, and thought, “You certainly are a pretty girl!”And when she came home she drank, in her gladness of heart, a draught of wine, and as wine excites a desire to eat, she tasted the best of whatever she was cooking until she was satisfied, and said, “The cook must know what the food is like.”

zh: 后来，有一天主人对她说：“格蕾特尔，今天晚上有个客人要来；给我准备两只可口的鸡。”“我会照办的，主人。”格蕾特尔回答道。她杀了两只鸡，用开水烫了，把毛拔了，然后串到烤肉叉上，快到晚上的时候把它们放到火上烤。两只鸡开始变成棕色，基本上快烤好了，但是客人还没有到。于是，格蕾特尔向她的主人喊道：“如果客人还不来，我就必须把鸡从火上拿开了，但是现在鸡烤得恰到好处，油都冒出来了，如果不马上吃了，真是太可惜了，简直是罪孽啊。”主人说：“我这就跑去把客人请来。”主人刚转身走开，格蕾特尔就把烤肉叉和鸡从火上取下来，心里想：“我在火边站了这么久，真是又热又渴，谁知道他们什么时候才能回来？这个时候，我一定要去酒窖里喝一口。”她跑过去，拿起一罐酒说：“上帝会保佑你喝了它的，格蕾特尔。”说完喝了一大口，又痛痛快快地喝了另外一大口。
en: It came to pass that the master one day said to her, “Grethel, there is a guest coming this evening; prepare me two fowls very daintily.”“I will see to it, master,” answered Grethel.She killed two fowls, scalded them, plucked them, put them on the spit, and towards evening set them before the fire, that they might roast.The fowls began to turn brown, and were nearly ready, but the guest had not yet arrived.Then Grethel called out to her master, “If the guest does not come, I must take the fowls away from the fire, but it will be a sin and a shame if they are not eaten directly, when they are juiciest.”The master said, “I will run myself, and fetch the guest.”When the master had turned his back, Grethel laid the spit with the fowls on one side, and thought, “Standing so long by the fire there, makes one hot and thirsty; who knows when they will come?Meanwhile, I will run into the cellar, and take a drink.”She ran down, set a jug, said, “God bless it to thy use, Grethel,” and took a good drink, and took yet another hearty draught.

zh: 然后，她再次把鸡放到火上，涂上油脂，高兴地把肉叉翻来翻去。但是，烤鸡的味道实在是太香了，格蕾特尔想：“可能还缺点佐料，应该尝尝！”她用手指碰了碰，说：“啊！多好的鸡啊！现在不马上吃了，真是可惜，是罪过！”她跑到窗户那儿，看看主人和客人是不是到了，但是她没看见一个人，就跑回到烤鸡那里，心想：“一只翅膀快烤焦了！我最好把它取下来，吃了。”因此她就把它切下来，享用了，吃完后她想：“另外一个也要弄下来，不然主人一定会发现少了点什么。”当她把两只翅膀都吃了，就跑去找她的主人，还是没有看见他。突然，她想到：“谁会知道？他们可能根本不会来了，去别的地方了。”然后，她说：“喂，格蕾特尔，好好吃吧，一只鸡已经切掉了两个翅膀，再喝一杯，把它都吃了；都吃了你才会心安一些，怎么能糟蹋上帝的礼物呢？”因此，她又跑进酒窖，喝了一大杯，兴高采烈地吃了一只鸡。当一只鸡被她吞进肚之后，她的主人还是没有回来，格蕾特尔看着另外一只鸡说：“那只鸡去了哪里，另外一只也应该跟着去，两只鸡应该一起。那只鸡怎么处理了，这只鸡也该怎么处理；我想如果我再喝上一口也没什么坏处。”因此，她又痛痛快快地喝了一大口，让第二只鸡去和第一只鸡团圆了。
en: Then she went and put the fowls down again to the fire, basted them, and drove the spit merrily round.But as the roast meat smelt so good, Grethel thought, “Something might be wrong, it ought to be tasted!”She touched it with her finger, and said, “Ah!how good fowls are!It certainly is a sin and a shame that they are not eaten directly!”She ran to the window, to see if the master was not coming with his guest, but she saw no one, and went back to the fowls and thought, “One of the wings is burning!I had better take it off and eat it.”So she cut it off, ate it, and enjoyed it, and when she had done, she thought, “the other must go down too, or else master will observe that something is missing.”When the two wings were eaten, she went and looked for her master, and did not see him.It suddenly occurred to her, “Who knows?They are perhaps not coming at all, and have turned in somewhere.”Then she said, “Hallo, Grethel, enjoy yourself, one fowl has been cut into, take another drink, and eat it up entirely; when it is eaten you will have some peace, why should God’s good gifts be spoilt?”So she ran into the cellar again, took an enormous drink and ate up the one chicken in great glee.When one of the chickens was swallowed down, and still her master did not come, Grethel looked at the other and said, “Where one is, the other should be likewise, the two go together; what’s right for the one is right for the other; I think if I were to take another draught it would do me no harm.”So she took another hearty drink, and let the second chicken rejoin the first.

zh: 她正吃得津津有味的时候，主人回来了，喊道：“快点儿，格蕾特尔，你快点儿，客人马上就到了！”“是的，主人，我马上就弄好。”格蕾特尔答道。同时，主人留心看看桌子已经布置好了，然后把切鸡用的大刀拿出来，去台阶上磨刀了。不一会儿，客人来了，亲切而又有礼貌地敲敲门。格蕾特尔跑去看是谁来了，当她看到是客人来了时，她把手指头竖在唇前，说：“嘘！嘘！赶紧逃跑吧，如果我的主人抓到你，你就惨了；他一定是说邀请你吃晚饭的吧，但是实际上他是想割掉你的两只耳朵。听听他这不是磨刀呢吗！”客人听到了磨刀声，慌忙地跑下台阶。格蕾特尔也没有耽搁；她尖叫着跑向主人，喊道：“你邀请来的贵客！”“啊，怎么啦，格蕾特尔？你说这话什么意思？”“是的，”她说，“他把我要端上来的鸡从盘子上抢走，拿着它们跑了！”“怎么会有这种事！”她的主人说，然后为可口的鸡感到惋惜。“如果他留一只给我，让我尝尝就好了。”他叫他停下来，但是客人装作没有听到。于是，他在后面追赶，手里拿着刀，喊着：“就要一只，就要一只。”意思是说客人应该留给他一只鸡，不要把两只都拿走。然而，客人想肯定是让他留下一只耳朵，跑得飞快像是火要烧到他了，带着两只耳朵回家去了。
en: While she was just in the best of the eating, her master came and cried, hurry up, “Haste thee, Grethel, the guest is coming directly after me!”“Yes, sir, I will soon serve up,” answered Grethel.Meantime the master looked to see that the table was properly laid, and took the great knife, wherewith he was going to carve the chickens, and sharpened it on the steps.Presently the guest came, and knocked politely and courteously at the house-door.Grethel ran, and looked to see who was there, and when she saw the guest, she put her finger to her lips and said, “Hush!hush!get away as quickly as you can, if my master catches you it will be the worse for you; he certainly did ask you to supper, but his intention is to cut off your two ears.Just listen how he is sharpening the knife for it!”The guest heard the sharpening, and hurried down the steps again as fast as he could.Grethel was not idle; she ran screaming to her master, and cried, “You have invited a fine guest!”“Eh, why, Grethel?What do you mean by that?”“Yes,” said she, “he has taken the chickens which I was just going to serve up, off the dish, and has run away with them!”“That’s a nice trick!” said her master, and lamented the fine chickens.“If he had but left me one, so that something remained for me to eat.”He called to him to stop, but the guest pretended not to hear.Then he ran after him with the knife still in his hand, crying, “Just one, just one,” meaning that the guest should leave him just one chicken, and not take both.The guest, however, thought no otherwise than that he was to give up one of his ears, and ran as if fire were burning under him, in order to take them both home with him.

zh: 聪明的汉斯
en: Clever Hans

zh: 汉斯的妈妈说：“汉斯，你去哪里？”汉斯回答：“我去格蕾特尔家。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“噢，我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”汉斯来到格蕾特尔家：“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。你带什么好东西来了吗？”“我什么都没带，我还想有人给我点什么呢。”格蕾特尔送给汉斯一根针。汉斯说：“再见，格蕾特尔。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: The mother of Hans said, “Whither away, Hans?”Hans answered, “To Grethel.”“Behave well, Hans.”“Oh, I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”Hans comes to Grethel, “Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.What dost thou bring that is good?”“I bring nothing, I want to have something given me.”Grethel presents Hans with a needle.Hans says, “Good-bye, Grethel.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯拿着针，把它插进草车里，跟着草车回到家里。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。你去哪里了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”“你送给她些什么？”“什么都没送给她；她还送我东西了呢。”“格蕾特尔送给了你什么？”“送给了我一根针。”“针在哪里，汉斯？”“插进草车里了。”“做得不对，汉斯。你应该把它插在袖子上。”“没关系，我下次会做得更好的。”
en: Hans takes the needle, sticks it into a hay-cart, and follows the cart home.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”“What didst thou take her?”“Took nothing; had something given me.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“Gave me a needle.”“Where is the needle, Hans?”“Stuck it in the hay-cart.”“That was ill done, Hans.Thou shouldst have stuck the needle in thy sleeve.”“Never mind, I’ll do better next time.”

zh: “你去哪里，汉斯？”“去格蕾特尔家，妈妈。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“噢，我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: “Whither away, Hans?”“To Grethel, mother.”“Behave well, Hans.”“Oh, I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯来到格蕾特尔家。“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。你给我带来什么好东西了吗？”“我什么都没带来；我想你送我些什么。”格蕾特尔送给了汉斯一把小刀。“再见，格雷特尔。”“再见，汉斯。”汉斯拿起刀子，插到袖子上，回到家里。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。你去哪了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”“你给她带些什么了？”“什么都没带，她给我东西了。”“格蕾特尔给你什么了？”“给了我一把刀。”“刀子在哪里，汉斯？”“插到我的袖子上了。”“做得不对，汉斯，你应该把它放到口袋里。”“没关系，我下次会做得更好的。”“你去哪里，汉斯？”“去格蕾特尔家，妈妈。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“噢，我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: Hans comes to Grethel.“Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.What dost thou bring that is good?”“I bring nothing; I want to have something given to me.”Grethel presents Hans with a knife.“Good-bye, Grethel.”“Good-bye Hans.”Hans takes the knife, sticks it in his sleeve, and goes home.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”“What didst thou take her?”“Took her nothing, she gave me something.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“Gave me a knife.”“Where is the knife, Hans?”“Stuck in my sleeve.”“That’s ill done, Hans, thou shouldst have put the knife in thy pocket.”“Never mind, will do better next time.”“Whither away, Hans?”“To Grethel, mother.” “Behave well, Hans.”“Oh, I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯来到格蕾特尔家。“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。你给我带什么好东西来了？”“我什么都没带，我想你送给我东西呢。”格蕾特尔送给汉斯一个小山羊。“再见，格蕾特尔。”“再见，汉斯。”汉斯带着小山羊，捆住它的腿，把它放进他的口袋里。他回到家里，小山羊被闷死了。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。你去哪里了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”“你给她带了些什么？”“什么都没带，她给我东西了。”“格蕾特尔给你什么了？”“她给了我一只山羊。”“山羊在哪里，汉斯？”“放到我的口袋里了。”“做得不对，汉斯，你应该用绳子套在山羊的脖子上。”“没关系，我下次会做得更好的。”
en: Hans comes to Grethel.“Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.What good thing dost thou bring?”“I bring nothing, I want something given me.”Grethel presents Hans with a young goat.“Good-bye, Grethel.”“Good-bye, Hans.”Hans takes the goat, ties its legs, and puts it in his pocket.When he gets home it is suffocated.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”“What didst thou take her?”“Took nothing, she gave me something.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“She gave me a goat.”“Where is the goat, Hans?”“Put it in my pocket.”“That was ill done, Hans, thou shouldst have put a rope round the goat’s neck.”“Never mind, will do better next time.”

zh: “你要去哪里，汉斯？”“去格蕾特尔家，妈妈。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“噢，我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”汉斯来到格蕾特尔家。“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。你给我带来什么好东西了吗？”“我什么都没带来，我想让你送给我呢。”格蕾特尔送给了汉斯一块儿熏肉。“再见，格蕾特尔。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: “Whither away, Hans?”“To Grethel, mother.”“Behave well, Hans.”“Oh, I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”Hans comes to Grethel.“Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.What good thing dost thou bring?”“I bring nothing, I want something given me.”Grethel presents Hans with a piece of bacon.“Good-bye, Grethel.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯拿着熏肉，用绳子系上，在后面拉着它。狗跑过来把熏肉吞了下去。当他回家后，绳子在手里，但是什么都没挂着了。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。”“你去哪里了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”你给她带了些什么？”“我什么都没给她带，她给我东西了。”“格蕾特尔给你什么了？”“给了我一丁点熏肉。”“熏肉在哪，汉斯？”“我把它系在绳子上，带回家的路上被狗吃了。”“做得不对，汉斯，你应该把它放到头上带回来。”“没关系，我下次会做得更好的。”“你去哪，汉斯？”“去格蕾特尔家，妈妈。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: Hans takes the bacon, ties it to a rope, and drags it away behind him.The dogs come and devour the bacon.When he gets home, he has the rope in his hand, and there is no longer anything hanging to it.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.”“Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”What didst thou take her?”“I took her nothing, she gave me something.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“Gave me a bit of bacon.”“Where is the bacon, Hans?”“I tied it to a rope, brought it home, dogs took it.”“That was ill done, Hans, thou shouldst have carried the bacon on thy head.”“Never mind, will do better next time.”“Whither away, Hans?”“To Grethel, mother.”“Behave well, Hans.”“I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯来到格蕾特尔家。“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。”“你带什么好东西了？”““我什么都没带，我想你送我些什么呢。”格蕾特尔送给汉斯一头小牛。“再见，格蕾特尔。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: Hans comes to Grethel.“Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.”“What good thing dost thou bring?”“I bring nothing, but would have something given.”Grethel presents Hans with a calf.“Good-bye, Grethel.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯带走小牛，把它放到头上，小牛踢他的脸。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。你去哪里了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”“你带给她些什么？”“我什么都没带给她，她送给我东西了。”“她送给你些什么？”“一头小牛。”“小牛在哪里，汉斯？”“我把它放到头上，它踢我的脸。”“做得不对，汉斯，你应该赶着小牛，把它赶到牲口棚里。”“没关系，我下次会做得更好的。”
en: Hans takes the calf, puts it on his head, and the calf kicks his face.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”“What didst thou take her?”“I took nothing, but had something given me.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“A calf.”“Where hast thou the calf, Hans?”“I set it on my head and it kicked my face.”“That was ill done, Hans, thou shouldst have led the calf, and put it in the stall.”“Never mind, will do better next time.”

zh: “你去哪里，汉斯？”“去格蕾特尔家，妈妈。”“表现好点儿，汉斯。”“我会好好表现的。再见，妈妈。”“再见，汉斯。”
en: “Whither away, Hans?”“To Grethel, mother.”“Behave well, Hans.”“I’ll behave well.Good-bye, mother.”“Good-bye, Hans.”

zh: 汉斯来到格蕾特尔家。“你好，格蕾特尔。”“你好，汉斯。你给我带什么好东西来了吗？”“我什么都没带，我还想你给我些什么呢。”格蕾特尔对汉斯说：“我和你一起去你家。”
en: Hans comes to Grethel.“Good day, Grethel.”“Good day, Hans.What good thing dost thou bring?”“I bring nothing, but would have something given.”Grethel says to Hans, “I will go with thee.”

zh: 汉斯把格蕾特尔系在一个绳子上，把她牵到喂草架上，把她捆得紧紧的。　然后，汉斯去见她的妈妈。“晚上好，妈妈。”“晚上好，汉斯。”你去哪里了？”“和格蕾特尔一起。”“你给她带了些什么呢？”“我什么都没给她带。”“她给你什么了？”“她什么都没给我，她和我一起来了。”“你把格蕾特尔带到哪里了？”“我用绳子牵着她，拴在架子上，给她倒了些草。”“做得不对，汉斯，你应该把友好的目光投给她。”“没关系，下次会做得更好。”
en: Hans takes Grethel, ties her to a rope, leads her to the rack and binds her fast.Then Hans goes to his mother.“Good evening, mother.”“Good evening, Hans.Where hast thou been?”“With Grethel.”“What didst thou take her?”“I took her nothing.”“What did Grethel give thee?”“She gave me nothing, she came with me.”“Where hast thou left Grethel?”“I led her by the rope, tied her to the rack, and scattered some grass for her.”“That was ill done, Hans, thou shouldst have cast friendly eyes on her.”“Never mind, will do better.”

zh: 汉斯走进牲口棚，把牛和羊的眼睛全都挖出来，扔到格蕾特尔脸上。格蕾特尔生气了，挣脱绳子跑走了，也不会做汉斯的新娘了。
en: Hans went into the stable, cut out all the calves’, and sheep’s eyes, and threw them in Grethel’s face.Then Grethel became angry, tore herself loose and ran away, and was no longer the bride of Hans.

zh: 弗雷德里克和凯瑟琳
en: Frederick and Catherine

zh: 很久以前，有个小伙子叫弗雷德里克，他娶了个老婆叫凯瑟琳，小两口新婚不久。一天，弗雷德里克对妻子说：“凯瑟琳，我要去耕田了，你务必准备些烤肉和新鲜啤酒放在桌上，等我回来，到时候我会又渴又饿。”“放心去吧，弗雷德里克，”凯瑟琳说，“放心去吧！我会准备好的。”临近午饭的时候，凯瑟琳从烟囱里取出一段香肠，扔进煎锅，和着黄油，一道放在炉火上煎。香肠开始煎得滋滋作响，凯瑟琳在一旁握着锅把，走起神来。她心想：“香肠还要再煎一会儿呢，何不趁现在去地窖打啤酒呢？”于是她把煎锅稳稳地放在火上，抓起酒罐就跑到地窖里去打酒。看着啤酒流入酒罐，她又猛然想到：“糟啦！楼上的狗没拴好，它肯定要把我的香肠叼走。还好我想到了！”她马上冲出地窖，但是绒毛狗已经叼起香肠，一路拖着香肠跑了。但是手忙脚乱的凯瑟琳拔腿就去追赶那条狗，一直撵到庄稼地里；那条狗呢，跑得比她快，并不想轻易结束它的香肠之旅，而是叼着香肠跨过了犁沟。“算了吧！”凯瑟琳只好往回走。因为刚才跑得太猛，累得不轻，她就慢慢悠悠地往回走，好让自己喘口气。就在这时，地窖里的啤酒还在从酒桶里往外流，因为她刚才忘了关龙头就跑出去了。于是啤酒灌满酒壶之后，就溢了出来，流到地窖里，直到整桶都漏光了。凯瑟琳一踏上地窖的楼梯，就看见了那灾难性的一幕。“我的老天哪！”她大叫道，“可别让弗雷德里克看见了！”她想了一会，猛然记起，上次赶集买的一袋精面粉还搁在阁楼上，可以拿来撒在啤酒上。“就是嘛，”她嘟囔着，“平时攒点什么，关键时候还真用得着呢！”她爬上阁楼，把面粉扛下来，往地窖里一扔，正好把那个酒罐给打翻了，给弗雷德里克备好的啤酒也洒在地窖里。“这倒好，”凯瑟琳说，“倒霉事全扎堆了！”她将整袋面粉全撒在地上。撒完之后，凯瑟琳兴奋地看着自己的杰作，高兴地说：“这儿看上去多干净整洁啊！”中午，弗雷德里克回家吃饭了：“嘿，老婆，做什么好吃的给我啦？”“唉，亲爱的，”妻子答道，“刚才，我锅里正给你煎着香肠呢，但是在去地窖给你打酒的时候，狗把香肠从锅里叼走了，我就去追狗，这时啤酒还流完了，我只有拿面粉来吸干地上的酒，又把你的酒罐碰翻了！不过你别担心，地窖里已经干啦！”弗雷德里克说道：“凯特啊凯特，你怎么能做这种傻事呢？竟然让狗叼走了香肠，啤酒还流光了，最后还搭上一袋子面粉！”“是啊，弗雷德里克，我不知道该怎么办。你早该教我的！”男人心想：“要是我老婆这么笨，那我以后可得看紧点儿了。”弗雷德里克以前攒下了许多银币，这时他全部兑换成了金币，然后对凯瑟琳说：“你看，这些都是赌博用的筹码；现在我把它们装进罐子里，埋在牛圈的食槽下面，你可千万别去碰，否则会惹麻烦的！”妻子回答道：“放心吧，我才不会碰它呢！”弗雷德里克出门后，几个卖盆盆罐罐的小贩子来到村里，见到这个年轻媳妇，就问她要不要买点什么。“唉，先生们，”凯瑟琳说，“我手里可没钱，买不了什么，可是我有一些黄铜筹码，你们愿意收的话，我就可以买你们的东西了。”“黄铜筹码？好啊！但是就给我们看看吧！”“那你们自己去牛圈的食槽下面挖吧，黄铜筹码就埋在那儿。我是不能过去的。”那些刁滑的小贩就走过去，在牛圈里挖出了那些金币。他们一拿到金币，就撇下那些盆盆罐罐，赶紧溜了。凯瑟琳心里想着要怎么用这些新东西，厨房里可什么都不缺，最后她把这些盆盆罐罐的底全部敲掉，一个个挂在屋外的篱笆上做装饰用。弗雷德里克回到家，看到篱笆上挂的那些新装饰，便问：“凯瑟琳，你这是干嘛呢？”“那些东西是我用你埋在牛圈下面的铜筹码买的。我可没过去，是那些小贩们自己去挖的。”“天哪，老婆呀，”弗雷德里克说，“瞧你都做了什么傻事啊！那些不是筹码，而是纯金币啊，是咱家的全部家当啊；你怎么能做这种事呢？”“是啊，老公，”妻子答道，“我不知道嘛，你怎么不早说呢？”
en: There was once on a time a man who was called Frederick and a woman called Catherine, who had married each other and lived together as young married folks.One day Frederick said, “I will now go and plough, Catherine; when I come back, there must be some roast meat on the table for hunger, and a fresh draught for thirst.”“Just go, Frederick,” answered Kate, “just go, I will have all ready for you.”Therefore when dinner-time drew near she got a sausage out of the chimney, put it in the frying-pan, put some butter to it, and set it on the fire.The sausage began to fry and to hiss, Catherine stood beside it and held the handle of the pan, and had her own thoughts as she was doing it.Then it occurred to her, “While the sausage is getting done thou couldst go into the cellar and draw beer.”So she set the frying-pan safely on the fire, took a can, and went down into the cellar to draw beer.The beer ran into the can and Kate watched it, and then she thought, “Oh, dear!The dog upstairs is not fastened up, it might get the sausage out of the pan.Well thought of.”And in a trice she was up the cellar-steps again, but the Spitz had the sausage in its mouth already, and trailed it away on the ground.But Catherine, who was not idle, set out after it, and chased it a long way into the field; the dog, however, was swifter than Catherine and did not let the sausage journey easily, but skipped over the furrows with it.“What’s gone is gone!” said Kate, and turned round, and as she had run till she was weary, she walked quietly and comfortably, and cooled herself.During this time the beer was still running out of the cask, for Kate had not turned the tap.And when the can was full and there was no other place for it, it ran into the cellar and did not stop until the whole cask was empty.As soon as Kate was on the steps she saw the mischance.“Good gracious!” she cried.“What shall I do now to stop Frederick knowing it!”She thought for a while, and at last she remembered that up in the garret was still standing a sack of the finest wheat flour from the last fair, and she would fetch that down and strew it over the beer.“Yes,” said she, “he who saves a thing when he ought, has it afterwards when he needs it,” and she climbed up to the garret and carried the sack below, and threw it straight down on the can of beer, which she knocked over, and Frederick’s draught swam also in the cellar.“It is all right,” said Kate, “where the one is the other ought to be also,” and she strewed the meal over the whole cellar.When it was done she was heartily delighted with her work, and said, “How clean and wholesome it does look here!”At mid-day home came Frederick: “Now, wife, what have you ready for me?”“Ah, Freddy,” she answered, “I was frying a sausage for you, but whilst I was drawing the beer to drink with it, the dog took it away out of the pan, and whilst I was running after the dog, all the beer ran out, and whilst I was drying up the beer with the flour, I knocked over the can as well, but be easy, the cellar is quite dry again.”Said Frederick, “Kate, Kate, you should not have done that!to let the sausage be carried off and the beer run out of the cask, and throw out all our flour into the bargain!”“Indeed, Frederick, I did not know that, you should have told me.”The man thought, “If my wife is like this, I must look after things more.”Now he had got together a good number of thalers which he changed into gold, and said to Catherine, “Look, these are counters for playing games; I will put them in a pot and bury them in the stable under the cow’s manger, but mind you keep away from them, or it will be the worse for you.”Said she, “Oh, no, Frederick, I certainly will not go.”And when Frederick was gone some pedlars came into the village who had cheap earthen-bowls and pots, and asked the young woman if there was nothing she wanted to bargain with them for?“Oh, dear people,” said Catherine, “I have no money and can buy nothing, but if you have any use for yellow counters I will buy of you.”“Yellow counters, why not?But just let us see them.”“Then go into the stable and dig under the cow’s manger, and you will find the yellow counters.I am not allowed to go there.”The rogues went thither, dug and found pure gold.Then they laid hold of it, ran away, and left their pots and bowls behind in the house.Catherine though she must use her new things, and as she had no lack in the kitchen already without these, she knocked the bottom out of every pot, and set them all as ornaments on the paling which went round about the house.When Frederick came and saw the new decorations, he said, “Catherine, what have you been about?”“I have bought them, Frederick, for the counters which were under the cow’s manger.I did not go there myself, the pedlars had to dig them out for themselves.”“Ah, wife,” said Frederick, “what have you done?Those were not counters, but pure gold, and all our wealth; you should not have done that.”“Indeed, Frederick,” said she, “I did not know that, you should have forewarned me.”

zh: 凯瑟琳站着想了会儿，然后对丈夫说：“听着，弗雷德里克，我们现在出发去追那些窃贼吧，把那些金币都追回来。”“那么，好吧，”弗雷德里克说，“我们试试吧，带点黄油和奶酪，我们路上饿了可以吃。”“好的，弗雷德里克，我这就去拿。”他们就出发了，弗雷德里克走得快些，因而凯瑟琳就跟在他后面。“这倒方便我了，”凯瑟琳心想，“往回走的时候，我就走在他前面了。”凯瑟琳来到一座大山前，路两侧都是深深的车辙。“看看，”凯瑟琳心想，“过路的车把可怜的地碾破轧伤了，这条路再也不会像以前那么平整了。”满怀同情心的凯瑟琳拿出黄油，把车辙两侧都抹了一遍，这样车轮碾过之时便不会如此受伤了。当她弯腰做好事的时候，一片奶酪从口袋里掉出来，滚到下山去了。凯瑟琳自言自语道：“我好不容易爬上山了，可不愿意再下去了；就让另一片奶酪去喊它回来吧。”于是她掏出第二片奶酪，扔下山去。但等了半天，都没回来，她又扔下第三片，心里想：“也许它们不想独自一人走路，而是等着结伴而行呢。”“也许它们不想独自一人走路，而是等着结伴而行呢。”由于三片奶酪都有去无归，凯瑟琳又说：“真是搞不懂，是不是第三片迷路走错了，那我再派第四片去找！”不过第四片也没回来交差。凯瑟琳发火了，她掏出剩下的第五片和第六片也扔下山去。她守在那儿等着，但是许久还是不见奶酪回来，便又说：“你们可真有本事啊！派你们出去这么久都不回来！别以为我会一直等着你们！我得赶路了，你们自己来追我吧；你们可比我年轻，跑得比我还快！”凯瑟琳就继续赶路，发现弗雷德里克在前方等着她，因为他想吃点东西。“把你带的食物拿出来吧！”他说。她只给了他一块干面包。“不是还叫你带了奶酪和黄油吗？”丈夫问。“哦，亲爱的，”凯瑟琳答道，“我把黄油抹在车辙里了，奶酪嘛，马上就自己回来了。有一片跑下山去了，我就派剩下的去找它去了。”弗雷德里克感叹道：“凯瑟琳，你怎么能用黄油去擦车辙印，让奶酪滚下山去呢！”“是啊，弗雷德里克，你早该教我的嘛！”于是，他们只能一起嚼着干面包，突然弗雷德里克问道：“凯瑟琳，出发的时候，家门关好了没？”“没关啊，弗雷德里克，你怎么不早说啊？”“那你就回去把门关好，顺便再带点吃的，我们吃了好继续赶路。我就在这儿等着你啊！”凯瑟琳就返身回家，她想：“弗雷德里克是想要吃点别的吧？那他肯定不喜欢黄油和奶酪了，我就带包梨子干给他，再拿罐醋给他解渴。”出门的时候，她把上半边门的门闩插好了，然后拆下下半边门，扛在背上，她想，门都随身带着呢，房子这下绝对安全了。凯瑟琳慢条斯理地走着，心想：“这样就可以让弗雷德里克多休息会儿了。”等她终于赶上老公，对他说：“我把门都给你扛来了，弗雷德里克，现在你可以自己看着啦。”“噢，我的老天爷！”他惊叹，“瞧我娶了个多么精明的老婆啊！她竟然把上半边门拴好，下半边门拆了，这样什么东西都能进去了。唉，现在让你再送回去也晚了。但既然你自己扛来的，你还是自己扛着吧！”“那就我扛吧，弗雷德里克，不过梨子干和醋罐实在太沉了，我把它们挂在门上，让门来背它们吧！”
en: Catherine stood for a while and bethought to herself; then she said, “Listen, Frederick, we will soon get the gold back again, we will run after the thieves.”“Come, then,” said Frederick, “we will try it; but take with you some butter and cheese that we may have something to eat on the way.”“Yes, Frederick, I will take them.”They set out, and as Frederick was the better walker, Catherine followed him.“It is to my advantage,” thought she, “when we turn back I shall be a little way in advance.”Then she came to a hill where there were deep ruts on both sides of the road.“There one can see,” said Catherine, “how they have torn and skinned and galled the poor earth, it will never be whole again as long as it lives,” and in her heart’s compassion she took her butter and smeared the ruts right and left, that they might not be so hurt by the wheels, and as she was thus bending down in her charity, one of the cheeses rolled out of her pocket down the hill.Said Catherine, “I have made my way once up here, I will not go down again; another may run and fetch it back.”So she took another cheese and rolled it down.But the cheeses did not come back, so she let a third run down, thinking,“perhaps they are waiting for company, and do not like to walk alone.”“Perhaps they are waiting for company, and do not like to walk alone.”As all three stayed away she said, “I do not know what that can mean, but it may perhaps be that the third has not found the way, and has gone wrong, I will just send the fourth to call it.”But the fourth did no better than the third.Then Catherine was angry, and threw down the fifth and sixth as well, and these were her last.She remained standing for some time watching for their coming, but when they still did not come, she said, “Oh, you are good folks to send in search of death, you stay a fine long time away!Do you think I will wait any longer for you?I shall go my way, you may run after me; you have younger legs than I.”Catherine went on and found Frederick, who was standing waiting for her because he wanted something to eat.“Now just let us have what you have brought with you,” said he.She gave him the dry bread.“Where have you the butter and the cheeses?” asked the man.“Ah, Freddy,” said Catherine, “I smeared the cart-ruts with the butter and the cheeses will come soon; one ran away from me, so I sent the others after to call it.”Said Frederick, “You should not have done that, Catherine, to smear the butter on the road, and let the cheeses run down the hill!”“Really, Frederick, you should have told me.”Then they ate the dry bread together, and Frederick said, “Catherine, did you make the house safe when you came away?”“No, Frederick, you should have told me to do it before.”“Then go home again, and make the house safe before we go any farther, and bring with you something else to eat.I will wait here for you.”Catherine went back and thought, “Frederick wants something more to eat, he does not like butter and cheese, so I will take with me a handkerchief full of dried pears and a pitcher of vinegar for him to drink.”Then she bolted the upper half of the door fast, but unhinged the lower door, and took it on her back, believing that when she had placed the door in security the house must be well taken care of.Catherine took her time on the way, and thought, “Frederick will rest himself so much the longer.”When she had once reached him she said, “Here is the house-door for you, Frederick, and now you can take care of the house yourself.”“Oh, heavens,” said he, “what a wise wife I have!She takes the under-door off the hinges that everything may run in, and bolts the upper one.It is now too late to go back home again, but since you have brought the door here, you shall just carry it farther.”“I will carry the door, Frederick, but the dried pears and the vinegar-jug will be too heavy for me, I will hang them on the door, it may carry them.”

zh: 他们走进树林了，四处寻找窃贼的踪迹，可是一无所获。天黑下来的时候，他们爬上一棵大树，准备在上面过夜。然而，他们刚在树枝上坐下来，树下竟然出现了那几个窃贼。这些窃贼总是拿走本不该被拿走的东西，被他们看上的东西一定会失踪。他们就在弗雷德里克和凯瑟琳藏身那棵树下坐了下来，几人升起一堆火便准备分赃。弗雷德里克从大树的另一边悄悄溜下来，捡了一些石块。然后他又爬上树去，打算从上面扔石块下来，砸死他们。但是石块都砸偏了！那几个无赖嚷道：“天恐怕要亮了吧，冷杉果都被风刮下来了！”凯瑟琳背上还背着一扇门呢，有点扛不住了，她觉得都是梨子干的问题，便对老公说：“弗雷德里克，我得把梨子干丢了哈！”“不行！凯瑟琳，现在可不行！”他回答道，“这样会暴露我们的！”“唉，但是，弗雷德里克，我实在是撑不住啦！我被压得不行了！”“那么就扔吧，真是找死！”梨子干就从树枝间滚下去，树下的几个无赖听见声音，就说：“是树叶落下来了。”
en: And now they went into the forest, and sought the rogues, but did not find them.At length as it grew dark they climbed into a tree and resolved to spend the night there.Scarcely, however, had they sat down at the top of it than the rascals came thither who carry away with them what does not want to go, and find things before they are lost.They sat down under the very tree in which Frederick and Catherine were sitting, lighted a fire, and were about to share their booty.Frederick got down on the other side and collected some stones together.Then he climbed up again with them, and wished to throw them at the thieves and kill them.The stones, however, did not hit them, and the knaves cried, “It will soon be morning, the wind is shaking down the fir-apples.Catherine still had the door on her back, and as it pressed so heavily on her, she thought it was the fault of the dried pears, and said, “Frederick, I must throw the pears down.”“No, Catherine, not now,” he replied, “they might betray us.”“Oh, but, Frederick, I must!They weigh me down far too much.”“Do it, then, and be hanged!”Then the dried pears rolled down between the branches, and the rascals below said, “The leaves are falling.”

zh: 过了一会儿，门依然很重，凯瑟琳受不了了，说：“唉，弗雷德里克，我得把醋倒下去了！”“不行，凯瑟琳，会暴露我们的！”“哎呀，但是，弗雷德里克，我没办法，实在是受不了了，醋好重啊！””那就倒吧，真是找死！”然后凯瑟琳就把醋倒下去了，洒在那些盗贼身上。那几个家伙说：“开始下露水了啊。”最后，凯瑟琳实在扛不住了，说：“难道一直是门太沉了？弗雷德里克，我得把门扔掉才行啦！”“不行，凯瑟琳，会暴露我们的！”“哦，但是，弗雷德里克，我没办法。我扛不住了，门太重了！”“哦，不行，凯瑟琳，坚持住！”“哎呀，弗雷德里克，我实在坚持不住了！”“那就扔了吧！真是见鬼！”门板就轰隆一下摔下去了，下面的几个无赖吓得大喊：“魔鬼下树了啊！”他们四散而逃，吓得什么都忘了带走。第二天一早，夫妻两个溜下树来，找回所有丢失的金币，带回家去了。
en: A short time afterwards, as the door was still heavy, Catherine said, “Ah, Frederick, I must pour out the vinegar.”“No, Catherine, you must not, it might betray us.”“Ah, but, Frederick, I must, it weighs me down far too much.”“Then do it and be hanged!”So she emptied out the vinegar, and it besprinkled the robbers.They said amongst themselves, “The dew is already falling.”At length Catherine thought, “Can it really be the door which weighs me down so?” and said, “Frederick, I must throw the door down.”“No, not now, Catherine, it might discover us.”“Oh, but, Frederick, I must.It weighs me down far too much.”“Oh, no, Catherine, do hold it fast.”“Ah, Frederick, I am letting it fall!”“Let it go, then, in the devil’s name.”Then it fell down with a violent clatter, and the rascals below cried, “The devil is coming down the tree!” and they ran away and left everything behind them.Early next morning, when the two came down they found all their gold again, and carried it home.

zh: 他们回到家后，弗雷德里克说：“凯瑟琳，从今往后，你也得好好干活了啊！”“好的，弗雷德里克，我会好好干的！我这就去地里收玉米去。”凯瑟琳来到地里，心里想：“收玉米之前是该先吃点东西，还是该睡一会儿呢？哦，我还是先吃点东西再说吧！”然后凯瑟琳就大吃起来，吃饱了又困了，她勉强支撑着去割麦子，半睡半醒之中把自己的衣服，包括围裙、外衣和连衣裙都当成麦子给割成碎片了。睡了很长时间之后，她醒来，看着自己半裸地站在那里，自言自语道：“这个人是我吗？哦，肯定不是啦！”这时天已经黑了，凯瑟琳跑回村里，敲着丈夫的窗户，大喊道：“弗雷德里克！”
en: When they were once more at home, Frederick said, “And now, Catherine, you, too, must be industrious and work.”“Yes, Frederick, I will soon do that, I will go into the field and cut corn.”When Catherine got into the field, she said to herself, “Shall I eat before I cut, or shall I sleep before I cut?Oh, I will eat first.”Then Catherine ate and eating made her sleepy, and she began to cut, and half in a dream cut all her clothes to pieces, her apron, her gown, and her shift.When Catherine awoke again after a long sleep she was standing there half-naked, and said to herself, “Is it I, or is it not I?Alas, it is not I.”In the meantime night came, and Catherine ran into the village, knocked at her husband’s window, and cried, “Frederick.”

zh: “什么事？”“我想问问凯瑟琳在不在家啊？”“在呢，在呢，”弗雷德里克回答道，“她应该在床上睡觉吧！”
en: “What is the matter?”“I should very much like to know if Catherine is in?”“Yes, yes,” replied Frederick, “she must be in and asleep.”

zh: 凯瑟琳说道：“哦，那我已经回家了嘛。”说完她就跑了。
en: Said she, “‘Tis well, then I am certainly at home already,” and ran away.

zh: 凯瑟琳走着走着，发现有几个小偷正准备偷人家东西呢。她走上去，对他们说：“我来给你们当帮手吧！”歹徒心想她熟悉这里的情况，就答应了。于是凯瑟琳走到几户人家门口，大声喊道：“好乡亲们，有什么好东西没？我们想来偷点东西！”小偷们吓了一跳，心想：“这不是坏事了嘛！”于是他们就想赶紧摆脱掉凯瑟琳。他们说：“村外的牧师家地里种着些萝卜。你去帮我们拔点回来吧。”于是凯瑟琳就来到牧师家的地里，开始拔萝卜，但是她拔了也懒得收。这时，一个人恰好路过，看见她，便停下脚步，心想，难道是魔鬼在拔萝卜？他赶紧跑到村里找到牧师，说：“牧师啊，有个魔鬼在你地里拔萝卜呢！”“天哪！”牧师回答道，“我有条腿瘸了，我不能出门，没法赶走它。”这个人说：“那我就背着你去吧！”说着，就背上牧师向地里跑去。他们来到地里，凯瑟琳这时刚好直起身来了。“天哪，是恶魔啊！”牧师吓得大叫，然后两个人撒腿就跑。牧师吓得不轻，他这个瘸腿的人，竟然比背他的那个健全人跑得还快呢！
en: Outside Catherine found some vagabonds who were going to steal.Then she went to them and said, “I will help you to steal.”The rascals thought that she knew the situation of the place, and were willing.Catherine went in front of the houses, and cried, “Good folks, have you anything?We want to steal.”The thieves thought to themselves, “That’s a fine way of doing things,” and wished themselves once more rid of Catherine.Then they said to her, “Outside the village the pastor has some turnips in the field.Go there and pull up some turnips for us.”Catherine went to the ground, and began to pull them up, but was so idle that she did not gather them together.Then a man came by, saw her, and stood still and thought that it was the devil who was thus rooting amongst the turnips.He ran away into the village to the pastor, and said, “Mr. Pastor, the devil is in your turnip-ground, rooting up turnips.”“Ah, heavens,” answered the pastor, “I have a lame foot, I cannot go out and drive him away.”Said the man, “Then I will carry you on my back,” and he carried him out on his back.And when they came to the ground, Catherine arose and stood up her full height.“Ah, the devil!” cried the pastor, and both hurried away, and in his great fright the pastor could run better with his lame foot than the man who had carried him on his back could do with his sound one.

zh: 赌鬼汉塞尔
en: Gambling Hansel

zh: 很久以前有一个人，他整天除了赌博之外什么都不做，也正是这个原因，人们除了叫他“赌鬼汉塞尔”外，从没称呼过他别的。由于他从来没有停止过赌博，他把他的房子和所有财产都输光了。到了债主们要来收房子的前一天，上帝和圣彼得来了，请求晚上的时候在他家借宿。赌鬼汉塞尔说：“对我来说，你们可以留下来过夜，但是没有可供你们休息的床，也没有任何吃的东西。”于是上帝说他们只想借宿，他们可以自己买东西吃。赌鬼汉塞尔对此没有异议。圣彼得随即给了他三枚银币，说让他去面包店买些面包。然后赌鬼汉塞尔就去了，但是当他走到其他赌棍聚集在一起的房子时，尽管他们已经赢走了他所有的财物，他们仍然冲他叫嚷着，说道：“汉塞尔，快进来吧。”“哦，”他说道，“你们想把这三枚银币也赢走吗？”汉塞尔说完，他们却还不放他走。于是他就进去了，把那三枚银币也输光了。同时圣彼得和上帝正等着他，因为他很久没回来，他们就动身去找他。赌鬼汉塞尔看见他们走过来，就装作把钱掉进了水沟里，还在那里一直认真地找，但是上帝已经知道他在赌博时输掉了。圣彼得又给了他三枚银币，而且这次汉塞尔再也不让自己上别人的钩了，终于给上帝和圣彼得买回了面包。然后上帝问他有没有葡萄酒，他说，“哎呀，先生，酒桶都是空的！”但是上帝说让他下酒窖去看看，因为最好的酒仍旧在那儿。半天他都不信，但是最后他说：“好吧，我下去，但是我知道那里已经没有葡萄酒了。”然而，当他拧开塞子，瞧啊，上好的葡萄酒就流了出来！于是他把葡萄酒拿给他们，上帝和圣彼得就在那里过了夜。第二天一大早，上帝告诉赌鬼汉塞尔他可以提三个请求。上帝以为他会请求到天堂里；但是赌鬼汉塞尔请求要一副可以赢得一切的扑克牌，一个可以赢得一切的骰子，一棵生长着各种果实的树，爬上这棵树的人，只要赌鬼汉塞尔不让他下来，他就下不来。上帝满足了他所有的请求，和圣彼得离开了。
en: Once upon a time there was a man who did nothing but gamble, and for that reason people never called him anything but Gambling Hansel, and as he never ceased to gamble, he played away his house and all that he had.Now the very day before his creditors were to take his house from him, came the Lord and St. Peter, and asked him to give them shelter for the night.Then Gambling Hansel said, “For my part, you may stay the night, but I cannot give you a bed or anything to eat.”So the Lord said he was just to take them in, and they themselves would buy something to eat, to which Gambling Hansel made no objection.Thereupon St. Peter gave him three groschen, and said he was to go to the baker’s and fetch some bread.So Gambling Hansel went, but when he reached the house where the other gambling vagabonds were gathered together, they, although they had won all that he had, greeted him clamorously, and said, “Hansel, do come in.”“Oh,” said he, “do you want to win the three groschen too?”On this they would not let him go.So he went in, and played away the three groschen also.Meanwhile St. Peter and the Lord were waiting, and as he was so long in coming, they set out to meet him.When Gambling Hansel came, however, he pretended that the money had fallen into the gutter, and kept raking about in it all the while to find it, but our Lord already knew that he had lost it in play.St. Peter again gave him three groschen, and now he did not allow himself to be led away once more, but fetched them the loaf.Our Lord then inquired if he had no wine, and he said, “Alack, sir, the casks are all empty!”But the Lord said he was to go down into the cellar, for the best wine was still there.For a long time he would not believe this, but at length he said, “Well, I will go down, but I know that there is none there.”When he turned the tap, however, lo and behold, the best of wine ran out!So he took it to them, and the two passed the night there.Early next day our Lord told Gambling Hansel that he might beg three favours.The Lord expected that he would ask to go to Heaven; but Gambling Hansel asked for a pack of cards with which he could win everything, for dice with which he would win everything, and for a tree whereon every kind of fruit would grow, and from which no one who had climbed up, could descend until he bade him do so.The Lord gave him all that he had asked, and departed with St. Peter.

zh: 现在赌鬼汉塞尔立即着手认真地赌博，不久以后他已经赢得了半个世界。圣彼得根据这个情况对上帝说：“上帝，这样的事情不能再继续下去了，他会赢得整个世界，而您会输掉整个世界。我们必须派死神去找他。”当死神出现的时候，赌鬼汉塞尔刚刚坐到赌桌前，然后死神说：“汉塞尔，出来一下。”但是赌鬼汉塞尔说：“等一小会儿，我把这局赌完，在这段时间里，你到外面那棵树上去，摘一些水果，我们可以在路上吃。”于是死神爬上了树，但是当他想要再下来的时候，他却下不来了。赌鬼汉塞尔让他在上面呆了七年，在这七年里没有人死去。
en: And now Gambling Hansel at once set about gambling in real earnest, and before long he had gained half the world.Upon this St. Peter said to the Lord, “Lord, this thing must not go on, he will win, and thou lose, the whole world.We must send Death to him.”When Death appeared, Gambling Hansel had just seated himself at the gaming-table, and Death said, “Hansel, come out a while.”But Gambling Hansel said, “Just wait a little until the game is done, and in the meantime get up into that tree out there, and gather a little fruit that we may have something to munch on our way.”Thereupon Death climbed up, but when he wanted to come down again, he could not, and Gambling Hansel left him up there for seven years, during which time no one died.

zh: 因此圣彼得对上帝说：“上帝，这种情况不能再继续下去了。人们都不会死了；我们必须亲自去一趟。”于是他们亲自去了，上帝命令汉塞尔让死神下来。因此，汉塞尔立即去见死神，然后对他说：“下来吧。”，死神一下来就直接把他杀了。他们一起离开，来到了另一个世界，然后赌鬼汉塞尔直接走到天堂的门口，敲了敲门。“谁在那儿？”“赌鬼汉塞尔。”“啊，我们不收留他！走开！”他又走到了炼狱门口，再次敲门。“谁在那儿？”“赌鬼汉塞尔。”“啊，这里就算没有他也已经全是哭泣声、哀号声了。我们不想赌博，你走吧。”然后他到了地狱门前，这次他们收留了他。然而，只有老撒旦和那些扭曲的小鬼在家，他们一直都在世上作恶。汉塞尔一坐下就又赌起来。然而，撒旦除了奇形怪状的小鬼外，没有什么可输的，于是赌鬼汉塞尔把小鬼都赢了过来，因为他的扑克牌不会让他输。现在他再次出发，带着他那些歪歪扭扭的小鬼去了霍恩福特，拔起一根啤酒花藤支柱，带回去捅天，天堂开始噼噼啪啪地响。于是，圣彼得再次说道：“上帝，这种情况不能再继续下去了，我们必须让他进来，否则他会把我们从天堂里扔下去。”于是他们让他进去了。但是，赌鬼汉塞尔立即又开始赌了，噪音和骚乱声之大，他们都听不到自己在说什么。因此，圣彼得再次说道：“上帝，这种情况不能再继续下去了，我们必须把他扔出去，否则他会把整个天堂弄得天翻地覆的。”于是他们立即去找他，并把他扔了下去，他的灵魂摔成了碎片，进入了赌棍的体内，到了今天还活在世上。
en: So St. Peter said to the Lord, “Lord, this thing must not go on.People no longer die; we must go ourselves.”And they went themselves, and the Lord commanded Hansel to let Death come down.So Hansel went at once to Death and said to him, “Come down,” and Death took him directly and put an end to him.They went away together and came to the next world, and then Gambling Hansel made straight for the door of Heaven, and knocked at it.“Who is there?”“Gambling Hansel.”“Ah, we will have nothing to do with him!Begone!”So he went to the door of Purgatory, and knocked once more.“Who is there?”“Gambling Hansel.”“Ah, there is quite enough weeping and wailing here without him.We do not want to gamble, just go away again.”Then he went to the door of Hell, and there they let him in.There was, however, no one at home but old Lucifer and the crooked devils who had just been doing their evil work in the world.And no sooner was Hansel there than he sat down to gamble again.Lucifer, however, had nothing to lose, but his mis-shapen devils, and Gambling Hansel won them from him, as with his cards he could not fail to do.And now he was off again with his crooked devils, and they went to Hohenfuert and pulled up a hop-pole, and with it went to Heaven and began to thrust the pole against it, and Heaven began to crack.So again St. Peter said, “Lord, this thing cannot go on, we must let him in, or he will throw us down from Heaven.”And they let him in.But Gambling Hansel instantly began to play again, and there was such a noise and confusion that there was no hearing what they themselves were saying.Therefore St. Peter once more said, “Lord, this cannot go on, we must throw him down, or he will make all Heaven rebellious.”So they went to him at once, and threw him down, and his soul broke into fragments, and went into the gambling vagabonds who are living this very day.

zh: 上帝的食物
en: God’s Food

zh: 从前有两姐妹，一个没有孩子，很富有，另一个生了五个孩子，是个寡妇，很穷，她和孩子们都已经没有吃的了。情急之下，她去她姐姐那儿，说：“我和我的孩子们都快饿死了，你那么富有，给我一口面包吧。”那个富姐姐心肠很硬，她说：“我自己家也没有吃的了。”然后对可怜的妹妹恶语相加，赶走了她。不久后，富姐姐的丈夫回到家，刚要给自己切片面包吃，但他第一刀刚切下去，鲜血就从面包中流了出来。他妻子看到后很是害怕，于是告诉了丈夫所发生的一切。他急忙离开，要去帮助寡妇和她的孩子们。可当他进屋后，发现寡妇在祈祷。她将两个最小的孩子搂在怀里，三个大一些的孩子躺在那儿，已经死了。他要给她食物，但她说：“我们不再需要俗世的食物了。上帝已经喂饱了三个孩子，我们的祈祷，上帝也同样会听见的。”她刚说完，两个最小的就断气了，随后她的心碎了，也倒下死去了。
en: There were once upon a time two sisters, one of whom had no children and was rich, and the other had five and was a widow, and so poor that she no longer had food enough to satisfy herself and her children.In her need, therefore, she went to her sister, and said, “My children and I are suffering the greatest hunger; thou art rich, give me a mouthful of bread.”The very rich sister was as hard as a stone, and said, “I myself have nothing in the house,” and drove away the poor creature with harsh words.After some time the husband of the rich sister came home, and was just going to cut himself a piece of bread, but when he made the first cut into the loaf, out flowed red blood.When the woman saw that she was terrified and told him what had occurred.He hurried away to help the widow and her children, but when he entered her room, he found her praying.She had her two youngest children in her arms, and the three eldest were lying dead.He offered her food, but she answered, “For earthly food have we no longer any desire.God has already satisfied the hunger of three of us, and he will hearken to our supplications likewise.”Scarcely had she uttered these words than the two little ones drew their last breath, whereupon her heart broke, and she sank down dead.

zh: 汉斯娶妻
en: Hans Married

zh: 在很久很久以前，有一个叫汉斯的年轻农民，他的叔叔想给他找个有钱的妻子。因此，他让汉斯在火炉后面坐下，把火炉烧得非常热。然后他取出一罐牛奶和很多白面包，又递给他一枚崭新的、闪闪发光的法新（1/4便士），说道：“汉斯，握紧那枚法新，把白面包弄成碎屑放到牛奶里，然后你就呆在这儿，在我回来之前不要乱动。”“好的，”汉斯说，“我会照您的吩咐做的。”然后，求爱者穿上一条旧的补丁裤，去找邻村一个有钱农民的女儿，说道：“嫁给我的侄子汉斯怎么样——你将得到一个适合你的、诚实明智的男人？”贪婪的父亲问道，“他的财产如何？”他吃得起面包吗？”“亲爱的朋友，”求爱者回复道，“我那年轻的侄子有舒适的床，手里有相当多的钱，还有很多面包可以掰着吃，除此之外，他也和我一样，有好多块儿。”（他边说，边拍着他裤子上的补丁，但是在那个区域，小块儿地也叫做“补丁”。）“如果你不怕麻烦可以和我回家看看，你马上就会看到我说的情形。”然后守财奴不想失去这么好的机会，说道：“如果确实如此，我不会再反对这门婚事了。”
en: There was once upon a time a young peasant named Hans, whose uncle wanted to find him a rich wife.He therefore seated Hans behind the stove, and had it made very hot.Then he fetched a pot of milk and plenty of white bread, gave him a bright newly-coined farthing in his hand, and said, “Hans, hold that farthing fast, crumble the white bread into the milk, and stay where you are, and do not stir from that spot till I come back.”“Yes,” said Hans, “I will do all that.”Then the wooer put on a pair of old patched trousers, went to a rich peasant’s daughter in the next village, and said, “Won’t you marry my nephew Hans—you will get an honest and sensible man who will suit you?”The covetous father asked, “How is it with regard to his means?Has he bread to break?”“Dear friend,” replied the wooer, “my young nephew has a snug berth, a nice bit of money in hand, and plenty of bread to break, besides he has quite as many patches as I have,” (and as he spoke, he slapped the patches on his trousers, but in that district small pieces of land were called patches also.) “If you will give yourself the trouble to go home with me, you shall see at once that all is as I have said.”Then the miser did not want to lose this good opportunity, and said, “If that is the case, I have nothing further to say against the marriage.”

zh: 因此婚礼在约定的日期举行了，当年轻的妻子走出房门去看看新郎的财产时，汉斯脱下他最好的衣服，穿上他带补丁的长罩衫说道，“我怕弄坏了我的好衣服。”然后他们一起出去了，看到了一块庄稼地和一块草地的交界处，汉斯用手指着，然后拍着他长罩衫上的一块儿大补丁和一块儿小补丁说，“那块儿是我的，那块儿也是，亲爱的，看看吧，”他的意思是说让他的妻子不要盯着那宽阔的土地看，而是看他的衣服，衣服上的补丁才是他的。
en: So the wedding was celebrated on the appointed day, and when the young wife went out of doors to see the bridegroom’s property, Hans took off his Sunday coat and put on his patched smock-frock and said, “I might spoil my good coat.”Then together they went out and wherever a boundary line came in sight, or fields and meadows were divided from each other, Hans pointed with his finger and then slapped either a large or a small patch on his smock-frock, and said, “That patch is mine, and that too, my dearest, just look at it,” meaning thereby that his wife should not stare at the broad land, but look at his garment, which was his own.

zh: “你确实是在婚礼上？”“是的，我确实在那儿，冠带齐全。我的头饰是雪做的；然后太阳一出来，它就化了。我的外衣是蛛丝做的，我又不得不穿过一些荆棘，都挂坏了，我的鞋是玻璃做的，我碰到一个石头上了，听到，‘叮当’一声，成了两半。”
en: “Were you indeed at the wedding?”“Yes, indeed I was there, and in full dress.My head-dress was of snow; then the sun came out, and it was melted.My coat was of cobwebs, and I had to pass by some thorns which tore it off me, my shoes were of glass, and I pushed against a stone and they said, “Klink,” and broke in two.

zh: 汉塞尔和格蕾特
en: Hansel and Grethel

zh: 在一个大森林附近，住着一个穷苦的砍柴人和他的妻子，还有他的两个孩子。儿子叫汉塞尔，女儿叫格蕾特。他们吃不起饭，日子过得很苦，有一年闹饥荒，家里连每天的口粮都没了。夜里，砍柴人躺在床上，想到眼前的困境，心里着急，辗转反侧，唉声叹气，他对妻子说：“我们该怎么办才好？我们自己都一无所有了，拿什么抚养我们苦命的孩子啊？”“老公，我告诉你怎么办，”妻子答道，“明天一早，我们就带孩子去森林最深处，在那儿点堆火，给孩子们各自留下一块面包，然后我们就去砍柴，把他们扔那儿不管了。他们肯定找不到回家的路，从今后我们就再也不用抚养他们了。”“不行，老婆，”男人说，“我做不到啊！我怎么能把自己的孩子遗弃在森林里呢？那些野兽很快就会发现他们，把他们撕碎的！”“哼，你这个蠢才！”妻子说，“那我们四个就都等着饿死吧！你这就去把棺材准备好吧。”妻子吵闹不休，男人别无他法，只得同意了。“但是我好心疼那两个苦命的孩子啊！”他哀叹道。
en: Hard by a great forest dwelt a poor wood-cutter with his wife and his two children.The boy was called Hansel and the girl Grethel.He had little to bite and to break, and once when great scarcity fell on the land, he could no longer procure daily bread.Now when he thought over this by night in his bed, and tossed about in his anxiety, he groaned and said to his wife, “What is to become of us?How are we to feed our poor children, when we no longer have anything even for ourselves?”“I’ll tell you what, husband,” answered the woman, “Early tomorrow morning we will take the children out into the forest to where it is the thickest, there we will light a fire for them, and give each of them one piece of bread more, and then we will go to our work and leave them alone.They will not find the way home again, and we shall be rid of them.”“No, wife,” said the man, “I will not do that; how can I bear to leave my children alone in the forest?—the wild animals would soon come and tear them to pieces.”“O, thou fool!” said she, “Then we must all four die of hunger, thou mayest as well plane the planks for our coffins,” and she left him no peace until he consented.“But I feel very sorry for the poor children, all the same,” said the man.

zh: 那两个孩子也因为太饿而睡不着觉，就听到了继母和爸爸的谈话。格蕾特伤心地哭了，她对汉塞尔说：“现在一切都完了。”“别哭，格蕾特，”汉塞尔说，“不用难过！我自有办法！”等大人们都睡了，汉塞尔从床上爬起来，披上他的小外套，打开下面的门，悄悄地爬出去了。月光是多么地皎洁啊，照得屋前地上的白色鹅卵石像银币一般闪闪发亮。汉塞尔弯下腰，捡了许多小石子，把外套的小衣兜装得满满的。回去以后，他对格蕾特说：“妹妹，你就安心地睡吧！上帝不会不管我们的。”然后他上床继续睡了。天刚朦朦亮，太阳还没升起来呢，继母就来把两个孩子喊起来了：“快起床！两个懒骨头！今天我们要去森林里砍柴。“继母给了两个孩子每人一小片面包，对他们说：“这是你俩的晚餐，别一下子吃完了，那可就什么都没有了。”汉塞尔的衣兜里装满了小石头，所以格蕾特就接过了面包，装进自己的围裙里。他们一家人便一起向森林出发了。每走一小会儿，汉塞尔就会停下，一次又一次转身回望家的方向。父亲问：“汉塞尔，落在后面在看什么呢？你这是在做什么呢？快赶路啊。”“哦，爸爸，”汉塞尔回答道，“我在看我的小白猫呢，它正蹲在屋梁上看着我，想和我说再见。”继母说：“傻瓜，那不是你的小白猫，那是太阳照在烟囱上的反光呢。”然而汉塞尔不是在看什么小白猫，他每次转身都悄悄地把兜里的小石头一一撒在路上。
en: The two children had also not been able to sleep for hunger, and had heard what their step-mother had said to their father.Grethel wept bitter tears, and said to Hansel, “Now all is over with us.”“Be quiet, Grethel,” said Hansel, “do not distress thyself, I will soon find a way to help us.”And when the old folks had fallen asleep, he got up, put on his little coat, opened the door below, and crept outside.The moon shone brightly, and the white pebbles which lay in front of the house glittered like real silver pennies.Hansel stooped and put as many of them in the little pocket of his coat as he could possibly get in.Then he went back and said to Grethel, “Be comforted, dear little sister, and sleep in peace, God will not forsake us,” and he lay down again in his bed.When day dawned, but before the sun had risen, the woman came and awoke the two children, saying “Get up, you sluggards!we are going into the forest to fetch wood.”She gave each a little piece of bread, and said, “There is something for your dinner, but do not eat it up before then, for you will get nothing else.”Grethel took the bread under her apron, as Hansel had the stones in his pocket.Then they all set out together on the way to the forest.When they had walked a short time, Hansel stood still and peeped back at the house, and did so again and again.His father said, “Hansel, what art thou looking at there and staying behind for?Mind what thou art about, and do not forget how to use thy legs.”“Ah, father,” said Hansel, “I am looking at my little white cat, which is sitting up on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me.”The wife said, “Fool, that is not thy little cat, that is the morning sun which is shining on the chimneys.”Hansel, however, had not been looking back at the cat, but had been constantly throwing one of the white pebble-stones out of his pocket on the road.

zh: 终于走到森林深处了，父亲对孩子们说：“孩子们，去拾些柴禾，我来点堆火，免得冻着你们。”汉塞尔和格莱特捡来好多小树枝，堆得像座小山。火堆点燃了，烧得很旺。继母对孩子们说：“孩子们，你们先在这儿烤火休息一会儿，我和你们爸爸去森林那边砍点柴。我们干完了就回来接你们。”
en: When they had reached the middle of the forest, the father said, “Now, children, pile up some wood, and I will light a fire that you may not be cold.”Hansel and Grethel gathered brushwood together, as high as a little hill.The brushwood was lighted, and when the flames were burning very high, the woman said, “Now, children, lay yourselves down by the fire and rest, we will go into the forest and cut some wood.When we have done, we will come back and fetch you away.”

zh: 汉塞尔和格蕾特就坐在火堆边等着。中午的时候，他们饿了，就把那一小片面包吃了。他们相信父亲就在不远处，因为还能听得见砍柴的声音。然而，事实上，那不是砍柴的声音，是父亲绑在枯树上的一段树枝，随风荡来荡去，发出的声音。两个孩子就一直坐在那儿等啊等，等到两眼都困得睁不开了，就睡着了。最后醒来的时候， 已经是深夜了。格蕾特开始哭了，说道：“我们怎么才能走出森林啊？”但汉塞尔安慰妹妹说：“再等一会儿，月亮升起来后，我们很快就会找到回家的路了。”不久，圆月升起。汉塞尔牵着妹妹的手，一路顺着在月光下如银币般闪闪发亮的鹅卵石，找到了回家的路。
en: Hansel and Grethel sat by the fire, and when noon came, each ate a little piece of bread, and as they heard the strokes of the wood-axe they believed that their father was near.It was not, however, the axe, it was a branch which he had fastened to a withered tree which the wind was blowing backwards and forwards.And as they had been sitting such a long time, their eyes shut with fatigue, and they fell fast asleep.When at last they awoke, it was already dark night.Grethel began to cry and said, “How are we to get out of the forest now?”But Hansel comforted her and said, “Just wait a little, until the moon has risen, and then we will soon find the way.”And when the full moon had risen, Hansel took his little sister by the hand, and followed the pebbles which shone like newly-coined silver pieces, and showed them the way.

zh: 他们走了整整一夜，第二天黎明时分才回到了父亲的家。他们敲了敲门，继母打开门，看见是他们，便说：“你们两个贪玩的小东西，怎么在森林里面睡了那么久呢？还以为你们不回来了呢！”可是爸爸非常高兴，他正为抛弃孩子们而心痛不已。
en: They walked the whole night long, and by break of day came once more to their father’s house.They knocked at the door, and when the woman opened it and saw that it was Hansel and Grethel, she said, “You naughty children, why have you slept so long in the forest?—we thought you were never coming back at all!”The father, however, rejoiced, for it had cut him to the heart to leave them behind alone.

zh: 不久之后，各地又闹饥荒。一天夜里，孩子们又听见继母对父亲说：“没吃的了，只剩半条面包了，吃完就什么都没了。那两个孩子必须得丢掉，这次我们把他们扔到森林的更深处，免得他们又自己找回家来了。只能这样，要不我们就等死吧！”男人心里很沉重，他相信：为人父母，应与子女的分享最后的食物。可是妻子根本就不听他的，只是一味地责骂他。可是一次妥协就意味着永远的妥协，父亲已经让步了一次，也只能再次让步了。
en: Not long afterwards, there was once more great scarcity in all parts, and the children heard their mother saying at night to their father, “Everything is eaten again, we have one half loaf left, and after that there is an end.The children must go, we will take them farther into the wood, so that they will not find their way out again; there is no other means of saving ourselves!”The man’s heart was heavy, and he thought “it would be better for thee to share the last mouthful with thy children.”The woman, however, would listen to nothing that he had to say, but scolded and reproached him.He who says A must say B, likewise, and as he had yielded the first time, he had to do so a second time also.

zh: 孩子们这次也没睡着，听到了继母和父亲的对话。等大人都睡了，汉塞尔又从床上爬起来，准备跟上次一样，出门捡些小石头做路标，可是，继母把门都锁死了，汉塞尔根本出不去。不过，他还是安慰妹妹，说：“别哭，格蕾特，安心地睡吧，好心的上帝会帮助我们的。”
en: The children were, however, still awake and had heard the conversation.When the old folks were asleep, Hansel again got up, and wanted to go out and pick up pebbles as he had done before, but the woman had locked the door, and Hansel could not get out.Nevertheless he comforted his little sister, and said, “Do not cry, Grethel, go to sleep quietly, the good God will help us.”

zh: 第二天一大早，继母来叫孩子们起床。她给了孩子们每人一小片面包，比上次的还小。在去森林路上，汉塞尔悄悄在口袋里把面包揉碎了，时不时地停下脚步，偷偷撒一点面包屑在路上。“汉塞尔，停下来东张西望地干什么呢？”父亲说，“快赶路吧！”“我看见我的小鸽子了，它就在屋顶上，好像在和我道别呢。”汉塞尔回答道。“傻瓜！”后母说，“那才不是你的小鸽子，是太阳照在烟囱上的反光呢。”然而，汉塞尔就这样一点一点地一路上撒着面包屑。
en: Early in the morning came the woman, and took the children out of their beds.Their bit of bread was given to them, but it was still smaller than the time before.On the way into the forest Hansel crumbled his in his pocket, and often stood still and threw a morsel on the ground.“Hansel, why dost thou stop and look round?” said the father, “go on.”“I am looking back at my little pigeon which is sitting on the roof, and wants to say good-bye to me,” answered Hansel.“Simpleton!” said the woman, “that is not thy little pigeon, that is the morning sun that is shining on the chimney.”Hansel, however, little by little, threw all the crumbs on the path.

zh: 后母把孩子们带进比上次更远的森林深处，那是他们从未到过的地方。她在那儿又点燃一大堆火，对孩子们说：“坐好了，孩子们，累了就自己睡一觉。我们要去森林里砍柴了，晚上干完活就回来接你们。”中午，兄妹俩分吃着格蕾特的那点面包，因为汉塞尔的已经撒在路上做路标了。过了一会儿，他们睡着了，天渐渐黑了，一直都没有人来找这两个可怜的孩子。夜深了，他们才醒来。汉塞尔安慰妹妹道：“等着吧，格莱特，等月亮升起来，我们就看得见路上的面包屑了，我们就可以找到路回家了。”月亮升起来，两兄妹寻找面包屑。可是哪里还有面包屑啊？树林里、田野里成千上万的鸟儿早就把面包屑吃光了。汉塞尔对格蕾特说：“我们很快就可以找到回家的路了。”可事实是，他们找不到了。他们走啊走，走了一整夜，第二天又从天亮走到天黑，却走不出森林，孩子们早就饿得不行了，他们没有东西吃，只有地上长着的几个浆果。走到双腿发软了，实在走不动了，他们就躺在一棵树下睡着了。
en: The woman led the children still deeper into the forest, where they had never in their lives been before.Then a great fire was again made, and the mother said, “Just sit there, you children, and when you are tired you may sleep a little; we are going into the forest to cut wood, and in the evening when we are done, we will come and fetch you away.”When it was noon, Grethel shared her piece of bread with Hansel, who had scattered his by the way.Then they fell asleep and evening came and went, but no one came to the poor children.They did not awake until it was dark night, and Hansel comforted his little sister and said, “Just wait, Grethel, until the moon rises, and then we shall see the crumbs of bread which I have strewn about, they will show us our way home again.”When the moon came they set out, but they found no crumbs, for the many thousands of birds which fly about in the woods and fields had picked them all up.Hansel said to Grethel, “We shall soon find the way,” but they did not find it.They walked the whole night and all the next day too from morning till evening, but they did not get out of the forest, and were very hungry, for they had nothing to eat but two or three berries, which grew on the ground.And as they were so weary that their legs would carry them no longer, they lay down beneath a tree and fell asleep.

zh: 这已经是离开父亲家以来的第三个早晨了。孩子们又继续往前走，但他们越走越深，要是再没有人帮助的话，他们会累死饿死的。正午时分，他们看见一只漂亮的小鸟正停在树枝上，浑身雪白，唱着悦耳的歌，兄妹俩不由得停下脚步，聆听起来。小鸟唱完，就扇着翅膀在他们前面飞起来了，兄妹俩一路跟过去，来到一座小屋子前。小鸟在屋顶落下，兄妹俩走近小屋，才发现小屋竟然是用面包砌的墙，蛋糕做的屋顶，晶莹透亮的糖果做的窗户！“现在我们有吃的了，”汉塞尔对妹妹说，“我们好好地大吃一顿吧！我想吃屋顶，格蕾特，你去尝尝窗子，肯定很甜很甜的。”汉塞尔够到顶上，掰下一小块屋顶，尝了尝；妹妹呢，靠在窗户上，一点一点地啃起来。突然，一个细微的声音从屋里传出来：
en: It was now three mornings since they had left their father’s house.They began to walk again, but they always got deeper into the forest, and if help did not come soon, they must die of hunger and weariness.When it was mid-day, they saw a beautiful snow-white bird sitting on a bough, which sang so delightfully that they stood still and listened to it.And when it had finished its song, it spread its wings and flew away before them, and they followed it until they reached a little house, on the roof of which it alighted; and when they came quite up to little house they saw that it was built of bread and covered with cakes, but that the windows were of clear sugar.“We will set to work on that,” said Hansel, “and have a good meal.I will eat a bit of the roof, and thou, Grethel, canst eat some of the window, it will taste sweet.”Hansel reached up above, and broke off a little of the roof to try how it tasted, and Grethel leant against the window and nibbled at the panes.Then a soft voice cried from the room,

zh: “啃，啃，啃！是谁在啃我的小屋子啊？”
en: “Nibble, nibble, gnaw, Who is nibbling at my little house?”

zh: 孩子们回答道：
en: The children answered,

zh: “是风，是风，是空中的风。”
en: “The wind, the wind, The heaven-born wind,”

zh: 孩子们继续吃，饥饿已经让他们什么都顾不上了。汉塞尔觉得屋顶的蛋糕真是太美味了，就掰下了一大块慢慢吃；格蕾特呢，干脆把整块圆玻璃都拆下来，坐下来慢慢吃。突然，门开了，一个老太太拄着拐棍，悄悄地走出来。汉塞尔和格蕾特见到她，吓了一跳，手里的吃的都掉到了地上。然而，老太太却笑着点了点头，说：“哦，可爱的孩子们，是谁把你们带到我这儿来的呢？进屋里来吧，就住我这儿。没有人会伤害你们的。”她拉起两个孩子的小手，把他们带进了屋。她拿出好多好吃的给孩子们吃，有牛奶、蛋糕、糖果、苹果，还有坚果。之后，她在两张漂亮的小床上铺上雪白的亚麻床单，让孩子们睡在上面，汉赛尔和格蕾特觉得简直像进了天堂一般。
en: and went on eating without disturbing themselves.Hansel, who thought the roof tasted very nice, tore down a great piece of it, and Grethel pushed out the whole of one round window-pane, sat down, and enjoyed herself with it.Suddenly the door opened, and a very, very old woman, who supported herself on crutches, came creeping out.Hansel and Grethel were so terribly frightened that they let fall what they had in their hands.The old woman, however, nodded her head, and said, “Oh, you dear children, who has brought you here?Do come in, and stay with me.No harm shall happen to you.”She took them both by the hand, and led them into her little house.Then good food was set before them, milk and pancakes, with sugar, apples, and nuts.Afterwards two pretty little beds were covered with clean white linen, and Hansel and Grethel lay down in them, and thought they were in heaven.

zh: 其实，这位老太太的善心都是装出来的，她其实是个邪恶的巫婆，专门造了这座美味甜点的小屋子来引诱他们的。一旦有孩子落入她的圈套，她就会杀了他，然后煮了吃掉，对她来说，那可是值得庆祝的丰收之宴。巫婆长着红彤彤的眼睛，看不清远处，不过她们的嗅觉可跟野兽一样灵敏，每当有人类走进，她就闻得到。之前当汉塞尔和格蕾特出现在附近的时候，她就闻到了，她邪恶地笑着，阴险地说：“哈哈！他们是我的了，可逃不出我的手掌心！”第二天一早，孩子们还在熟睡之中，巫婆就起身了，她来到他们的床前，看着他们熟睡中肉嘟嘟、红彤彤的小脸蛋，自言自语道：“真是香喷喷的美味啊！”她用她干枯如树枝的手一把抓住汉塞尔，把他丢到一间小马圈里，关在了栅栏后。汉塞尔惊恐得大声叫喊，可是没有用。老巫婆来到格蕾特身旁，抓住她用力地摇醒，大声喊道：“起床了，懒东西，快去挑水，给你哥哥煮好吃的去，他现在在屋外的马圈里呢，要把他养得胖胖的。等他长肥了，我就吃了他。”格蕾特伤心地大哭起来，可是有什么用呢？她必须得照巫婆的命令去做。
en: The old woman had only pretended to be so kind; she was in reality a wicked witch, who lay in wait for children, and had only built the little house of bread in order to entice them there.When a child fell into her power, she killed it, cooked and ate it, and that was a feast day with her.Witches have red eyes, and cannot see far, but they have a keen scent like the beasts, and are aware when human beings draw near.When Hansel and Grethel came into her neighborhood, she laughed maliciously, and said mockingly, “I have them, they shall not escape me again!”Early in the morning before the children were awake, she was already up, and when she saw both of them sleeping and looking so pretty, with their plump red cheeks, she muttered to herself, “That will be a dainty mouthful!”Then she seized Hansel with her shrivelled hand, carried him into a little stable, and shut him in with a grated door.He might scream as he liked, that was of no use.Then she went to Grethel, shook her till she awoke, and cried, “Get up, lazy thing, fetch some water, and cook something good for thy brother, he is in the stable outside, and is to be made fat.When he is fat, I will eat him.”Grethel began to weep bitterly, but it was all in vain, she was forced to do what the wicked witch ordered her.

zh: 于是，每天，汉塞尔都能吃到格蕾特做的可口的饭菜，可格蕾特只能吃点螃蟹壳充饥。每天早晨，老巫婆都会溜到小马圈，对汉塞尔喊道：“汉塞尔， 把你的手指头伸出来给我摸摸，看看你快长胖了没有。”汉塞尔呢，每次都伸出一只小骨头，老巫婆眼睛看不清楚，就以为真是他的手指，感到非常纳闷，搞不清楚怎么老是喂不肥他。四个星期过去了，汉塞尔的手指摸起来还是那么干枯，老巫婆不耐烦了，再也等不下去了。“嘿，格蕾特，”她对女孩嚷道，“跑快点，快去挑水！我可不管汉塞尔是胖是瘦，明天我一定要把他杀了吃了。”苦命的妹妹去挑水的时候，恸哭起来，泪水顺着脸颊流淌！她喊道：“亲爱的上帝，请救救我们吧！就算被林子里的野兽吞吃了，我们也能死在一起了。”“省省吧，”巫婆说，“谁也救不了你们。”
en: And now the best food was cooked for poor Hansel, but Grethel got nothing but crab-shells.Every morning the woman crept to the little stable, and cried, “Hansel, stretch out thy finger that I may feel if thou wilt soon be fat.”Hansel, however, stretched out a little bone to her, and the old woman, who had dim eyes, could not see it, and thought it was Hansel’s finger, and was astonished that there was no way of fattening him.When four weeks had gone by, and Hansel still continued thin, she was seized with impatience and would not wait any longer.“Hola, Grethel,” she cried to the girl, “be active, and bring some water.Let Hansel be fat or lean, to-morrow I will kill him, and cook him.”Ah, how the poor little sister did lament when she had to fetch the water, and how her tears did flow down over her cheeks!“Dear God, do help us,” she cried.“If the wild beasts in the forest had but devoured us, we should at any rate have died together.”“Just keep thy noise to thyself,” said the old woman, “all that won’t help thee at all.”

zh: 第二天一早，格蕾特就得起床，挑水，架锅，烧火。“我们先烤面包，”巫婆说，“我已经把炉子烧热了，面也揉好了。”她把可怜的格蕾特推到炉子跟前，炉子里的火苗已经窜出老高。“你给我爬进去！”巫婆命令道，“看看炉子是不是够热了，够热就把面包放进去。”老巫婆的如意算盘是：等格蕾特一爬进去，她就在外面把炉门关上，把她烤熟，然后就可以一道把她吃了。不过格蕾特可是完全看穿了巫婆的用心，说：“我不知道怎么爬进去，你是怎么进去的呢？”“真是个大笨蛋！”老巫婆说，“门足够大，看着，我这个老婆子都爬得进去！”老巫婆跪下来，把头伸了进去。格蕾特赶紧把老巫婆往炉子里用力一推，然后合上炉子门，插好炉闩。啊！老巫婆在炉子里凄惨地叫喊，但格蕾特却跑开了。邪恶的巫婆就这样被活活地烧死了。
en: Early in the morning, Grethel had to go out and hang up the cauldron with the water, and light the fire.“We will bake first,” said the old woman, “I have already heated the oven, and kneaded the dough.”She pushed poor Grethel out to the oven, from which flames of fire were already darting.“Creep in,” said the witch, “and see if it is properly heated, so that we can shut the bread in.”And when once Grethel was inside, she intended to shut the oven and let her bake in it, and then she would eat her, too.But Grethel saw what she had in her mind, and said, “I do not know how I am to do it; how do you get in?”“Silly goose,” said the old woman, “The door is big enough; just look, I can get in myself!” and she crept up and thrust her head into the oven.Then Grethel gave her a push that drove her far into it, and shut the iron door, and fastened the bolt.Oh! then she began to howl quite horribly, but Grethel ran away, and the godless witch was miserably burnt to death.

zh: 这时，格蕾特飞也似的跑去找哥哥，打开马圈的门，喊道：“汉塞尔，我们得救了！老巫婆死了！”门一打开，汉塞尔就像只出笼的小鸟一样冲了出来。他们高兴地紧紧地拥抱着，又蹦又跳，开心地亲吻着彼此！因为他们已经不用再害怕那个老巫婆了，于是便回到那个小屋子，屋子里的每个角落都有成箱的金银珠宝。“这些比我们的小石子可好多了！”汉塞尔高兴地说，把衣兜塞得满满的。格蕾特说：“我也要带点东西回家。”也把围裙装满了宝贝。“现在我们可以走了，”汉塞尔说，“离开这个老巫婆的森林。”
en: Grethel, however, ran like lightning to Hansel, opened his little stable, and cried, “Hansel, we are saved!The old witch is dead!”Then Hansel sprang out like a bird from its cage when the door is opened for it.How they did rejoice and embrace each other, and dance about and kiss each other!And as they had no longer any need to fear her, they went into the witch’s house, and in every corner there stood chests full of pearls and jewels.“These are far better than pebbles!” said Hansel, and thrust into his pockets whatever could be got in, and Grethel said, “I, too, will take something home with me,” and filled her pinafore full.“But now we will go away.” said Hansel, “that we may get out of the witch’s forest.”

zh: 走啊走，走了两个钟头，他们来到一条大河边。“我们这样可过不去啊！”汉塞尔说，“没有踏板，也没有桥。”“也没有船，”格蕾特说，“不过你看，那边有只白色的鸭子在水里游着，我去求求它渡我们过河吧！”格蕾特对鸭子喊道：
en: When they had walked for two hours, they came to a great piece of water.“We cannot get over,” said Hansel, “I see no foot-plank, and no bridge.”“And no boat crosses either,” answered Grethel, “but a white duck is swimming there; if I ask her, she will help us over.”Then she cried,

zh: “小鸭子，小鸭子，你看见我们了吗？汉塞尔和格蕾特正等着你呢。河上既没有踏板，也没有桥。
en: “Little duck, little duck, dost thou see, Hansel and Grethel are waiting for thee?There’s never a plank, or bridge in sight,

zh: 请用你洁白的背驮我们过河吧！”
en: Take us across on thy back so white.”

zh: 鸭子游过来，汉塞尔骑到了鸭子背上，让妹妹坐在他身旁。“不行，”格蕾特说，“我们两个一起坐太沉了，让小鸭子一个一个地送我们过去吧。”好心的小鸭子就这样把他们送过了岸。两兄妹渡过河继续前行，走了一小会儿，就发觉树林越看越熟悉了，最后，终于远远地望见了父亲的家。两个孩子高兴地奔跑起来 ，冲进家门，直扑进爸爸的怀里。爸爸自从把孩子们丢弃在森林里，就没开心过一天。而那个狠心的继母也过世了。格蕾特把兜里的珍珠玉石都倾倒出来，撒了一地；汉塞尔也从兜里大把大把地掏出珠宝来。从此，他们一家再无烦恼，生活得开开心心，无忧无虑。我的故事讲完了。看见那边有只大老鼠没？谁捉住它，就可以拿鼠皮做顶皮帽了。
en: The duck came to them, and Hansel seated himself on its back, and told his sister to sit by him.“No,” replied Grethel, “that will be too heavy for the little duck; she shall take us across, one after the other.”The good little duck did so, and when they were once safely across and had walked for a short time, the forest seemed to be more and more familiar to them, and at length they saw from afar their father’s house.Then they began to run, rushed into the parlour, and threw themselves into their father’s arms.The man had not known one happy hour since he had left the children in the forest; the woman, however, was dead.Grethel emptied her pinafore until pearls and precious stones ran about the room, and Hansel threw one handful after another out of his pocket to add to them.Then all anxiety was at an end, and they lived together in perfect happiness.My tale is done, there runs a mouse, whosoever catches it, may make himself a big fur cap out of it.

zh: 克布斯先生
en: Herr Korbes

zh: 有一次，小公鸡和小母鸡想要一同旅行。于是，小公鸡造了一辆漂亮的马车，马车备有四个红色的车轮，由四只小老鼠拉着。小母鸡坐上马车，与小公鸡一起驾车出发了。不一会儿，他们遇到了一只猫，猫问道：“你们要去哪儿啊？”小公鸡回答说：“我们要去克布斯先生家。”猫说道：“带我一起去吧！”小公鸡说：“好呀，从后面上来吧，免得你从前面上来摔下去。千万要小心，别把我的红色小车轮弄脏了。亲爱的车轮们，往前滚动吧，亲爱的老鼠们，喊起你们的号子，我们接着往克布斯先生家走。”
en: There were once a cock and a hen who wanted to take a journey together.So the cock built a beautiful carriage, which had four red wheels, and harnessed four mice to it.The hen seated herself in it with the cock, and they drove away together.Not long afterwards they met a cat who said, “Where are you going?”The cock replied, “We are going to the house of Herr Korbes.”“Take me with you,” said the cat.The cock answered, “Most willingly, get up behind, lest you fall off in front.Take great care not to dirty my little red wheels.And you little wheels, roll on, and you little mice pipe out, as we go forth on our way to the house of Herr Korbes.”

zh: 后来它们又碰到一个磨盘、一个鸡蛋、一只鸭子、一根别针和一根缝衣针，大家都坐上了马车，前往克布斯家。不过，它们到克布斯先生家时，克布斯先生出去了。小老鼠们把马车拉进了谷仓，小母鸡和小公鸡飞上了栖木。猫坐在炉边，鸭子蹲到井架上。鸡蛋滚进了毛巾里，别针把自己钉在坐垫上，缝衣针跳上了床钻到了枕头中间，而磨盘则平躺着呆在门框上。克布斯先生回到家了。他走向了壁炉想要生火，猫扑了他一脸炭灰。他连忙跑进厨房洗脸，鸭子又把水溅了他一脸。他想要拿毛巾擦干，可鸡蛋滚到他脸上，碎了，把他的眼睛都糊住了。他想在椅子上歇一会，于是坐了下来，别针便扎了他一下。他气坏了，往床上一躺，可头刚落在枕头上，就被缝衣针扎了一下。他尖声大叫起来，怒气冲冲地想要跑出去，可刚到门口，磨盘就跳了下来，把他砸死了。克布斯先生一定是一个大坏蛋！
en: After this came a millstone, then an egg, then a duck, then a pin, and at last a needle, who all seated themselves in the carriage, and drove with them.When, however, they reached the house of Herr Korbes, Herr Korbes was not there.The mice drew the carriage into the barn, the hen flew with the cock upon a perch.The cat sat down by the hearth, the duck on the well-pole.The egg rolled itself into a towel, the pin stuck itself into the chair-cushion, the needle jumped on to the bed in the middle of the pillow, and the millstone laid itself over the door.Then Herr Korbes came home, went to the hearth, and was about to light the fire, when the cat threw a quantity of ashes in his face.He ran into the kitchen in a great hurry to wash it off, and the duck splashed some water in his face.He wanted to dry it with the towel, but the egg rolled up against him, broke, and glued up his eyes.He wanted to rest, and sat down in the chair, and then the pin pricked him.He fell in a passion, and threw himself on his bed, but as soon as he laid his head on the pillow, the needle pricked him, so that he screamed aloud, and was just going to run out into the wide world in his rage, but when he came to the house-door, the millstone leapt down and struck him dead.Herr Korbes must have been a very wicked man!

zh: 一只眼、两只眼和三只眼
en: One-eye, Two-eyes, and Three-eyes

zh: 从前，有个女人，她有三个女儿。大女儿只有一只眼睛，长在前额正中间，所以她叫一只眼。二女儿和普通人一样长着两只眼睛，所以她叫两只眼。小女儿有三只眼睛，她的第三只眼睛也长在前额的正中间，所以她叫三只眼。　　　然而，由于两只眼看东西和其他普通人一模一样，她的姐妹和妈妈都不能忍受她。她们对她说：“你长着两只眼，和那些普通人一样，你和我们不是一家人！”她们还任意摆布她，给她穿旧衣服，给她吃剩饭剩菜，并且还想方设法折磨她。有一天，两只眼的姐妹们只给她一点儿吃的，虽然她依然很饿，她们还让她去到田野里放羊。于是她坐在山丘上开始哭啊哭，哭得是那么伤心，她的眼泪像两条小河似的不断地从眼睛里往下淌。她悲伤地抬起头来时，发现一个女人站在她身边，这个女人问道：“可怜的两只眼，你为什么哭啊？”两只眼回答说：“叫我怎能不哭呢？因为我和普通人一样长着两只眼，我的姐妹和妈妈都讨厌我。她们对我任意摆布，只让我穿旧衣服，让我吃剩饭剩菜。今天她们给我吃的太少，现在我还是很饿！”那时，睿智的女人说道：“两只眼，擦掉你的眼泪，让我来告诉你一个好办法，你以后就不会再挨饿了。你只要对着你的羊说：
en: THERE was once a woman who had three daughters, the eldest of whom was called One-eye, because she had only one eye in the middle of her forehead, and the second, Two-eyes, because she had two eyes like other folks, and the youngest, Three-eyes, because she had three eyes; and her third eye was also in the centre of her forehead.However, as Two-eyes saw just as other human beings did, her sisters and her mother could not endure her.They said to her, “Thou, with thy two eyes, art no better than the common people; thou dost not belong to us!”They pushed her about, and threw old clothes to her, and gave her nothing to eat but what they left, and did everything that they could to make her unhappy.It came to pass that Two-eyes had to go out into the fields and tend the goat, but she was still quite hungry, because her sisters had given her so little to eat.So she sat down on a ridge and began to weep, and so bitterly that two streams ran down from her eyes.And once when she looked up in her grief, a woman was standing beside her, who said, “Why art thou weeping, little Two-eyes?”Two-Eyes answered, “Have I not reason to weep, when I have two eyes like other people, and my sisters and mother hate me for it, and push me from one corner to another, throw old clothes at me, and give me nothing to eat but the scraps they leave?Today they have given me so little that I am still quite hungry.”Then the wise woman said, “Wipe away thy tears, Two-eyes, and I will tell thee something to stop thee ever suffering from hunger again; just say to thy goat,

zh: ‘小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快放好！’
en: “Bleat, my little goat, bleat, Cover the table with something to eat,”

zh: 然后你的面前就会出现一张干干净净、摆放整齐的小饭桌，桌上摆满了好吃的东西，你可以尽情地吃个够。吃饱之后，你就不再需要这个小饭桌了，这时，你只要说：
en: and then a clean well-spread little table will stand before thee, with the most delicious food upon it of which thou mayst eat as much as thou art inclined for, and when thou hast had enough, and hast no more need of the little table, just say,

zh: ‘小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快收好。’
en: “Bleat, bleat, my little goat, I pray, And take the table quite away,”

zh: 那样它就会在你眼前消失。”说完，那个睿智的女人就离开了。两只眼心里想：“我一定要马上试一试，看她说的是不是真的，因为我实在是太饿了。”于是，她说：
en: and then it will vanish again from thy sight.”Hereupon the wise woman departed.But Two-eyes thought, “I must instantly make a trial, and see if what she said is true, for I am far too hungry,” and she said,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快放好！”
en: “Bleat, my little goat, bleat, Cover the table with something to eat,”

zh: 话音刚落，一张铺着白色台布的小饭桌便出现在她眼前了。饭桌上放好了盘子、刀叉和银勺，满桌的美味热腾腾的，就好像是刚从厨房里端出来的一样。于是，两只眼说了一句最简短的祷词：“上帝啊，愿你和我们永远在一起，阿门！”接着她便津津有味地吃了起来。吃饱之后，她就按照那个睿智的女人所教的，说道：
en: and scarcely had she spoken the words than a little table, covered with a white cloth, was standing there, and on it was a plate with a knife and fork, and a silver spoon; and the most delicious food was there also, warm and smoking as if it had just come out of the kitchen.Then Two-eyes said the shortest prayer she knew, “Lord God, be with us always, Amen,” and helped herself to some food, and enjoyed it.And when she was satisfied, she said, as the wise woman had taught her,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快收好。”
en: “Bleat, bleat, my little goat, I pray, And take the table quite away,”

zh: 转眼间，小饭桌和上面的东西就都不见了。两只眼感到非常快乐，非常幸福，她心里想：“这样的生活真是美好啊！”
en: and immediately the little table and everything on it was gone again.“That is a delightful way of keeping house!” thought Two-eyes, and was quite glad and happy.

zh: 天黑了，她赶着羊回到家中，看到姐妹们在她的小陶碟里留下的一口剩饭，就连碰都没去碰一下。第二天她又出去放羊，出门时并没有把她们留给她的几口碎面包带上，面包依旧放在那里，她碰都没碰。她这样做，开始姐妹们根本没有注意到。可是她每次都这样，她们就开始察觉，说：“两只眼有些不正常，以前给她什么她都会吃个精光，可是现在一口不吃就走了。她一定有其他办法找吃的。”她们为了弄清真相，决定让一只眼跟着两只眼去牧场放羊，监视两只眼在那儿到底做了什么，看看是不是有人给她送去吃的喝的。于是，当两只眼又要出去放羊的时候，一只眼走过去对她说：“今天我陪你一起去牧场，看看你放羊放得好不好，是不是把羊带到了草多的地方。”可是两只眼看透了她的心思，便把羊赶进高高的草丛中，然后对她说：“一只眼，过来吧，咱们坐下，我唱歌给你听。”一只眼坐了下来，她不习惯走那么远路，再加上烈日炎炎，所以她感到很疲倦，并且两只眼一遍又一遍地唱着：
en: In the evening, when she went home with her goat, she found a small earthenware dish with some food, which her sisters had set ready for her, but she did not touch it.Next day she again went out with her goat, and left the few bits of broken bread which had been handed to her, lying untouched.The first and second time that she did this, her sisters did not remark it at all, but as it happened every time, they did observe it, and said, “There is something wrong about Two-eyes, she always leaves her food untasted, and she used to eat up everything that was given her; she must have discovered other ways of getting food.”In order that they might learn the truth, they resolved to send One-eye with Two-eyes when she went to drive her goat to the pasture, to observe what Two-eyes did when she was there, and whether any one brought her anything to eat and drink.So when Two-eyes set out the next time, One-eye went to her and said, “I will go with you to the pasture, and see that the goat is well taken care of, and driven where there is food.”But Two-eyes knew what was in One-eye’s mind, and drove the goat into high grass and said, “Come, One-eye, we will sit down, and I will sing something to you.”One-eye sat down and was tired with the unaccustomed walk and the heat of the sun, and Two-eyes sang constantly,

zh: “一只眼，你还醒着吗？一只眼，你睡着了吗？”
en: “One eye, wakest thou?One eye, sleepest thou?”

zh: 直到一只眼闭上了她那一只眼，进入了梦乡，两只眼才停下来，看到她已经睡熟了，不会发现什么了，就说道：
en: until One-eye shut her one eye, and fell asleep, and as soon as Two-eyes saw that One-eye was fast asleep, and could discover nothing, she said,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快放好！”
en: “Bleat, my little goat, bleat, Cover the table with something to eat,”

zh: 然后她就坐在桌旁吃起来、喝起来，一直到她吃饱喝足了，她又大声说道：
en: and seated herself at her table, and ate and drank until she was satisfied, and then she again cried,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快收好。”
en: “Bleat, bleat, my little goat, I pray, And take the table quite away,”

zh: 转眼间，一切都立刻消失了。这时，两只眼叫醒一只眼，对她说：“一只眼，你想来放羊，可是你却睡着了，羊会趁机跑丢的。走吧，我们回家吧。”她们回到家里，两只眼还是一口饭都没吃。一只眼却没法向她妈妈解释为什么两只眼不吃饭，只得为自己开脱：“我在外面睡着了。”
en: and in an instant all was gone.Two-eyes now awakened One-eye, and said, “One-eye, you want to take care of the goat, and go to sleep while you are doing it, and in the meantime the goat might run all over the world.Come, let us go home again.”So they went home, and again Two-eyes let her little dish stand untouched, and One-eye could not tell her mother why she would not eat it, and to excuse herself said, “I fell asleep when I was out.”

zh: 第二天，妈妈对三只眼说：“这次你跟着两只眼，看她是不是在外面吃过东西了，是不是有人给她送吃的喝的，要明白，她肯定是背着我们大吃大喝了。”于是，三只眼走到两只眼面前说：“我陪你去放羊，看看你放羊放得好不好，是不是把羊带到了草多的地方。”可是，两只眼又看透了她的心思，就把羊赶到了高高的草丛中，对三只眼说：“三只眼，我们坐下来吧，我要唱歌给你听。”三只眼坐下来，走了那么远的路，再加上烈日炎炎，她已经很累了，这时两只眼又唱起上次的歌：
en: Next day the mother said to Three-eyes, “This time thou shalt go and observe if Two-eyes eats anything when she is out, and if any one fetches her food and drink, for she must eat and drink in secret.”So Three-eyes went to Two-eyes, and said, “I will go with you and see if the goat is taken proper care of, and driven where there is food.”But Two-eyes knew what was in Three-eyes’ mind, and drove the goat into high grass and said, “We will sit down, and I will sing something to you, Three-eyes.”Three-eyes sat down and was tired with the walk and with the heat of the sun, and Two-eyes began the same song as before, and sang,

zh: “三只眼，你还醒着吗？”
en: “Three eyes, are you waking?”

zh: 可是那时，她本应该接着唱：
en: but then, instead of singing,

zh: “三只眼，你睡着了吗？”
en: “Three eyes, are you sleeping?”

zh: 但是她不小心却唱成：
en: as she ought to have done, she thoughtlessly sang,

zh: “两只眼，你睡着了吗？”
en: “Two eyes, are you sleeping?”

zh: 然后一直反复地唱着：
en: and sang all the time,

zh: “三只眼，你还醒着吗？两只眼，你睡着了吗？”
en: “Three eyes, are you waking?Two eyes, are you sleeping?”

zh: 唱着，唱着，三只眼就闭上两只眼睛进入梦乡了，但是两只眼在歌中没提到的第三只眼却还醒着。的确，三只眼将第三只眼闭上了，但她却是在狡猾地装睡，她的第三只眼一眨一眨的，能够看清所发生的一切。两只眼以为三只眼真的已经睡熟了，便念起咒语：
en: Then two of the eyes which Three-eyes had, shut and fell asleep, but the third, as it had not been named in the song, did not sleep.It is true that Three-eyes shut it, but only in her cunning, to pretend it was asleep too, but it blinked, and could see everything very well.And when Two-eyes thought that Three-eyes was fast asleep, she used her little charm,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快放好！”
en: “Bleat, my little goat, bleat, Cover the table with something to eat,”

zh: 然后她就放心享用起吃的喝的，之后就叫桌子消失：
en: and ate and drank as much as her heart desired, and then ordered the table to go away again,

zh: “小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快收好。”
en: “Bleat, bleat, my little goat, I pray, And take the table quite away,”

zh: 三只眼什么都看见了。两只眼过去把她叫醒，说道：“三只眼，你睡着了吗？你放羊放得真好！走吧，我们回家吧。”她们回到家以后，两只眼又没吃东西。三只眼就对妈妈说：“此刻我终于明白了那傲慢的家伙为什么不吃东西了。在田野里，她对着羊儿说：
en: and Three-eyes had seen everything.Then Two-eyes came to her, waked her and said, “Have you been asleep, Three-eyes?You are a good care-taker!Come, we will go home.”And when they got home, Two-eyes again did not eat, and Three-eyes said to the mother, “Now, I know why that high-minded thing there does not eat.When she is out, she says to the goat,

zh: ‘小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快放好！’
en: ‘Bleat, my little goat, bleat, Cover the table with something to eat,’

zh: 于是她面前就出现了一张小饭桌，上面摆满了美味的食物，比我们吃的好多了。她吃饱以后，又说道：
en: and then a little table appears before her covered with the best of food, much better than any we have here, and when she has eaten all she wants, she says,

zh: ‘小羊儿，咩咩叫，小饭桌，快收好。’
en: ‘Bleat, bleat, my little goat, I pray, And take the table quite away,’

zh: 然后所有东西就都消失了。我把这一切看得清清楚楚。她念咒给我听，我的两只眼睛就睡着了，可是幸好我前额的第三只眼睛还醒着。”那心怀嫉妒的妈妈听后，大声说道：“你想吃得比我们还好吗？以后你就别想啦！”于是妈妈拿起一把屠刀，一刀刺进羊的心脏，那只羊倒在地上死了。
en: and all disappears.I watched everything closely.She put two of my eyes to sleep by using a certain form of words, but luckily the one in my forehead kept awake.”Then the envious mother cried, “Dost thou want to fare better than we do?The desire shall pass away,” and she fetched a butcher’s knife, and thrust it into the heart of the goat, which fell down dead.

zh: 见此情形，两只眼十分难过地离开了家，坐在田野边野草遍布的山丘上大哭了起来。突然，那个睿智的女人又站在她的身边，对她说：“两只眼，你为什么哭啊？”“叫我怎么能不哭呢？”她回答道，“我一念你教的咒语，那只小羊就把小饭桌为我摆好，如今它却被我妈妈杀掉了。现在我又要忍饥挨饿了。”睿智的女人说道：“两只眼，我告诉你一个好方法，你去求你的姐妹把这只羊的内脏分给你，然后把它埋在你家门前的地里，这样，它就又会给你带来好运了。”话音刚落，那个女人就消失了。两只眼回到家里，跟她的姐妹说道：“亲爱的姐妹，分给我一点羊身上的东西吧。我不想要什么好东西，给我点内脏就行啦！”她们笑着说：“如果那就是你想要的，你尽管拿好了。”两只眼就拿了羊内脏，天黑以后按照那个睿智的女人说的那样悄悄地把它埋在了她家门前的地里。
en: When Two-eyes saw that, she went out full of trouble, seated herself on the ridge of grass at the edge of the field, and wept bitter tears.Suddenly the wise woman once more stood by her side, and said, “Two-eyes, why art thou weeping?”“Have I not reason to weep?” she answered.“The goat which covered the table for me every day when I spoke your charm, has been killed by my mother, and now I shall again have to bear hunger and want.”The wise woman said, “Two-eyes, I will give thee a piece of good advice; ask thy sisters to give thee the entrails of the slaughtered goat, and bury them in the ground in front of the house, and thy fortune will be made.”Then she vanished, and Two-eyes went home and said to her sisters, “Dear sisters, do give me some part of my goat; I don’t wish for what is good, but give me the entrails.”Then they laughed and said, “If that’s all you want, you can have it.”So Two-eyes took the entrails and buried them quietly in the evening, in front of the house-door, as the wise woman had counselled her to do.

zh: 第二天早上，当她们醒来，走出家门，看到面前挺立着一棵奇妙的树，上面长着银色的叶子和金色的果实。世界上再也没有比这更美丽、更珍贵的东西了。可她们却弄不明白，一夜之间怎么会长出这么一棵树来。只有两只眼清楚这是从羊的内脏里长出来的，因为这棵树正好长在她埋内脏的地方。此刻，妈妈对一只眼说：“孩子，爬到树上去，把果实给我们摘下来。”一只眼爬了上去，但是每当她要伸出手去摘那些金色的苹果时，树枝却总是从她的手里滑脱开来，每次都如此。就这样，不管她怎么努力，还是一个苹果也没摘到。于是妈妈说道：“三只眼，你上去吧，你有三只眼睛，你能比一只眼看得更准些。”一只眼爬下来，三只眼又爬了上去。她和一只眼一样，不论她怎么伸手去够，那些苹果总是避开她。最后，妈妈不耐烦了，便自己爬了上去，但是和一只眼三只眼一样，一抓一个空，一个苹果都没摘到。此时，两只眼说道：“让我上去试试吧，或许我能摘到苹果呢。”姐妹们大叫起来：“你，你长着两只眼睛，你能做什么呢？”但两只眼爬上了树，金色的苹果不但不从她手边溜走，反倒主动送到了她的手里。这样她就一个接一个地摘，把满满一围裙金苹果带了下来。妈妈从两只眼那里拿走了那些金苹果，但她并不因此对可怜的两只眼好些，她们只是嫉妒只有她一个人能摘到金苹果，所以对她变本加厉。
