en: Next morning, when they all awoke, and went to the house-door, there stood a strangely magnificent tree with leaves of silver, and fruit of gold hanging among them, so that in all the wide world there was nothing more beautiful or precious.They did not know how the tree could have come there during the night, but Two-eyes saw that it had grown up out of the entrails of the goat, for it was standing on the exact spot where she had buried them.Then the mother said to One-eye, “Climb up, my child, and gather some of the fruit of the tree for us.”One-eye climbed up, but when she was about to get hold of one of the golden apples, the branch escaped from her hands, and that happened each time, so that she could not pluck a single apple, let her do what she might.Then said the mother, “Three-eyes, do you climb up; you with your three eyes can look about you better than One-eye.”One-eye slipped down, and Three-eyes climbed up.Three-eyes was not more skilful, and might search as she liked, but the golden apples always escaped her.At length the mother grew impatient, and climbed up herself, but could get hold of the fruit no better than One-eye and Three-eyes, for she always clutched empty air.Then said Two-eyes, “I will just go up, perhaps I may succeed better.”The sisters cried, “You indeed, with your two eyes, what can you do?”But Two-eyes climbed up, and the golden apples did get out of her way, but came into her hand of their own accord, so that she could pluck them one after the other, and brought a whole apronful down with her.The mother took them away from her, and instead of treating poor Two-eyes any better for this, she and One-eye and Three-eyes were only envious, because Two-eyes alone had been able to get the fruit, and they treated her still more cruelly.

zh: 一天，正当她们都站在树下，一个年轻的骑士从远处走了过来。“两只眼，快点！”姐妹俩叫道，“蹲在这下面，不要给我们丢脸！”她们急忙用树旁的空桶盖住了两只眼，把她刚刚摘下来的金苹果也一同盖上了。当骑士走近时，她们发现他是一个英俊的贵族，他停下来欣赏这棵奇妙的金银树，对姐妹俩说：“这棵树是谁的啊？谁要是能给我折下一枝，她要什么我都会给的。”一只眼和三只眼说这树是她们的，她们愿意折一枝送给他。她们便使出浑身解数去折，但就是折不下来，因为树枝和果实老是避开她们的手。骑士看后说道：“这真是太奇怪了，树既然是你们的，可是你们连一枝树枝都折不下来！”姐妹俩还是坚持说这棵树是她们的。就在她们说话的时候，两只眼从桶下扔出几只金苹果，苹果滚到了骑士的脚边，因为姐妹俩的谎言把她惹恼了。骑士看到苹果很吃惊，就问苹果是从哪里来的。一只眼和三只眼回答说，她们还有一个姐妹，因为她和普通人一样有两只眼睛，不能出来和生人见面。然而，骑士却很想见她，就叫道：“两只眼，出来吧。”于是，两只眼放心地从桶里钻了出来，骑士见她长得十分美丽，很是惊异，就说：“两只眼，你肯定能为我从树上折下一枝树枝。”“是的。”两只眼回答道，“我肯定能做到，因为这树是我的。”于是两只眼爬到树上，轻而易举地折下了一枝长满银叶和金果的树枝，送给了骑士。骑士说：“两只眼，我怎样才能报答你呢？”“唉！”两只眼回答道，“在这儿我整天忍饥挨饿，痛苦不堪，如果你能把我带走，救我出去，我会很高兴的。”于是，骑士就把两只眼抱上马，把她带回到他父亲的城堡。在那儿，他让两只眼穿上华丽的衣服，让她尽情地享用美味。骑士非常爱她，就娶了她，他们举行了神圣的婚礼，非常幸福。两只眼被英俊的骑士带走以后，她的两个姐妹十分嫉妒她的好运。“不过这棵树还在我们这里。”她们想，“即使我们不能从树上摘下果子，可人人都会驻足观赏，来到我们这里称赞它。说不定哪天我们也会交上好运呢！”可是第二天早上，那棵树就不见了，姐妹俩的希望也落了个空。此刻两只眼从她的小房间往窗外看，让她高兴的是，那棵树就矗立在她的面前，原来它也跟着来到了这里。
en: It so befell that once when they were all standing together by the tree, a young knight came up.“Quick, Two-eyes,” cried the two sisters, “creep under this, and don’t disgrace us!” and with all speed they turned an empty barrel which was standing close by the tree over poor Two-eyes, and they pushed the golden apples which she had been gathering, under it too.When the knight came nearer he was a handsome lord, who stopped and admired the magnificent gold and silver tree, and said to the two sisters, “To whom does this fine tree belong?Any one who would bestow one branch of it on me might in return for it ask whatsoever he desired.”Then One-eye and Three-eyes replied that the tree belonged to them, and that they would give him a branch.They both took great trouble, but they were not able to do it, for the branches and fruit both moved away from them every time.Then said the knight, “It is very strange that the tree should belong to you, and that you should still not be able to break a piece off.”They again asserted that the tree was their property.Whilst they were saying so, Two-eyes rolled out a couple of golden apples from under the barrel to the feet of the knight, for she was vexed with One-eye and Three-eyes, for not speaking the truth.When the knight saw the apples he was astonished, and asked where they came from.One-eye and Three-eyes answered that they had another sister, who was not allowed to show herself, for she had only two eyes like any common person.The knight, however, desired to see her, and cried, “Two-eyes, come forth.”Then Two-eyes, quite comforted, came from beneath the barrel, and the knight was surprised at her great beauty, and said, “Thou, Two-eyes, canst certainly break off a branch from the tree for me.”“Yes,” replied Two-eyes, “that I certainly shall be able to do, for the tree belongs to me.”And she climbed up, and with the greatest ease broke off a branch with beautiful silver leaves and golden fruit, and gave it to the knight.Then said the knight, “Two-eyes, what shall I give thee for it?”“Alas!” answered Two-eyes, “I suffer from hunger and thirst, grief and want, from early morning till late night; if you would take me with you, and deliver me from these things, I should be happy.”So the knight lifted Two-eyes on to his horse, and took her home with him to his father’s castle, and there he gave her beautiful clothes, and meat and drink to her heart’s content, and as he loved her so much he married her, and the wedding was solemnized with great rejoicing.When Two-eyes was thus carried away by the handsome knight, her two sisters grudged her good fortune in downright earnest.The wonderful tree, however, still remains with us,” thought they, “and even if we can gather no fruit from it, still every one will stand still and look at it, and come to us and admire it.Who knows what good things may be in store for us?”But next morning, the tree had vanished, and all their hopes were at an end.And when Two-eyes looked out of the window of her own little room, to her great delight it was standing in front of it, and so it had followed her.

zh: 两只眼幸福地度过了很长时间。一天，有两个可怜的女人走进她住的城堡，求她施舍。两只眼一看到她们的脸，才知道是她的姐姐和妹妹。她们俩现在穷困潦倒，不得不四处流浪，挨家挨户地乞讨为生。然而，两只眼不仅欢迎她们，还十分善待她们，她们俩为自己当年虐待两只眼而感到悔恨不已。
en: Two-eyes lived a long time in happiness.Once two poor women came to her in her castle, and begged for alms.She looked in their faces, and recognized her sisters, One-eye, and Three-eyes, who had fallen into such poverty that they had to wander about and beg their bread from door to door.Two-eyes, however, made them welcome, and was kind to them, and took care of them, so that they both with all their hearts repented the evil that they had done their sister in their youth.

zh: 圣母的小玻璃杯
en: Our Lady’s Little Glass

zh: 从前有个车夫，他的车载满了酒，陷在泥里走不了了，不论他怎么弄，车就是没法前进。就在那时圣母偶然经过，她看到这个可怜的车夫如此苦恼，于是对他说：“我累了，很渴，给我一杯酒吧，然后我就可以让你的车走起来。”“乐意之极，”车夫答道，“但是我没有玻璃杯，没法给你乘酒。”于是圣母摘了一朵带红色条纹的小白花，人们叫它田旋花，这种花看起来很像一个玻璃杯，圣母将其递给车夫。车夫往杯里倒满酒，然后圣母喝了，与此同时，车也活动起来了，车夫得以驾车前行。现在人们还是总把这种小花叫做“圣母的小玻璃杯”。
en: Once upon a time a waggoner’s cart which was heavily laden with wine had stuck so fast that in spite of all that he could do, he could not get it to move again.Then it chanced that Our Lady just happened to come by that way, and when she perceived the poor man’s distress, she said to him, “I am tired and thirsty, give me a glass of wine, and I will set thy cart free for thee.”“Willingly,” answered the waggoner, “but I have no glass in which I can give thee the wine.”Then Our Lady plucked a little white flower with red stripes, called field bindweed, which looks very like a glass, and gave it to the waggoner.He filled it with wine, and then Our Lady drank it, and in the self-same instant the cart was set free, and the waggoner could drive onwards.The little flower is still always called Our Lady’s Little Glass.

zh: 甜粥
en: Sweet Porridge

zh: 从前有个贫穷的好女孩儿，她跟妈妈单独住在一起，她们没有食物了。所以小女孩儿到森林里去，那里住着一位老婆婆，老婆婆知道小女孩儿的悲伤，于是赠给她一个小锅，当她说“做饭，小锅，做饭”，小锅就可以熬出美味的甜粥，当她说“停下来，小锅”，小锅就停止煮食物。小女孩把锅拿回家给妈妈，现在她们就不会再因为贫穷而挨饿了，她们可以喝到可口的甜粥，而且想喝多少就喝多少。有一次小女孩外出，她的妈妈说：“做饭，小锅，做饭。”然后，小锅就煮出了美味的粥，最后她吃得很饱。当她想让小锅停下来时却不知道该对小锅说什么。所以小锅不停地煮着，粥溢出来了，但是小锅仍旧继续煮着粥，整个厨房、整个房子，到处都是粥，邻居家也是同样的情况，然后是整条街到处都流着粥，好像小锅要把整个饥饿的世界都喂饱似的，大家都非常惊慌失措，但是没人知道怎么做才能让小锅停下来。最后，只剩下一间房子没有被粥填满了，小孩回到家，只说了句：“停下来，小锅。”然后小锅就停下来了，不再煮粥。要是谁想回到这个小镇，就必须一路喝着粥回家。
en: THERE was a poor but good little girl who lived alone with her mother, and they no longer had anything to eat.So the child went into the forest, and there an aged woman met her who was aware of her sorrow, and presented her with a little pot, which when she said, “Cook, little pot, cook,” would cook good, sweet porridge, and when she said, “Stop, little pot,” it ceased to cook.The girl took the pot home to her mother, and now they were freed from their poverty and hunger, and ate sweet porridge as often as they chose.Once on a time when the girl had gone out, her mother said, “Cook, little pot, cook.”And it did cook and she ate till she was satisfied, and then she wanted the pot to stop cooking, but did not know the word.So it went on cooking and the porridge rose over the edge, and still it cooked on until the kitchen and whole house were full, and then the next house, and then the whole street, just as if it wanted to satisfy the hunger of the whole world, and there was the greatest distress, but no one knew how to stop it.At last when only one single house remained, the child came home and just said, “Stop, little pot,” and it stopped and gave up cooking, and whosoever wished to return to the town had to eat his way back.

zh: 鸡驮的木头
en: The Beam

zh: 从前有一个巫师，他站在一大群人中间表演他的巫术。他带来了一个公鸡，它能驮着放在它背上的重重的木头，就好像那木头轻得像羽毛一样。但是在场的一个女孩曾经找到过四片叶子的三叶草，并变得非常智慧，以至于没有任何骗术能骗到她，而她看出来那根木头只不过是一根稻草。所以她喊道：“朋友们，你们看不到那公鸡驮的是一根稻草，而不是木头？”随即魔法就消失了，人们看到确实是稻草，就把羞愧难当、无地自容的巫师给赶走了。然而，他满带怨恨地说：“我很快会回来报仇的。”
en: There was once an enchanter who was standing in the midst of a great crowd of people performing his wonders.He had a cock brought in, which lifted a heavy beam and carried it as if it were as light as a feather.But a girl was present who had just found a bit of four-leaved clover, and had thus become so wise that no deception could stand out against her, and she saw that the beam was nothing but a straw.So she cried, “You people, do you not see that it is a straw that the cock is carrying, and no beam?”Immediately the enchantment vanished, and the people saw what it was, and drove the magician away in shame and disgrace.He, however, full of inward anger, said, “I will soon revenge myself?”

zh: 过了一段时间后，这个女孩结婚的日子到了，她妆扮一新，在送亲队伍的簇拥下到教堂去。突然她遇到了一条小溪，溪水涨得很高，上面也没有桥或是木板可以过去。这位新娘敏捷地把衣服提起，想要趟水过去。而就当她站在水中的时候，一个人，就是那个巫师，站在她身边很近的地方嘲笑起她来：“哈哈！你哪只眼睛看到那是水了？”然后她的眼睁开了，看到她自己正提着衣服站在一块开满花的暗黑色的亚麻田里。大家也都看清了整个场面，嘲笑着把她赶走了。
en: After some time the girl’s wedding-day came, and she was decked out, and went in a great procession over the fields to the place where the church was.All at once she came to a stream which was very much swollen, and there was no bridge and no plank to cross it.Then the bride nimbly took her clothes up, and wanted to wade through it.And just as she was thus standing in the water, a man, and it was the enchanter, cried mockingly close beside her, “Aha!Where are thine eyes that thou takest that for water?”Then her eyes were opened, and she saw that she was standing with her clothes lifted up in the middle of a field that was blue with the flowers of blue flax.Then all the people saw it likewise, and chased her away with ridicule and laughter.

zh: 麻鸦和戴胜鸟
en: The Bittern and the Hoopoe

zh: 有人问一个放牛的老人：“你最喜欢去哪里放牛？”“这里，先生，草既不太多也不太少的地方，其他的地方都不行。”“为什么呢？”那人问。“你听见那边牧场上悲伤的叫声了么？”牧人回答道，“那是麻鸦在叫，他曾经是一个牧人，戴胜鸟曾经也是——我会告诉你整个故事。麻鸦把他的牛群赶到绿草丰茂、开满鲜花的草地上放牧，他的牛儿们变得野起来，不好管了。而戴胜鸟把他的牛赶到一个草木稀少的高山上，那里有风沙光顾，他的牛儿们开始变瘦，变得没有力气了。到了傍晚，牧人要把他们的牛群赶回家，麻鸦却不能再把他的牛儿们聚拢在一起，它们的精神太足，都跑开了。他喊道：‘回来，牛儿，回来。’但是一点用都没有，它们对他的呼唤一点都不理睬。尽管戴胜鸟的牛儿没有跑掉，但是，他甚至都不能让他的牛儿们站起来，它们是那么地虚弱无力。‘起来，起来，起来 。’他大喊大叫，但是徒劳无功，它们依然趴在沙地上。当一个人做事却不知道适度的时候，就会出现那样的情况。直到今天，尽管他们已经没有牛群需要放牧了，麻鸦还是在喊‘回来，牛儿，回来。’而戴胜鸟也在叫‘起来，起来，起来。’”
en: “Where do you like best to feed your flocks?” said a man to an old cow-herd.“Here, sir, where the grass is neither too rich nor too poor, or else it is no use.”“Why not?” asked the man.“Do you hear that melancholy cry from the meadow there?” answered the shepherd, “that is the bittern; he was once a shepherd, and so was the hoopoe also,—I will tell you the story.The bittern pastured his flocks on rich green meadows where flowers grew in abundance, so his cows became wild and unmanageable.The hoopoe drove his cattle on to high barren hills, where the wind plays with the sand, and his cows became thin, and got no strength.When it was evening, and the shepherds wanted to drive their cows homewards, the bittern could not get his together again; they were too high-spirited, and ran away from him.He called, “Come, cows, come,” but it was of no use; they took no notice of his calling.The hoopoe, however, could not even get his cows up on their legs, so faint and weak had they become.“Up, up, up,” screamed he, but it was in vain, they remained lying on the sand.That is the way when one has no moderation.And to this day, though they have no flocks now to watch, the bittern cries, “Come, cows, come,” and the hoopoe, “Up, up, up.”

zh: 迪特马申的奇事
en: The Ditmarsch Tale of Wonders

zh: 我给大家说说一些事。我曾见过两只烤鸡在天上飞，他们飞得很快，而且肚子朝天、背朝地；一个铁砧和一块磨石在莱茵河上慢条斯理地、无比优雅地漂着；一只青蛙在圣灵降临周那会儿坐在冰上，啃着犁头。我还见过三个想要逮野兔的人拄着拐杖，踩着高跷；他们其中一个耳朵听不见，一个眼睛看不见，另一个嘴巴出不了声，还有一个连路都不能走。你想知道他们是怎么抓到野兔的吗？先是眼睛看不见的人看到兔子在田里跑，接着出不了声的人叫走不了路的人去抓它，最后，走不了路的人提着兔子的脖子，抓住了它。
en: I will tell you something.I saw two roasted fowls flying; they flew quickly and had their breasts turned to heaven and their backs to hell, and an anvil and a mill-stone swam across the Rhine prettily, slowly, and gently, and a frog sat on the ice at Whitsuntide and ate a ploughshare.Three fellows who wanted to catch a hare, went on crutches and stilts; one of them was deaf, the second blind, the third dumb, and the fourth could not stir a step.Do you want to know how it was done?First, the blind man saw the hare running across the field, the dumb one called to the lame one, and the lame one seized it by the neck.

zh: 我还知道，有些人想在旱地上驾船航行，于是他们在风中挂帆起航，驶过广袤的大地。后来他们驾船想要掠过高山，却在那里悲惨地淹死了。我还见过一只螃蟹正追逐着全速奔跑的野兔；高高的屋顶上有一头凭着自己的本事爬上去的母牛。在迪特马申那里，苍蝇像这儿的山羊一样大。打开窗户，或许这些谎话都能飞出去呢。
en: There were certain men who wished to sail on dry land, and they set their sails in the wind, and sailed away over great fields.Then they sailed over a high mountain, and there they were miserably drowned.A crab was chasing a hare which was running away at full speed, and high up on the roof lay a cow which had climbed up there.In that country the flies are as big as the goats are here.Open the window, that the lies may fly out.

zh: 鼓手
en: The Drummer

zh: 一天傍晚，一位年轻的鼓手独自一人到郊外漫步。走到一片湖畔的时候，他看见地上放着三片白色的亚麻布。
en: A young drummer went out alone one evening into the country, and came to a lake on the shore of which he perceived three pieces of white linen lying.

zh: “好漂亮的亚麻布啊！”说着他捡起一片装进了自己的口袋。回到家，他已经忘了这事，就上床睡了。
en: “What fine linen,” said he, and put one piece in his pocket.He returned home, thought no more of what he had found, and went to bed.

zh: 正要入睡时，他感觉似乎有人在喊他的名字。他侧耳倾听，听到一个柔弱的声音在喊他：“鼓手，鼓手，醒醒啊！”可此时漆黑一片，他看不见人，只感觉似乎有个人影在床边晃晃悠悠的。
en: Just as he was going to sleep, it seemed to him as if some one was saying his name.He listened, and was aware of a soft voice which cried to him, “Drummer, drummer, wake up!”As it was a dark night he could see no one, but it appeared to him that a figure was hovering about his bed.

zh: “你要干什么？”他问道。
en: “What do you want?” he asked.

zh: “还我的裙子啊，”那个声音说，“就是你昨天傍晚在湖边捡走的那条。”
en: “Give me back my dress,” answered the voice, “that you took away from me last evening by the lake.”

zh: “我会还给你的，”鼓手说，“不过你得先告诉我你是谁。”
en: “You shall have it back again,” said the drummer, “if you will tell me who you are.”

zh: “哦，”那个声音回答到，“我是一位强大的国王的女儿，却被一个女巫捉走了，关在了玻璃山上。我跟我的两个姐姐每天都要去湖里洗澡，可是没了裙子我就飞不回去了。她们都回去了，我只好留在这儿了。求求你，把我的裙子还给我吧。”
en: “Ah,” answered the voice, “I am the daughter of a mighty King; but I have fallen into the power of a witch, and am shut up on the glass-mountain.I have to bathe in the lake every day with my two sisters, but I cannot fly back again without my dress.My sisters have gone away, but I have been forced to stay behind.I entreat you to give me my dress back.”

zh: “别着急，可怜的孩子。”鼓手道。
en: “Be easy, poor child,” said the drummer.

zh: “我愿意还给你。”
en: “I will willingly give it back to you.”

zh: 他从口袋里掏出裙子，摸黑递给她。她急匆匆地抓过去，想马上飞走。
en: He took it out of his pocket, and reached it to her in the dark.She snatched it in haste, and wanted to go away with it.

zh: “等一等，也许我还能帮你呢！”
en: “Stop a moment, perhaps I can help you.”

zh: “你要帮我，只有爬上玻璃山，把我从巫婆的巫术中解救出来。可是你到不了玻璃山的。就算你到了山脚下，也爬不上去的。”
en: “You can only help me by ascending the glass-mountain, and freeing me from the power of the witch.But you cannot come to the glass-mountain, and indeed if you were quite close to it you could not ascend it.”

zh: “只要我想做的事情，就一定做到，”鼓手说，“我很同情你，而且我无所畏惧。但是我不知道去玻璃山的路。”
en: “When I want to do a thing I always can do it,” said the drummer; “I am sorry for you, and have no fear of anything.But I do not know the way which leads to the glass-mountain.”

zh: “要穿过住着食人巨怪的大森林，”女孩回答说，“其他的我就不敢多说什么了。”
en: “The road goes through the great forest, in which the man-eaters live,” she answered, “and more than that, I dare not tell you.”

zh: 鼓手听到一阵翅膀颤动的声音，之后女孩飞走了。
en: And then he heard her wings quiver, and she flew away.

zh: 于是天刚蒙蒙亮，鼓手就起床了。他系好鼓带，毫无畏惧地走进了大森林。走了一阵子，他没发现什么巨怪，心里想：“看来我得把这些懒家伙叫醒。”于是他把鼓挂在胸前，一阵狂敲，把树上的鸟儿惊得大声鸣叫着飞散开去。没多久，躺在草丛中睡觉的一个巨怪就被惊醒了。他站起来，足有杉树那么高。
en: By daybreak the drummer arose, buckled on his drum, and went without fear straight into the forest.After he had walked for a while without seeing any giants, he thought to himself, “I must waken up the sluggards,” and he hung his drum before him, and beat such a reveille that the birds flew out of the trees with loud cries.It was not long before a giant who had been lying sleeping among the grass, rose up, and was as tall as a fir tree.

zh: “混蛋！”他大叫道，“你干嘛跑这儿来敲鼓？干嘛破坏我的美梦？”
en: “Wretch!” cried he; “what are you drumming here for, and wakening me out of my best sleep?”

zh: 鼓手回答道：“我敲鼓是因为要给后面跟着的几千人带路。”
en: “I am drumming,” he answered, “because I want to show the way to many thousands who are following me.”

zh: “他们来我的森林做什么？”巨怪问。
en: “What do they want in my forest?” demanded the giant.

zh: “他们是来杀你的，要把你这样的怪物清理出森林！”
en: “They want to put an end to you, and cleanse the forest of such a monster as you are!”

zh: “哈哈！”巨怪说，“那我就把你们像踩蚂蚁一样都踩死。”
en: “Oho!” said the giant, “I will trample you all to death like so many ants.”

zh: “你以为你打得过我们吗？”鼓手说，“你弯腰去抓一个人的时候，他会逃走躲起来。但是等你躺下睡觉时，他们又从四周的树丛里钻出来，悄悄围攻你。他们腰带上可都别着铁锤子呢，可以砸破你的头骨！”
en: “Do you think you can do anything against us?” said the drummer; “if you stoop to take hold of one, he will jump away and hide himself; but when you are lying down and sleeping, they will come forth from every thicket, and creep up to you.Every one of them has a hammer of steel in his belt, and with that they will beat in your skull.”

zh: 巨怪很气恼，他暗自想：“要是和这些狡猾的人交手，肯定对我不利。我能勒死狼和熊，但和这些小蚯蚓过招，我还真无法保全自己。”
en: The giant grew angry and thought, “If I meddle with the crafty folk, it might turn out badly for me.I can strangle wolves and bears, but I cannot protect myself from these earthworms.”

zh: “听着，小东西，”他说，“你回去吧！我发誓以后再也不骚扰你和你的同伴了。如果你还有什么要求，尽管说吧，我很愿意为你效劳。”
en: “Listen, little fellow,” said he; “go back again, and I will promise you that for the future I will leave you and your comrades in peace, and if there is anything else you wish for, tell me, for I am quite willing to do something to please you.”

zh: “你腿长，跑起来比我快，”鼓手说，“就带我去玻璃山吧，我就发信号让其他人都撤兵，他们这次就放过你了。”
en: “You have long legs,” said the drummer, “and can run quicker than I; carry me to the glass-mountain, and I will give my followers a signal to go back, and they shall leave you in peace this time.”

zh: “上来吧，你这只小虫子，”巨怪说，“坐我的肩上来，我带你去你想去的地方。”
en: “Come here, worm,” said the giant; “seat yourself on my shoulder, I will carry you where you wish to be.”

zh: 巨怪把他托起来，鼓手开心地敲起鼓来。巨怪心想：“那是在发信号让其他人撤退。”
en: The giant lifted him up, and the drummer began to beat his drum up aloft to his heart’s delight.The giant thought, “That is the signal for the other people to turn back.”

zh: 走了一会，来了第二个巨怪。他站在路中间，接过了鼓手，把他放在自己的扣眼里。鼓手搂住盘子大的扣子，稳稳坐着，开心地四处张望。接着又来了第三个巨怪，把鼓手从扣眼里拈出来，放在自己的帽檐上。鼓手在帽檐上溜达来溜达去，越过树顶观望着远处。他看到蔚蓝的天际浮现出一座山，心里想：“那一定就是玻璃山了。”他猜对了。距离山脚下只差两步远的时候，巨怪把鼓手放了下来。鼓手要他把自己放到山顶上，可是巨怪摇摇头，胡子间发出几声咆哮，然后他转身回森林去了。
en: After a while, a second giant was standing in the road, who took the drummer from the first, and stuck him in his own button-hole.The drummer laid hold of the button, which was as large as a dish, held on by it, and looked merrily around.Then they came to a third giant, who took him out of the button-hole, and set him on the rim of his hat.Then the drummer walked backwards and forwards up above, and looked over the trees, and when he perceived a mountain in the blue distance, he thought, “That must be the glass-mountain,” and so it was.The giant only made two steps more, and they reached the foot of the mountain, when the giant put him down.The drummer demanded to be put on the summit of the glass-mountain, but the giant shook his head, growled something in his beard, and went back into the forest.

zh: 可怜的鼓手此时就站在山脚下。山高得像三座山重叠起来，而且光滑得像镜子一样，鼓手不知道该怎么爬上去。鼓手开始往上爬，可是无济于事，他一次次地滑下来。
en: And now the poor drummer was standing before the mountain, which was as high as if three mountains were piled on each other, and at the same time as smooth as a looking-glass, and did not know how to get up it.He began to climb, but that was useless, for he always slipped back again.

zh: “我要是只鸟就好了！”鼓手想，可希望终归是希望，他并没有长出翅膀来。
en: “If one were a bird now,” thought he; but what was the good of wishing, no wings grew for him.

zh: 正当鼓手站在那儿不知所措的时候，他看见不远处有两个人争执得很厉害。他走过去，发现两人是为面前地上的一副马鞍而争执，他们都想得到它。
en: While he was standing thus, not knowing what to do, he saw, not far from him, two men who were struggling fiercely together.He went up to them and saw that they were disputing about a saddle which was lying on the ground before them, and which both of them wanted to have.

zh: “你们可够傻的，”鼓手说，“你们连马都没有，却为马鞍争来争去的！”
en: “What fools you are,” said he, “to quarrel about a saddle, when you have not a horse for it!”

zh: “这马鞍很值得一争，”其中一个人回答道，“不管谁坐上去，想到哪儿就可以到哪儿。就算要到天涯海角，只要讲出自己的愿望，那也只是一瞬间的事。这副马鞍是我们俩共有的。这次该轮到我坐了，可是他不让。”
en: “The saddle is worth fighting about,” answered one of the men; “whoever sits on it, and wishes himself in any place, even if it should be the very end of the earth, gets there the instant he has uttered the wish.The saddle belongs to us in common.It is my turn to ride on it, but that other man will not let me do it.”

zh: “我马上来给你们裁决一下。”鼓手说着往前迈了几步，在地上插了根白色的木桩子。转身回来，鼓手说：“现在你们都向木桩跑，谁先到谁就可以先坐马鞍。”
en: “I will soon decide the quarrel,” said the drummer, and he went to a short distance and stuck a white rod in the ground.Then he came back and said, “Now run to the goal, and whoever gets there first, shall ride first.”

zh: 两人撒腿就跑，可还没迈出几步远呢，鼓手就跨上马鞍，许愿登上玻璃山顶，在两个人转身之前就到达了。
en: Both put themselves into a trot; but hardly had they gone a couple of steps before the drummer swung himself on the saddle, wished himself on the glass-mountain, and before anyone could turn round, he was there.

zh: 山顶上是一片平地。有座老石头屋子，屋前是一个大鱼池，屋后是一片阴森的森林。他没发现什么人或动物，四周都静悄悄的，只有风吹树叶的沙沙声，低低的白云从头顶掠过。鼓手走上前，敲了敲屋门。敲第三下的时候，门开了，出来一位老太太，她面色黝黑，眼睛通红。老太太高高的鼻梁上还架着副眼镜，用锐利的眼神打量着鼓手，问他来做什么。
en: On the top of the mountain was a plain.There stood an old stone house, and in front of the house lay a great fish-pond, but behind it was a dark forest.He saw neither men nor animals, everything was quiet; only the wind rustled among the trees, and the clouds moved by quite close above his head.He went to the door and knocked.When he had knocked for the third time, an old woman with a brown face and red eyes opened the door.She had spectacles on her long nose, and looked sharply at him; then she asked what he wanted.

zh: “我想进屋去，吃点东西，再在这里歇一晚。”鼓手说。
en: “Entrance, food, and a bed for the night,” answered the drummer.

zh: 老太太回答道：“那你得答应为我做三件事，我就满足你的要求。”
en: “That you shall have,” said the old woman, “if you will perform three services in return.”

zh: “没问题啊，”鼓手说，“我什么都能做，再难都难不倒我！”
en: “Why not?” he answered, “I am not afraid of any kind of work, however hard it may be.”

zh: 于是老太太就让他进屋了，给他吃的，还让他在一张舒适的床上睡了一夜。第二天早上，等鼓手睡醒了，老太太从她皱巴巴的手指上取下一枚顶针，交给他，吩咐道：“快去干活吧，用这枚顶针把外面鱼池里的水舀干，天黑前得干完，还有，把鱼全部捞出来，按大小种类堆放。”
en: The old woman let him go in, and gave him some food and a good bed at night.The next morning when he had had his sleep out, she took a thimble from her wrinkled finger, reached it to the drummer, and said, “Go to work now, and empty out the pond with this thimble; but you must have it done before night, and must have sought out all the fishes which are in the water and laid them side by side, according to their kind and size.”

zh: “好奇怪的活儿！”鼓手自言自语道，但他还是拿着顶针来到鱼池，开始舀池水。他舀了一上午，可是哪怕舀一千年，单凭这枚小小的顶针怎么能够舀干这么大个鱼池里的水呢？
en: “That is strange work,” said the drummer, but he went to the pond, and began to empty it.He bailed the whole morning; but what can anyone do to a great lake with a thimble, even if he were to bail for a thousand years?

zh: 到中午时分了，鼓手心想：“根本就没用，干不干都一样。”
en: When it was noon, he thought, “It is all useless, and whether I work or not it will come to the same thing.”

zh: 于是他就坐下不干了。这时，石屋里走出一个女子，她把一小篮吃的放在他面前，问道：“你怎么了，为什么坐在这儿发愁啊？”他抬头看着她，发现她真是美如天仙。
en: So he gave it up and sat down.Then came a maiden out of the house who set a little basket with food before him, and said, “What ails you, that you sit so sadly here?”He looked at her, and saw that she was wondrously beautiful.

zh: “唉，”他叹着气说，“第一件事就完不成，后面的事该怎么办？我是来寻找住在这儿的一位公主的，可还没看见她，所以我得接着往前走。”
en: “Ah,” said he, “I cannot finish the first piece of work, how will it be with the others?I came forth to seek a king’s daughter who is said to dwell here, but I have not found her, and I will go farther.”

zh: “待在这里吧，”女孩说，“我来帮助你。你累了，就枕在我腿上睡一觉吧。等你醒来的时候，任务就完成了。”
en: “Stay here,” said the maiden, “I will help you out of your difficulty.You are tired, lay your head in my lap, and sleep.When you awake again, your work will be done.”

zh: 鼓手听她这么说，当然求之不得了。他一闭上眼睛，女孩就转动手指上的如意戒，口中念到：“水升起，鱼出去！”
en: The drummer did not need to be told that twice.As soon as his eyes were shut, she turned a wishing-ring and said, “Rise, water.Fishes, come out.”

zh: 眨眼之间，池水像白雾一般升上天空，和其他白云一起飘走了；鱼儿自己跳上岸，按大小和种类排得整整齐齐。
en: Instantly the water rose on high like a white mist, and moved away with the other clouds, and the fishes sprang on the shore and laid themselves side by side each according to his size and kind.

zh: 鼓手一觉醒来，惊讶地看见一切都做完了。不过女孩说：“还有一条鱼没有跟它的同类在一起，而是单独放着。晚上老太太回来看见她要求你做的事都做完了，会问你：‘怎么有一条鱼自个儿待着呢？’你就把这条鱼甩到她脸上，说：‘这条是留给你的，老巫婆。’”晚上巫婆来时，还真这么问了，鼓手就把鱼甩她的脸上。巫婆一副无所谓的样子，什么也没说，只是恶毒地看着他。
en: When the drummer awoke, he saw with amazement that all was done.But the maiden said, “One of the fish is not lying with those of its own kind, but quite alone; when the old woman comes tonight and sees that all she demanded has been done, she will ask you, ‘What is this fish lying alone for?’Then throw the fish in her face, and say, ‘This one shall be for you, old witch.’” In the evening the witch came, and when she had put this question, he threw the fish in her face.She behaved as if she did not remark it, and said nothing, but looked at him with malicious eyes.

zh: 第二天一早，巫婆又吩咐了：“昨天的事对你来说太容易了，我必须吩咐你做一件比较难的事。今天你得去把这整个森林的树都砍倒，劈成木柴，堆成垛，傍晚前做完。”
en: Next morning she said, “Yesterday it was too easy for you, I must give you harder work.Today you must hew down the whole of the forest, split the wood into logs, and pile them up, and everything must be finished by the evening.”

zh: 她交给他一把斧头，一把大头锤和两个楔子。但是斧头是铅做的，大头锤和楔子是锡制的。等他拿到林子里一用，斧头的刃就卷边了，锤子和楔子也变形了。
en: She gave him an axe, a mallet, and two wedges.But the axe was made of lead, and the mallet and wedges were of tin.When he began to cut, the edge of the axe turned back, and the mallet and wedges were beaten out of shape.

zh: 鼓手又不知道该怎么办，但是中午的时候，那个女孩又来了，给他带了午餐，还安慰他。
en: He did not know how to manage, but at mid-day the maiden came once more with his dinner and comforted him.

zh: “枕在我腿上睡一觉，”她说，“等你醒来的时候，你的任务就完成了。”
en: “Lay your head on my lap,” said she, “and sleep; when you awake, your work will be done.”

zh: 女孩转动如意戒，一刹那间整座森林都砍倒了，圆木被劈成木柴，整整齐齐地堆放着，就像是由看不见的巨人完成的。等鼓手睡醒，女孩嘱咐道：“你看，木柴都按要求堆好了，只有一根没放好。晚上老巫婆回来问起，你就用这根抽她一下，说：‘这根是留给你的，老巫婆。’”
en: She turned her wishing-ring, and in an instant the whole forest fell down with a crash, the wood split, and arranged itself in heaps, and it seemed just as if unseen giants were finishing the work.When he awoke, the maiden said, “Do you see that the wood is piled up and arranged, one bough alone remains; but when the old woman comes this evening and asks you about that bough, give her a blow with it, and say, ‘That is for you, you witch.’”

zh: 晚上老巫婆回来了，说：“看！这工作多轻松啊！但那根木柴放在那儿是留给谁的？”
en: The old woman came, “There!You see how easy the work was!” said she; “but for whom have you left that bough which is lying there still?”

zh: “给你留的，老巫婆！”鼓手回答道，抽了老巫婆一下。但是老巫婆还是假装无所谓的样子，阴笑着说：“明天一早你把木头堆成一垛，全部烧了！”
en: “For you, you witch,” he answered, and gave her a blow with it.But she pretended not to feel it, laughed scornfully, and said, “Early tomorrow morning you shall arrange all the wood in one heap, set fire to it, and burn it.”

zh: 第二天天刚亮，鼓手就起床开始搬木头了，可是他一个人怎么能搬完整个森林的木头呢？怎么搬都无济于事。不过，那个女孩并没有在他需要的时候抛弃他。中午她给他送饭过来。他吃完饭，就枕在女孩的腿上睡着了。鼓手醒来的时候，看见山一样高的木头垛子正燃起大火，熊熊火焰向天空伸去。
en: He rose at break of day, and began to pick up the wood, but how can a single man get a whole forest together?The work made no progress.The maiden, however, did not desert him in his need.She brought him his food at noon, and when he had eaten, he laid his head on her lap, and went to sleep.When he awoke, the entire pile of wood was burning in one enormous flame, which stretched its tongues out into the sky.

zh: “听着，”女孩说，“老巫婆来的时候，还会要你做很多事；无论她吩咐什么，你都要毫无畏惧地去做，这样她也拿你没办法。不过要是你退缩了，这场大火就会烧到你身上，把你烧死。等你什么都做完了，就用双手抓住她，把她推到火里。”
en: “Listen to me,” said the maiden, “when the witch comes, she will give you all kinds of orders; do whatever she asks you without fear, and then she will not be able to get the better of you, but if you are afraid, the fire will lay hold of you, and consume you.At last when you have done everything, seize her with both your hands, and throw her into the midst of the fire.”

zh: 女孩离开了，老巫婆不知什么时候偷偷跑了过来。
en: The maiden departed, and the old woman came sneaking up to him.

zh: “噢，我好冷！”她说，“但这里有堆火，刚好暖暖我的老骨头，舒服啊！但怎么还有根木头没烧着，把它拿给我。做完这件事，你就自由了，想去哪儿去哪儿。快行行好钻进去帮我拿吧。”
en: “Oh, I am cold,” said she, “but that is a fire that burns; it warms my old bones for me, and does me good!But there is a log lying there which won’t burn, bring it out for me.When you have done that, you are free, and may go where you like; come, go in with a good will.”

zh: 鼓手毫不犹豫地跳进了火堆。但大火却没烧到他，就连一根头发都没烧着。他把那根木头拽出来，放在地上。然而，木头一放到地上就变了，变成了那位总在他遇到困境时帮助他的女子，她站在鼓手面前，身上穿着闪着金光的丝绸裙子，鼓手知道她正是公主。但老巫婆却恶毒地笑了笑，说：“你别以为你这就得到她了，想得美！”说着她向公主扑去，要把她带走，小伙子双手抓住老巫婆，把她高高举起，一下扔进火堆，火舌一下子就吞没了老巫婆，好像也迫不及待地要烧死她似的。
en: The drummer did not reflect long; he sprang into the midst of the flames, but they did not hurt him, and could not even singe a hair of his head.He carried the log out, and laid it down.Hardly, however, had the wood touched the earth than it was transformed, and the beautiful maiden who had helped him in his need stood before him, and by the silken and shining golden garments which she wore, he knew right well that she was the king’s daughter.But the old woman laughed venomously, and said, “You think you have her safe, but you have not got her yet!”Just as she was about to fall on the maiden and take her away, the youth seized the old woman with both his hands, raised her up on high, and threw her into the jaws of the fire, which closed over her as if it were delighted that the old witch was to be burnt.

zh: 这时，公主才仔细打量着鼓手，发现他是个英俊的小伙子，又念及他不顾生命危险解救她，于是她把手放到他的掌心，说：“你为我甘冒一切危险，但我也愿意为你付出一切。请承诺对我忠贞不渝吧，那么你就是我的丈夫了。我们以后会非常富有，老巫婆搜刮的财宝已经够我俩用的了。”
en: Then the king’s daughter looked at the drummer, and when she saw that he was a handsome youth and remembered how he had risked his life to deliver her, she gave him her hand, and said, “You have ventured everything for my sake, but I also will do everything for your.Promise to be true to me, and you shall be my husband.We shall not want for riches, we shall have enough with what the witch has gathered together here.”

zh: 公主把鼓手带进石屋，那里到处都是老巫婆敛来的钱柜宝箱。公主没有拿那些金银，只带了些宝石。公主不想继续留在玻璃山上了，于是鼓手对她说：“靠着我坐到马鞍上来，我们就可以像小鸟一样飞下山了。”
en: She led him into the house, where there were chests and coffers crammed with the old woman’s treasures.The maiden left the gold and silver where it was, and took only the precious stones.She would not stay any longer on the glass-mountain, so the drummer said to her, “Seat yourself by me on my saddle, and then we will fly down like birds.”

zh: “我不想坐这个破旧的马鞍，”公主说，“我只需转动一下如意戒，我们就回家了。”
en: “I do not like the old saddle,” said she, “I need only turn my wishing-ring and we shall be at home.”

zh: “好啊！”鼓手答道，“那我们先到城门口吧。”
en: “Very well, then,” answered the drummer, “then wish us in front of the town-gate.”

zh: 一转眼，他们就到了城门口。但这时鼓手对公主说：“我想去见见父母，告诉他们这个消息，就在这儿等着我吧，我很快就回来。”
en: In the twinkling of an eye they were there, but the drummer said, “I will just go to my parents and tell them the news, wait for me outside here, I shall soon be back.”

zh: “哎，”公主说，“求你要小心啊。到家后别吻你父母的右脸颊，要不然你就会忘记一切，把我孤零零一个人扔在这儿的。”
en: “Ah,” said the king’s daughter, “I beg you to be careful.On your arrival do not kiss your parents on the right cheek, or else you will forget everything, and I shall stay behind here outside, alone and deserted.”

zh: “我怎么会忘记你呢?”鼓手承诺见完父母马上就回来，并举手起誓。
en: “How can I forget you?” said he, and promised her to come back very soon, and gave his hand on it.

zh: 可等鼓手回到家里，由于他变化太大了，谁都不认识他了，因为他在玻璃山上过的三天相当于凡间的三年。终于认出他后，他的父母高兴地搂着儿子的脖子，他也特别感动，忘记了公主的嘱咐，亲了父母的左右脸颊。但当他一吻到父母的右脸颊，就再也记不得公主这个人了。鼓手把口袋都掏空了，把大颗大颗的宝石堆在桌上。他的父母看着这么多财宝，简直手足无措了。后来，他父亲用这笔钱建了一座华丽无比的城堡，四周都是花园、树林和草坪，简直像给王子建的。庭院建好后，母亲对他说：“我已经帮你选好了一位女孩做妻子，三天之后就举行婚礼吧。”
en: When he went into his father’s house, he had changed so much that no one knew who he was, for the three days which he had passed on the glass-mountain had been three years.Then he made himself known, and his parents fell on his neck with joy, and his heart was so moved that he forgot what the maiden had said, and kissed them on both cheeks.But when he had given them the kiss on the right cheek, every thought of the king’s daughter vanished from him.He emptied out his pockets, and laid handfuls of the largest jewels on the table.The parents had not the least idea what to do with the riches.Then the father built a magnificent castle all surrounded by gardens, woods, and meadows as if a Prince were going to live in it, and when it was ready, the mother said, “I have found a maiden for you, and the wedding shall be in three days.”

zh: 儿子同意了父母的安排。
en: The son was content to do as his parents desired.

zh: 在城门外，可怜的公主还在久久地等候小伙子回来。一直等到天黑了，她想：“他一定是亲了父母的右脸颊，忘记我了。”
en: The poor King’s daughter had stood for a long time without the town waiting for the return of the young man.When evening came, she said, “He must certainly have kissed his parents on the right cheek, and has forgotten me.”

zh: 公主心里十分悲伤，她许愿让自己隐居到一座寂寞的森林小屋里，不愿再回父亲的宫殿了。不过，每天傍晚，她都会去城里，特意走过鼓手的家门。鼓手经常看见这个女子，却再也不记得她了。终于有一天，公主听到人们说：“鼓手明天就要成婚了。”
en: Her heart was full of sorrow, she wished herself into a solitary little hut in a forest, and would not return to her father’s court.Every evening she went into the town and passed the young man’s house; he often saw her, but he no longer knew her.At length she heard the people saying, “The wedding will take place tomorrow.”

zh: 公主对自己说：“我要再努力一次，挽回鼓手的心。”
en: Then she said, “I will try if I can win his heart back.”

zh: 在鼓手婚礼的第一天，公主转动如意戒，念道：“请许我一条如阳光般绚烂的裙子吧！”
en: On the first day of the wedding ceremonies, she turned her wishing-ring, and said, “A dress as bright as the sun.”

zh: 转眼间，一条裙子出现在她面前，绚烂无比，仿佛真是用阳光织就的。 当所有的宾客都到齐了，她才进入大厅。每个人看见这条炫丽的裙子，都无比惊叹。尤其是新娘子，因为美丽的衣裙是她的最爱，于是她走到公主面前，问她是否可以卖给她。
en: Instantly the dress lay before her, and it was as bright as if it had been woven of real sunbeams.When all the guests were assembled, she entered the hall.Every one was amazed at the beautiful dress, and the bride most of all, and as pretty dresses were the things she had most delight in, she went to the stranger and asked if she would sell it to her.

zh: “钱可买不到我这条裙子，”公主答道，“不过如果你在新婚头一夜，能让我守在新郎卧室外的话，我就把裙子白送给你。”
en: “Not for money,” she answered, “but if I may pass the first night outside the door of the room where your betrothed sleeps, I will give it up to you.”

zh: 新娘禁不住诱惑，就同意了，不过她在新郎晚上喝的酒里放了安眠药，新郎喝下去就陷入沉睡了。夜深人静的时候，公主悄悄来到鼓手的卧室外，将门推开一道缝，朝里面喊道：
en: The bride could not overcome her desire and consented, but she mixed a sleeping-draught with the wine her betrothed took at night, which made him fall into a deep sleep.When all had become quiet, the king’s daughter crouched down by the door of the bedroom, opened it just a little, and cried,

zh: “鼓手啊，鼓手，你可听见？
en: “Drummer, drummer, I pray you hear!

zh: 难道已经忘记我们相亲又相爱？
en: Have you forgotten you held me dear?

zh: 玻璃山上的日日夜夜我们相依又相伴，
en: That on the glass-mountain we sat hour by hour?

zh: 我也曾救你于巫婆的万般魔法，
en: That I rescued your life from the witch’s power?

zh: 难道你忘了你曾对我许下的衷心誓言？
en: Did you not plight your troth to me?

zh: 鼓手啊，鼓手，请倾听我的真心呼唤！”
en: Drummer, drummer, harken to me!”

zh: 可一切都是白费。鼓手没有醒，第二天黎明，公主不得不失望地离开。
en: But it was all in vain, the drummer did not awake, and when morning dawned, the king’s daughter was forced to go back again as she came.

zh: 第二天傍晚，公主又转动如意戒，念道：“请许我一条如月光般银光闪闪的裙子吧！”
en: On the second evening she turned her wishing-ring and said, “A dress as silvery as the moon.”

zh: 当她身着这如月光般柔美的裙子出现在宴席上时，新娘又忍不住诱惑了。公主又把裙子送给她，这样公主又可以在新郎卧室外守一晚。
en: When she appeared at the feast in the dress which was as soft as moonbeams, it again excited the desire of the bride, and the king’s daughter gave it to her for permission to pass the second night also, outside the door of the bedroom.

zh: 夜深人静的时候，她又在门外喊道：
en: Then in the stillness of the night, she cried,

zh: “鼓手啊，鼓手，你可听见？
en: “Drummer, drummer, I pray you hear!

zh: 难道已经忘记我们相亲又相爱？
en: Have you forgotten you held me dear?

zh: 玻璃山上的日日夜夜我们相依又相伴，
en: That on the glass-mountain we sat hour by hour?

zh: 我也曾救你于巫婆的万般魔法，
en: That I rescued your life from the witch’s power?

zh: 难道你就忘了你曾对我许下的衷心誓言？
en: Did you not plight your troth to me?

zh: 鼓手啊， 鼓手，请倾听我的真心呼唤！”
en: Drummer, drummer, harken to me!”

zh: 但是鼓手还是被安眠药麻醉得沉沉睡去，未能被唤醒。天一亮，她只能悲伤地回到林中的小木屋里。但是，幸好新郎的家人都听到了这位陌生女子在夜晚的悲叹，他们把那些话告诉了新郎。他们还提醒他，他之所以听不见，是因为新娘在酒里放了安眠药。
en: But the drummer, who was stupefied with the sleeping-draught, could not be aroused.Sadly next morning she went back to her hut in the forest.But the people in the house had heard the lamentation of the stranger-maiden, and told the bridegroom about it.They told him also that it was impossible that he could hear anything of it, because the maiden he was going to marry had poured a sleeping-draught into his wine.

zh: 第三个黄昏，公主又转动如意戒，念道：“请许我一条如星光般闪耀的裙子吧。”
en: On the third evening, the king’s daughter turned her wishing-ring, and said, “A dress glittering like the stars.”

zh: 当公主身着这条裙子出现在宴席上，新娘被这条惊艳无比的裙子深深迷住了，她对公主说：“我一定要，而且一定会拥有它！”
en: When she showed herself therein at the feast, the bride was quite beside herself with the splendor of the dress, which far surpassed the others, and she said, “I must, and will have it.”

zh: 于是，公主又如愿以偿地换来了第三个可以守在新郎卧室外的夜晚。然而，这一夜，新郎没有喝下新娘放过药的酒，而是悄悄把酒倒在了床后，夜深人静之时，他终于听见了一个女子用甜美的声音对他呼唤：
en: The maiden gave it as she had given the others for permission to spend the night outside the bridegroom’s door.The bridegroom, however, did not drink the wine which was handed to him before he went to bed, but poured it behind the bed, and when everything was quiet, he heard a sweet voice which called to him,

zh: “鼓手啊，鼓手，你可听见？
en: “Drummer, drummer, I pray you hear!

zh: 难道你已忘记我们相亲又相爱？
en: Have you forgotten you held me dear?

zh: 在玻璃山上的日日夜夜我们相依又相伴，
en: That on the glass-mountain we sat hour by hour?

zh: 我也曾救你于巫婆的万般魔法，
en: That I rescued your life from the witch’s power?

zh: 难道你就忘了你对我许下的衷心誓言？
en: Did you not plight your troth to me?

zh: 鼓手啊，鼓手，请倾听我的真心呼唤！”
en: Drummer, drummer, harken to me!”

zh: 一刹那间，鼓手什么都想起来了！
en: Suddenly, his memory returned to him.

zh: “天哪！”他大叫道，“我怎么能做出如此不忠的事情啊？但都怪我当时太激动，吻了父母的右脸颊，我才变得如此糊涂啊！”鼓手一跃而起，握住公主的手，把她带到父母面前。
en: “Ah,” cried he, “how can I have acted so unfaithfully; but the kiss which in the joy of my heart I gave my parents, on the right cheek, that is to blame for it all, that is what stupefied me!”He sprang up, took the king’s daughter by the hand, and led her to his parents’ bed.

zh: “这才是我的新娘，”他说道，“如果我娶了别人，我就大错特错了！”他的父母听他讲了事情的前因后果之后，也赞成了儿子的做法。大厅里再次灯火通明，鼓号手也请来了，亲戚朋友们再次应邀前来，在一片欢乐隆重的气氛中，举行了真正的婚礼。而第一位新娘因为得到了三条漂亮的裙子作为补偿，也表示自己很满意。
en: “This is my true bride,” said he; “if I marry the other, I shall do a great wrong.The parents, when they heard how everything had happened, gave their consent.Then the lights in the hall were lighted again, drums and trumpets were brought, friends and relations were invited to come, and the real wedding was solemnized with great rejoicing.The first bride received the beautiful dresses as a compensation, and declared herself satisfied.

zh: 麦穗
en: The Ear of Corn

zh: 很久很久以前，上帝还会亲自到人间走走，那时候土地的收成比现在要好得多，一根麦穗上可不是只结五六十粒麦粒，而是有四五百倍那么多。那时的麦穗从麦秆底部一直长到顶端，麦秆有多高，麦穗就长多高。但是人们生来就是如此，生活富裕了就不再珍惜上帝的恩赐，而是变得满不在乎并且马虎草率起来。一天，一个妇女带着她的孩子走过一片麦田，孩子在她身边跑来跑去，掉进了水坑，把她的连衣裙都弄脏了。这位母亲马上扯下一把漂亮的麦穗来擦她的裙子。
en: In former times, when God himself still walked the earth, the fruitfulness of the soil was much greater than it is now; then the ears of corn did not bear fifty or sixty, but four or five hundred-fold.Then the corn grew from the bottom to the very top of the stalk, and according to the length of the stalk was the length of the ear.Men however are so made, that when they are too well off they no longer value the blessings which come from God, but grow indifferent and careless.One day a woman was passing by a corn-field when her little child, who was running beside her, fell into a puddle, and dirtied her frock.On this the mother tore up a handful of the beautiful ears of corn, and cleaned the frock with them.

zh: 这时候，上帝恰好路过，看到了这一切，他非常生气，说道：“从今以后麦秆上再也不会长穗了，人类再也不配得到神的恩赐。”旁观的人听到这些话后都吓坏了，连忙跪下来祈求上帝说，即使他们自己不配享有这份恩赐，但为了那些无辜的小鸟，也请上帝把麦穗留在麦秆上，否则小鸟们会饿死的。上帝预知到小鸟的苦难，觉得它们很可怜，便答应了人们的请求。因此，麦穗就变成现在这样了。
en: When the Lord, who just then came by, saw that, he was angry, and said, “Henceforth shall the stalks of corn bear no more ears; men are no longer worthy of heavenly gifts.”The by-standers who heard this, were terrified, and fell on their knees and prayed that he would still leave something on the stalks, even if the people were undeserving of it, for the sake of the innocent birds which would otherwise have to starve.The Lord, who foresaw their suffering, had pity on them, and granted the request.So the ears were left as they now grow.

zh: 本领非凡的四兄弟
en: The Four Skilful Brothers

zh: 从前，有个穷人，养育了四个儿子。儿子长大成人后，他对他们说：“亲爱的儿子们，你们得去外面闯闯事业了。我很穷，给不了你们什么。所以你们就出发吧，到外面去学点本领吧，瞧瞧你们各自能有多大的出息。”于是，四兄弟就各自拿上手杖，与父亲道别，然后一起出了城门。同行了一段路，他们走到一个岔路口，岔路口延伸向四个不同的方向。老大说：“咱们就在这儿道别吧！四年后的今天，我们就在这儿见面，现在我们就各自去闯荡吧。”
en: There was once a poor man who had four sons, and when they were grown up, he said to them, “My dear children, you must now go out into the world, for I have nothing to give you, so set out, and go to some distance and learn a trade, and see how you can make your way.”So the four brothers took their sticks, bade their father farewell, and went through the town-gate together.When they had travelled about for some time, they came to a cross-way which branched off in four different directions.Then said the eldest, “Here we must separate, but on this day four years, we will meet each other again at this spot, and in the meantime we will seek our fortunes.”

zh: 于是四兄弟就各奔前程。老大在路上遇到一个人，那个人问他去向何方，要干什么。“我想学个本事。”老大回答道。那个人便说：“随我来吧，去当小偷。”“不行，”老大说，“那才不是正道呢，最终小偷都要被绞死的。”“呵呵，”那个人说，“别担心什么绞刑，我教你偷的东西别人根本拿不到手，而且永远不会有人逮到你。”老大被说动了心，跟着那个人学习技术，最后成了一名技术精湛的小偷，身手灵活到只有他想不到的，没有偷不到的。老二也遇到一个人同样问他要学什么。“我还不知道呢。”他回答道。“跟我走吧，去学天文学，那可是再好不过的本领，学了就无所不知了。”老二欣然同意，最终成为了一名优秀的天文学家，学成准备离开的时候，师傅送给他一副望远镜，嘱咐道：“它可以帮你看到天上地上所有的事情，什么都逃不过你的眼睛。”老三拜了一位猎人为师，猎人对他悉心指导，把自己的打猎本领全部传授给了他，老三最终成了一名经验丰富的猎人。老三学成离开的时候，师傅送他一只猎枪，嘱咐说：“这是只神枪！你想打什么都打得中。”老四也在路上遇到一个人问他要去做什么。“想不想做个裁缝？”那人问。“不喜欢，”老四回答道，“一天到晚得弯腰驼背地坐着，没完没了地缝缝补补，我可不喜欢做裁缝。”“噢，那你就说错啦。”那人说，“我会教你一种非常特别的缝纫技术，那可是一门令人敬重的体面技艺，这种技艺可以说是倍受景仰。”于是老四就答应了，跟那人从头开始学习这门非常特别的裁缝技术。学成离开的时候，师傅送他一根针，嘱咐道：“这根针可以缝合任何东西。不管是蛋壳那样易碎的，还是钢那样坚硬的东西，它都能缝得完完整整、天衣无缝。”
en: Then each of them went his way, and the eldest met a man who asked him where he was going, and what he was intending to do?“I want to learn a trade,” he replied.Then the other said, “Come with me, and be a thief.”“No,” he answered, “that is no longer regarded as a reputable trade, and the end of it is that one has to swing on the gallows.”“Oh,” said the man, “you need not be afraid of the gallows; I will only teach you to get such things as no other man could ever lay hold of, and no one will ever detect you.”So he allowed himself to be talked into it, and while with the man became an accomplished thief, and so dexterous that nothing was safe from him, if he once desired to have it.The second brother met a man who put the same question to him what he wanted to learn in the world.“I don’t know yet,” he replied.“Then come with me, and be an astronomer; there is nothing better than that, for nothing is hid from you.”He liked the idea, and became such a skillful astronomer that when he had learnt everything, and was about to travel onwards, his master gave him a telescope and said to him, “With that you canst thou see whatsoever takes place either on earth or in heaven, and nothing can remain concealed from thee.”A huntsman took the third brother into training, and gave him such excellent instruction in everything which related to huntsmanship, that he became an experienced hunter.When he went away, his master gave him a gun and said, “It will never fail you; whatsoever you aim at, you are certain to hit.”The youngest brother also met a man who spoke to him, and inquired what his intentions were.“Would you not like to be a tailor?” said he.“Not that I know of,” said the youth; “sitting doubled up from morning till night, driving the needle and the goose backwards and forwards, is not to my taste.”“Oh, but you are speaking in ignorance,” answered the man; “with me you would learn a very different kind of tailoring, which is respectable and proper, and for the most part very honorable.”So he let himself be persuaded, and went with the man, and learnt his art from the very beginning.When they parted, the man gave the youth a needle, and said, “With this you can sew together whatever is given you, whether it is as soft as an egg or as hard as steel; and it will all become one piece of stuff, so that no seam will be visible.”

zh: 转眼到了四年后约定见面的那一天，四兄弟同时赶到了那个岔路口，他们彼此亲吻拥抱，一起回家看望父亲。父亲开心地说：“啊，现在你们终于回家啦。”他们把这四年的经历一一告诉了父亲，个个都学成出师了。此刻大家围坐在房前的一棵大树下，父亲对儿子们说：“我来考考你们，看你们本事如何！”他抬头看看大树，对老二说：“在树顶的两段树枝间，有个苍头燕雀的窝，告诉我里面有多少鸟蛋。”天文学家拿起望远镜，看了看，说：“有五只蛋。”父亲转头又对大儿子说：“你去把蛋取下来，别惊动了那只孵蛋的鸟。”神偷爬上树，把五只蛋从那只鸟身下取了出来，它根本没有察觉，还安静地坐着孵蛋呢。神偷把蛋拿给父亲。父亲把其中四只蛋分别放在桌子的一角，另一只蛋置于桌子中心，对当猎人的三儿子说：“现在，你只射一枪，要让子弹从五只蛋中心穿过。”猎人瞄准，开枪射击，正如父亲要求的那样，一枪就射中了五个蛋。他一定是拥有一些用于回旋射击的子弹。“现在轮到你了，”父亲对老四说，“你把蛋重新缝起来，里面的雏鸟也得缝好，要让它完好无损，就像没射穿过一样。”裁缝拿出他的神针，照父亲的吩咐缝起来。完成之后，大儿子爬上树，又把蛋放回了鸟窝，放到那只鸟身下，它依然没有察觉。雌鸟整天孵蛋，几天后，五只雏鸟钻出蛋壳，在每只鸟的脖子上，裁缝曾经缝合的地方还留有条红线。
en: When the appointed four years were over, the four brothers arrived at the same time at the cross-roads, embraced and kissed each other, and returned home to their father.“So now,” said he, quite delighted, “the wind has blown you back again to me.”They told him of all that had happened to them, and that each had learnt his own trade.Now they were sitting just in front of the house under a large tree, and the father said, “I will put you all to the test, and see what you can do.”Then he looked up and said to his second son, “Between two branches up at the top of this tree, there is a chaffinch’s nest, tell me how many eggs there are in it.”The astronomer took his glass, looked up, and said, “There are five.”Then the father said to the eldest, “Fetch the eggs down without disturbing the bird which is sitting hatching them.”The skillful thief climbed up, and took the five eggs from beneath the bird, which never observed what he was doing, and remained quietly sitting where she was, and brought them down to his father.The father took them, and put one of them on each corner of the table, and the fifth in the middle, and said to the huntsman, “With one shot thou shalt shoot me the five eggs in two, through the middle.”The huntsman aimed, and shot the eggs, all five as the father had desired, and that at one shot.He certainly must have had some of the powder for shooting round corners.“Now it’s your turn,” said the father to the fourth son; “you shall sew the eggs together again, and the young birds that are inside them as well, and you must do it so that they are not hurt by the shot.”The tailor brought his needle, and sewed them as his father wished.When he had done this the thief had to climb up the tree again, and carry them to the nest, and put them back again under the bird without her being aware of it.The bird sat her full time, and after a few days the young ones crept out, and they had a red line round their necks where they had been sewn together by the tailor.

zh: “棒极了，”老人对儿子们说，“个个都成了神手啊！你们这几年的时间没有白费，学到了非凡的好本领。我说不出你们之中谁最值得表扬。如果早点有机会让你们一展身手，这就可以证明了。”不久，国家出了件大事，国王的女儿被一头龙给叼走了。国王日夜焦虑，通告全国：救回公主的人，就可以娶公主为妻。四兄弟商量道：“这可是咱们一展身手的好机会啊！”他们相约一同上路去拯救公主。“我很快就可以知道她哪里！”天文学家拿出望远镜，看了看，说，“看见了，她在海中间的一块大石上，那条恶龙就在一边守着呢。”之后，天文学家去面见国王，并向国王要了一艘船。四兄弟驾着船，穿越大海，最后到了那块岩石边。公主就坐在那儿呢，恶龙躺在她腿上正睡着。猎人说：“我不敢开枪，怕误伤了美丽的公主。”“那么让我来试试。”神偷应声道。他爬上大石，把公主从恶龙身下偷出来，他的动作是那么轻快敏捷，恶龙一点都没意识到，还在呼呼大睡呢！他们很兴奋，把公主抱上船，然后驾船驶入大海。但是，那条恶龙醒来后，不见公主，就气呼呼地追赶他们的船。正当恶龙在船上空盘旋，准备俯冲下来的时候，猎人掏出神枪，一枪打中了它的心脏。恶龙当场毙命，掉了下来，但是巨大的身躯把船砸碎了。然而，幸运的是，他们抓住了一些木板，在大海上漂浮着。于是大家又陷入危险处境，可是裁缝可没闲着，他掏出神针，几针就把那几块木板给缝好了，然后他们坐在木板上，继续寻找散落海中的船体碎片。接着，裁缝把碎片一块块缝合起来，很快船就可以正常行驶了，他们安全地回到了王国。
en: “Well,” said the old man to his sons, “I begin to think you are worth more than breen clover; you have used your time well, and learnt something good.I can’t say which of you deserves the most praise.That will be proved if you have but an early opportunity of using your talents.”Not long after this, there was a great uproar in the country, for the King’s daughter was carried off by a dragon.The King was full of trouble about it, both by day and night, and caused it to be proclaimed that whosoever brought her back should have her to wife.The four brothers said to each other, “This would be a fine opportunity for us to show what we can do!” and resolved to go forth together and liberate the King’s daughter.“I will soon know where she is,” said the astronomer, and looked through his telescope and said, “I see her already, she is far away from here on a rock in the sea, and the dragon is beside her watching her.”Then he went to the King, and asked for a ship for himself and his brothers, and sailed with them over the sea until they came to the rock.There the King’s daughter was sitting, and the dragon was lying asleep on her lap.The huntsman said, “I dare not fire, I should kill the beautiful maiden at the same time.”“Then I will try my art,” said the thief, and he crept thither and stole her away from under the dragon, so quietly and dexterously, that the monster never remarked it, but went on snoring.Full of joy, they hurried off with her on board ship, and steered out into the open sea; but the dragon, who when he awoke had found no princess there, followed them, and came snorting angrily through the air.Just as he was circling above the ship, and about to descend on it, the huntsman shouldered his gun, and shot him to the heart.The monster fell down dead, but was so large and powerful that his fall shattered the whole ship.Fortunately, however, they laid hold of a couple of planks, and swam about the wide sea.Then again they were in great peril, but the tailor, who was not idle, took his wondrous needle, and with a few stitches sewed the planks together, and they seated themselves upon them, and collected together all the fragments of the vessel.Then he sewed these so skilfully together, that in a very short time the ship was once more seaworthy, and they could go home again in safety.

zh: 国王和女儿重逢，十分高兴。他对四兄弟说：“你们之中有一位可以娶到公主，但究竟是谁，这要你们自己决定了。”四兄弟各执一词，激烈地争论起来。天文学家说：“如果不是我先发现公主的位置，你们那些本领也用不上。所以，公主应该属于我。”神偷说：“光发现公主有什么用？还不是我把公主从恶龙身下偷出来的？她应该属于我！”猎人也说：“要不是我一枪打死了恶龙，你们所有的人，包括公主，不早就被恶龙撕成碎片了吗？公主应该属于我！”裁缝说：“要不是我用我的技术把船缝好，你们早就悲惨地葬身海底了，公主应该属于我才对！”最后国王发话了：“你们的功劳一样大，可是你们四个人不能都娶到公主，所以，她谁也不能嫁，但是作为报答，我决定把王国的一半送给你们，作为奖赏。”听到这个决定，四兄弟都很开心，说：“这样好！免得我们兄弟相争，伤了和气。”后来他们得到了半个王国，和父亲一起过着幸福的生活，直到升上天堂。
en: When the King once more saw his daughter, there were great rejoicings.He said to the four brothers, “One of you shall have her to wife, but which of you it is to be you must settle among yourselves.”Then a warm contest arose among them, for each of them preferred his own claim.The astronomer said, “If I had not seen the princess, all your arts would have been useless, so she is mine.”The thief said, “What would have been the use of your seeing, if I had not got her away from the dragon?so she is mine.”The huntsman said, “You and the princess, and all of you, would have been torn to pieces by the dragon if my ball had not hit him, so she is mine.”The tailor said, “And if I, by my art, had not sewn the ship together again, you would all of you have been miserably drowned, so she is mine.”Then the King uttered this saying, “Each of you has an equal right, and as all of you cannot have the maiden, none of you shall have her, but I will give to each of you, as a reward, half a kingdom.”The brothers were pleased with this decision, and said, “It is better thus than that we should be at variance with each other.”Then each of them received half a kingdom, and they lived with their father in the greatest happiness as long as it pleased God.

zh: 狐狸与猫
en: The Fox and the Cat

zh: 猫在森林里碰巧遇见了狐狸，它想：“狐狸既聪明又世故，倍受世人尊敬呢。”于是，猫友善地对狐狸说：“您好，亲爱的狐狸先生，您近来可好？您日子过得如何？您准备怎么熬过荒年呢？”心高气傲的狐狸将猫从头到脚打量了一番，犹豫了很长时间，不知是否要回答。最后，狐狸说：“哼，你这个只会捋胡须的倒霉鬼，看你花里花气的蠢样，像个饿死鬼似的成天追着耗子跑，你想干什么？竟然还敢问我过得如何？你学过什么？会几样本领？”猫谦虚地答道：“我只会一样。”“是什么？”狐狸问。“猎狗追我的时候，我可以跳到树上去保命。”“就这个？”狐狸回答。“我会的本领可有上百样，此外，我还有满满一袋子的计谋。你这可怜虫，跟我来吧，让我教教你怎么甩掉猎狗。”就在这时，猎人带着四只狗走了过来。猫敏捷地跳上了树，坐在了树梢上，藏在茂密的枝叶当中。“快打开您的智慧之袋，狐狸先生，快啊。”猫对着狐狸大喊。可猎犬已经追到了狐狸，并死死地逮住了它。“唉，狐狸先生，”猫叹道，“您纵是有百般本领还是难逃厄运啊！您要是能像我这样窜到树上去，也不会就此丧命啊。”
en: It happened that the cat met the fox in a forest, and as she thought to herself,  “He is clever and full of experience, and much esteemed in the world,” she spoke to him in a friendly way.“Good-day, dear Mr. Fox, how are you? How is all with you?How are you getting through this dear season?”The fox, full of all kinds of arrogance, looked at the cat from head to foot, and for a long time did not know whether he would give any answer or not.At last he said, “Oh, thou wretched beard-cleaner, thou piebald fool, thou hungry mouse-hunter, what canst thou be thinking of?Dost thou venture to ask how I am getting on?What hast thou learnt?How many arts dost thou understand?” “I understand but one,” replied the cat, modestly.“What art is that?” asked the fox.“When the hounds are following me, I can spring into a tree and save myself.”“Is that all?” said the fox.“I am master of a hundred arts, and have into the bargain a sackful of cunning.Thou makest me sorry for thee; come with me, I will teach thee how people get away from the hounds.”Just then came a hunter with four dogs.The cat sprang nimbly up a tree, and sat down on top of it, where the branches and foliage quite concealed her.“Open your sack, Mr. Fox, open your sack,” cried the cat to him, but the dogs had already seized him, and were holding him fast.“Ah, Mr. Fox,” cried the cat.“You with your hundred arts are left in the lurch!Had you been able to climb like me, you would not have lost your life.”

zh: 懒惰的纺纱妇
en: The Lazy Spinner

zh: 从前，在一个村庄里住着一个男人和他的妻子。妻子懒得什么都不想做；无论她的丈夫给她什么纺，她都纺不完，而且她纺了的线也不缠起来，让它全都纠缠成一堆。如果她的丈夫责骂她，她总能找到借口，说：“啊，我都没有卷轴，怎么把线缠起来？你赶快去森林里给我弄一个来呀。”“如果只是这个原因，”男人说，“那么我这就去森林里，弄些木材来做个卷轴。”于是，这个女人害怕如果他有了木材就会给她做个卷轴，那么她就不得不把线缠起来，然后又要开始纺新线。她稍微一动脑筋，就想到了一个好主意，她秘密地跟着她的丈夫去了森林，当他爬上一棵树边选边砍时，她就溜到下面丈夫看不到的灌木丛里，喊道：
en: In a certain village there once lived a man and his wife, and the wife was so idle that she would never work at anything; whatever her husband gave her to spin, she did not get done, and what she did spin she did not wind, but let it all remain entangled in a heap.If the man scolded her, she was always ready with her tongue, and said, “Well, how should I wind it, when I have no reel?Just you go into the forest and get me one.”“If that is all,” said the man, “then I will go into the forest, and get some wood for making reels.”Then the woman was afraid that if he had the wood he would make her a reel of it, and she would have to wind her yarn off, and then begin to spin again.She bethought herself a little, and then a lucky idea occurred to her, and she secretly followed the man into the forest, and when he had climbed into a tree to choose and cut the wood, she crept into the thicket below where he could not see her, and cried,

zh: “砍木材做卷轴的人会死，缠线的人也会亡。”
en: “He who cuts wood for reels shall die, And he who winds, shall perish.”

zh: 丈夫听到后，把斧头放下停了一会儿，开始考虑那是什么意思。“喂，”最后他说，“怎么会那样呢；一定是我耳鸣，我可不能无中生有，自己吓自己。”于是，他再次抓起斧头，开始砍，然后下面又传来叫喊声：
en: The man listened, laid down his axe for a moment, and began to consider what that could mean.“Hollo,” he said at last, “what can that have been; my ears must have been singing, I won’t alarm myself for nothing.”So he again seized the axe, and began to hew, then again there came a cry from below:

zh: “砍木材做卷轴的人会死，缠线的人也会亡。”
en: “He who cuts wood for reels shall die, And he who winds, shall perish.”

zh: 他停下来，觉得既害怕又担忧，然后仔细考虑了一下刚才的情况。但是过了一会儿，他又重新振作了起来，第三次伸出手拿过斧头，开始砍。但是有人第三次大声喊道：
en: He stopped, and felt afraid and alarmed, and pondered over the circumstance.But when a few moments had passed, he took heart again, and a third time he stretched out his hand for the axe, and began to cut.But some one called out a third time, and said loudly,

zh: “砍木材做卷轴的人会死，缠线的人会亡。”
en: “He who cuts wood for reels shall die, And he who winds, shall perish.”

zh: 他听不下去了，再也没有心思干活，于是他很快从树上爬下来，动身回家。女人抄小道拼命地跑，好赶在丈夫前面先到家。就这样，当他进客厅时，她就装出一幅若无其事的样子，好像什么都没有发生过，说：“唔，你带回来一块好木材做卷轴了吗？”“没有，”他说，“我明白了，还是不要缠线的好。”并告诉她在森林里发生的事，从此以后他再也不提让她缠线的事了。然而，过了一段时间，男人又开始抱怨房子里的混乱。“媳妇，”他说，“纺好的线全都在那儿乱缠着，真是太丢人了！”“我来告诉你怎么办。”她说，“因为我们还没有卷轴，你去阁楼上，我站在下面把线扔上去给你，你把它扔下来给我，那样我们就能把线缠成一束了。”“是的，就这么办。”男人说。于是他们就照做了，做完以后，他说：“纺线缠成一团了，现在必须要把它煮开。”女人又感到很苦恼；她肯定地说：“是的，我们明天一大早就把它煮开。”但是她背地里又设计了另一个诡计。
en: That was enough for him, and all inclination had departed from him, so he hastily descended the tree, and set out on his way home.The woman ran as fast as she could by by-ways so as to get home first.So when he entered the parlour, she put on an innocent look as if nothing had happened, and said, “Well, have you brought a nice piece of wood for reels?”“No,” said he, “I see very well that winding won’t do,” and told her what had happened to him in the forest, and from that time forth left her in peace about it.Nevertheless after some time, the man again began to complain of the disorder in the house.“Wife,” said he, “it is really a shame that the spun yarn should lie there all entangled!”“I’ll tell you what,” said she, “as we still don’t come by any reel, go you up into the loft, and I will stand down below, and will throw the yarn up to you, and you will throw it down to me, and so we shall get a skein after all.”“Yes, that will do,” said the man.So they did that, and when it was done, he said, “The yarn is in skeins, now it must be boiled.”The woman was again distressed; She certainly said, “Yes, we will boil it next morning early.” but she was secretly contriving another trick.

zh: 第二天一大早她就起床了，点着火，烧上一壶水，只是不是要煮线而是将一团短麻屑放了进去，把它煮开。然后她去找她的丈夫，她的丈夫还躺在床上，她对他说：“我现在必须出去一趟，你得赶紧起床，照看放在火上煮着的壶里的纱线，你要马上去；留心，因为如果鸡鸣了，你还没去照看纱线，它就会变成短麻屑。”丈夫很乐意，说做就做。他尽快起了床，来到厨房。但是，当他来壶边往里一瞥，却惊恐地发现他只看见一团短麻屑。结果这个可怜的丈夫不敢吭声，认为是他自己疏忽了，责任在他，以后再也不提纺线和缠线了。不过，你自己一定会认为她是一个可恶的女人吧！
en: Early in the morning she got up, lighted a fire, and put the kettle on, only instead of the yarn, she put in a lump of tow, and let it boil.After that she went to the man who was still lying in bed, and said to him, “I must just go out, you must get up and look after the yarn which is in the kettle on the fire, but you must be at hand at once; mind that, for if the cock should happen to crow, and you are not attending to the yarn, it will become tow.”The man was willing and took good care not to loiter.He got up as quickly as he could, and went into the kitchen.But when he reached the kettle and peeped in, he saw, to his horror, nothing but a lump of tow.Then the poor man was as still as a mouse, thinking he had neglected it, and was to blame, and in future said no more about yarn and spinning.But you yourself must own she was an odious woman!

zh: 讨饭的老婆婆
en: The Old Beggar-Woman

zh: 曾经有一个老婆婆，你以前见过老婆婆讨饭么？这个老婆婆就是那样乞讨，而且当她讨到东西的时候会说：“愿上帝恩赐于你。”这个讨饭的老婆婆来到一户人家的门前，在壁炉边上，一个友好而调皮的男孩儿正站在旁边取暖。看到这个可怜的老婆婆站在门前瑟瑟发抖，男孩儿友好地对她说：“来，老妈妈，暖和一下。”她走了进去，但是她站得离壁炉太近了，以至于她那破旧的衣服都开始着了起来，而她却没有察觉。那男孩儿站在那里看着这一切，但是他应该把火扑灭的。他是不是真的应该把火扑灭？而且即使他没有水，他也应该让全身的水从双眼中流出来，那将是两股美丽的水流，他可以借此把火扑灭。
en: There was once an old woman, but thou hast surely seen an old woman go a-begging before now?This woman begged likewise, and when she got anything she said, “May God reward you.”The beggar-woman came to a door, and there by the fire a friendly rogue of a boy was standing warming himself.The boy said kindly to the poor old woman as she was standing shivering thus by the door, “Come, old mother, and warm yourself.”She came in, but stood too near the fire, so that her old rags began to burn, and she was not aware of it.The boy stood and saw that, but he ought to have put the flames out.Is it not true that he ought to have put them out?And if he had not any water, then should he have wept all the water in his body out of his eyes, and that would have supplied two pretty streams with which to extinguish them.

zh: 一群叫花子
en: The Pack of Ragamuffins

zh: 从前，有一只公鸡对一只母鸡说：“这个时候我们的坚果应该熟了，我们一起去山上，赶在松鼠把它们都摘走之前，痛痛快快地吃个饱吧。”“好啊，”母鸡回复道，“来，我们一起去开开心心地玩。”然后，他们就离开家，去了山上。那一天天气晴朗，他们一直呆到了晚上。现在，我不知道是因为他们吃得太多而长胖了，还是因为他们变得骄傲了，他们不愿意走着回家，公鸡不得不用坚果壳造了一辆马车。马车造好以后，小母鸡坐在里面，对公鸡说：“只能是你自己拉车。”“好像我喜欢拉车一样！”公鸡说，“我宁愿走回家，也不愿意自己拉车；不行，我们可没说好。我不介意坐在座位上当车夫，但是让我自己拉车，我不干。”
en: The cock once said to the hen, “It is now the time when our nuts are ripe, so let us go to the hill together and for once eat our fill before the squirrel takes them all away.”“Yes,” replied the hen, “come, we will have some pleasure together.”Then they went away to the hill, and on it was a bright day they stayed till evening.Now I do not know whether it was that they had eaten till they were too fat, or whether they had become proud, but they would not go home on foot, and the cock had to build a little carriage of nut-shells.When it was ready, the little hen seated herself in it and said to the cock, “Thou canst just harness thyself to it.”“I like that!” said the cock, “I would rather go home on foot than let myself be harnessed to it; no, that is not our bargain.I do not mind being coachman and sitting on the box, but drag it myself I will not.”

zh: 他们正这样争吵着的时候，一只鸭子嘎嘎叫着走过来：“你们这两个偷东西的家伙，谁叫你们来我的坚果山上偷坚果呢？唔，我要你们好看！”，她张着嘴向公鸡跑去。但是，公鸡也不是好惹的，他大胆地将鸭子击倒在地，最后用距把她弄伤了。小鸭子向他求饶，并愿意给他们拉车，将功折罪。现在小公鸡自己坐在驭者座上当马车夫，并催促道：“鸭子，跑得越快越好。”因此车跑得飞快。他们走了一段路后遇到了两个脚夫——一个大头针和一个缝衣针。他们大叫道：“停下来！停下来！”并且说天马上就变得漆黑了，他们再也无法继续赶路了，路上非常脏，问他们是否可以上车呆一会儿。他们在城门口裁缝家的小酒馆里喝啤酒，因此耽误了时间。因为它们都很瘦，占不了多大地方，公鸡就让它们两个进去了，但是他必须让大头针和缝衣针承诺不踩他和小母鸡的脚。深夜的时候，他们来到一家客栈，因为他们不喜欢晚上赶路，并且鸭子的脚也快撑不住了，左摇右摆地走了进去。店主一开始不让他们在那过夜，他的房子已经住满了，除此之外，店主觉得他们不是什么重要人物；但是最终他们说了很多好听的话，并告诉他会把小母鸡在路上下的蛋送给他，同时，还会把每天下一个蛋的鸭子也送给他，最后店主同意他们晚上在那过夜。现在他们叫了丰盛的饭菜，大吃大喝，欢闹作乐。一大清早，天刚蒙蒙亮，大家还都在睡觉，公鸡叫醒母鸡，带上鸡蛋，把它啄开，一起吃了，但是他们把蛋壳扔在了壁炉边。然后他们去找缝衣针，缝衣针还在睡觉，他们就抓起针头，把它扎进了店主椅子的坐垫里，并把大头针扎进他的毛巾，最后没什么可做了，他们就穿过荒野跑走了。鸭子喜欢在露天的地方睡觉，因此就呆在院子里，听到他们跑走，沾沾自喜，她发现了一条小溪，就顺着水流游走了，这比拉着车走要快多了。再过了两个小时店主才起床；他洗了个澡，想用毛巾擦干，然后大头针扎到他脸上，两个耳朵之间划了一道血印。过后，他走到厨房，想要把烟袋点着，但是当他走到壁炉前，马上就看到了鸡蛋壳。“今天早上一切都和我作对。”他说，非常生气地坐在他爷爷的椅子上，但是他很快就跳起来，大叫道：“哎呦，好疼啊！”缝衣针比大头针刺得疼多了，而且不是头部。现在，他彻底生气了，怀疑是昨天晚上很晚来投宿的客人搞的鬼，可是当他去找他们的时候，他们已经不见了。然后，他发誓再也不把一些叫花子带到他的房子里了，因为他们大吃大喝，也不付账，还对这些恩情报以恶作剧。
en: As they were thus disputing, a duck quacked to them, “You thieving folks, who bade you go to my nut-hill?Well, you shall suffer for it!” and ran with open beak at the cock.But the cock also was not idle, and fell boldly on the duck, and at last wounded her so with his spurs that she also begged for mercy, and willingly let herself be harnessed to the carriage as a punishment.The little cock now seated himself on the box and was coachman, and thereupon they went off in a gallop, with “Duck, go as fast as thou canst.”When they had driven a part of the way they met two foot-passengers, a pin and a needle.They cried, “Stop!stop!” and said that it would soon be as dark as pitch, and then they could not go a step further, and that it was so dirty on the road, and asked if they could not get into the carriage for a while.They had been at the tailor’s public—house by the gate, and had stayed too long over the beer.As they were thin people, who did not take up much room, the cock let them both get in, but they had to promise him and his little hen not to step on their feet.Late in the evening they came to an inn, and as they did not like to go further by night, and as the duck also was not strong on her feet, and fell from one side to the other, they went in.The host at first made many objections, his house was already full, besides he thought they could not be very distinguished persons; but at last, as they made pleasant speeches, and told him that he should have the egg which the little hen has laid on the way, and should likewise keep the duck, which laid one every day, he at length said that they might stay the night.And now they had themselves well served, and feasted and rioted.Early in the morning, when day was breaking, and every one was asleep, the cock awoke the hen, brought the egg, pecked it open, and they ate it together, but they threw the shell on the hearth.Then they went to the needle which was still asleep, took it by the head and stuck it into the cushion of the landlord’s chair, and put the pin in his towel, and at the last without more ado they flew away over the heath.The duck who liked to sleep in the open air and had stayed in the yard, heard them going away, made herself merry and found a stream, down which she swam, which was a much quicker way of travelling than being harnessed to a carriage.The host did not get out of bed for two hours after this; he washed himself and wanted to dry himself, then the pin went over his face and made a red streak from one ear to the other.After this he went into the kitchen and wanted to light a pipe, but when he came to the hearth the egg-shell darted into his eyes.“This morning everything attacks my head, “ said he, and angrily sat down on his grandfather’s chair, but he quickly started up again and cried, “Woe is me, “ for the needle had pricked him still worse than the pin, and not in the head.Now he was thoroughly angry, and suspected the guests who had come so late the night before, and when he went and looked about for them, they were gone.Then he made a vow to take no more ragamuffins into his house, for they consume much, pay for nothing, and play mischievous tricks into the bargain by way of gratitude.

zh: 天堂的礼遇
en: The Peasant in Heaven

zh: 从前有个虔诚的贫农过世了，他来到了天堂大门前。与此同时，一位非常富有的地主也来到这里，他也想进天堂。圣彼得拿着钥匙来了，打开大门，让富人进去，但是很显然他没有看见农民，就把门关上了。现在农民在门外听见天堂里面大家为富人的到来而欢呼雀跃，他们奏着美妙的音乐，唱着歌。最后一切又变得很安静，圣彼得又来打开天堂之门，让农民进来。农民期待着进去时大家也能弹奏美妙的音乐，为他唱歌，但是一切都还是那么安静，大家都热情接待他，真的，天使也都来看望他，但是没人唱歌。于是农民问圣彼得为什么富人进来时大家为他歌唱而他进来时没人唱歌，他还说对他来说天堂的一切都跟地上一样不公平。然后圣彼得说道：“绝不是那样的，对我们来说，你和其他人一样珍贵，会享受到富人所享受到的一切天堂般的快乐，但是每天都会有像你这样的穷人来到天堂，但是像他那样的富人一百年里最多才来一次！”
en: Once on a time a poor pious peasant died, and arrived before the gate of heaven.At the same time a very rich, rich lord came there who also wanted to get into heaven.Then Saint Peter came with the key, and opened the door, and let the great man in, but apparently did not see the peasant, and shut the door again.And now the peasant outside, heard how the great man was received in heaven with all kinds of rejoicing, and how they were making music, and singing within.At length all became quiet again, and Saint Peter came and opened the gate of heaven, and let the peasant in.The peasant, however, expected that they would make music and sing when he went in also, but all remained quite quiet; he was received with great affection, it is true, and the angels came to meet him, but no one sang.Then the peasant asked Saint Peter how it was that they did not sing for him as they had done when the rich man went in, and said that it seemed to him that there in heaven things were done with just as much partiality as on earth.Then said Saint Peter, “By no means, thou art just as dear to us as any one else, and wilt enjoy every heavenly delight that the rich man enjoys, but poor fellows like thee come to heaven every day, but a rich man like this does not come more than once in a hundred years!”

zh: 蜂王
en: The Queen Bee

zh: 从前，国王的两个儿子出去历险，却过起了狂野、无序的生活，因此他们再也没有回过家。最小的王子叫“笨蛋”，动身找他的哥哥们，但是最后当他找到他们时，他们却嘲笑他，觉得他那么单纯，很难在世界上过活。他们两个比他聪明得多，都快混不下去了，更别提他了。他们三个一起上路，来到了一个蚁冢前。年长的两个想要捣毁它，看看小蚂蚁们在恐惧之中到处乱爬，并把它们的蚁卵带走的情形，但是“笨蛋”却说：“让这些生物平静地生活吧；我不允许你们打扰它们。”然后，他们继续向前走，来到了一个湖边，湖里有很多鸭子在游泳。两个哥哥想要抓一对，烤了吃，但是“笨蛋”不允许，他说：“让这些生物平静地生活吧，我不能忍受你们杀死它们。”后来，他们来到了一个蜂窝前，蜂窝里有很多蜂蜜，多得都从蜂窝顺着树干流出来了。他们两个想在树下生火，闷死那些蜜蜂，好把蜂蜜取走，但是“笨蛋”又阻止了他们，说道：“让这些生物平静生活吧，我不允许你们烧死它们。”最后，三兄弟来到了一个城堡，城堡的马棚里站着很多石头马，却不见有一个人，他们穿过了所有的大厅，走到最里面的那个门前，门上有三把锁。不过，门的中间有一个小窗口，从那儿他们可以看到房间里的情形。在那儿，他们看到一个灰白头发的小矮人坐在桌子前。他们叫他，一次，两次，但是他没有听到，最后他们叫他第三次的时候，他起身，打开锁，走了出来。但是，他什么也没说，只是把他们带到一张摆满了美味佳肴的桌子前，等他们吃饱喝足后，小矮人又给他们每人安排了一间卧室。第二天早上，灰白头发的小矮人来到年纪最长的面前，打手势叫他，并把他带到一个石桌子前，桌子上刻着三个任务，完成这三个任务才能拯救城堡。第一个任务是，在森林里，苔藓下面，放置着公主的一千粒珍珠，他必须把它们拾起来，如果日落之前还有一颗珍珠没找到，那么找珍珠的人就会变成石头。老大就去了，找了一整天，但是日落前他只找到了一百颗，刻在石桌上的话应验了，他变成了石头。第二天，老二承担了这项任务。然而，他的表现比老大强不了多少。他找到了不足两百颗珍珠，也变成了石头。最后轮到“笨蛋”在苔藓中找珍珠了。但是，找齐珍珠太困难了，他的进展非常缓慢，于是他坐在一块石头上哭了起来。就在这时候，他曾经救过的蚁王带了五千只蚂蚁来了。不一会儿，这些小东西就把所有的珍珠都找到了，堆在一起。第二个任务是从湖里取出国王女儿卧室的钥匙。当“笨蛋”来到湖边时，他曾经救过的鸭子朝他游过来，潜到水里，把钥匙从水里取了出来。但是，第三个任务是最困难的：从三个熟睡的公主里挑出年龄最小、最可爱的那个。可是，她们三个人长得一模一样，只能通过她们睡前吃的不同的蜜饯来区分：大公主吃了一点儿糖；二公主吃了一点儿糖浆；小公主吃了一勺蜂蜜。“笨蛋”曾经保护蜂王逃过火灾，所以蜂王飞过来，在三位公主的嘴唇上分别尝了尝，最后它停留在吃了蜂蜜的公主的嘴唇上，于是王子意识到这位就是他要找的公主。然后，魔咒消失了；所有人都醒了，那些变成石头的人也恢复了原来的模样。“笨蛋”娶了那位年龄最小、最可爱的公主，在她父亲死后继成了王位，他的两个哥哥也娶了另外两位公主。
en: Two kings’ sons once went out in search of adventures, and fell into a wild, disorderly way of living, so that they never came home again.The youngest, who was called Simpleton, set out to seek his brothers, but when at length he found them they mocked him for thinking that he with his simplicity could get through the world, when they two could not make their way, and yet were so much cleverer.They all three travelled away together, and came to an ant-hill.The two elder wanted to destroy it, to see the little ants creeping about in their terror, and carrying their eggs away, but Simpleton said, “Leave the creatures in peace; I will not allow you to disturb them.”Then they went onwards and came to a lake, on which a great number of ducks were swimming.The two brothers wanted to catch a couple and roast them, but Simpleton would not permit it, and said, “ Leave the creatures in peace, I will not suffer you to kill them.”At length they came to a bee’s nest, in which there was so much honey that it ran out of the trunk of the tree where it was.The two wanted to make a fire beneath the tree, and suffocate the bees in order to take away the honey, but Simpleton again stopped them and said, “Leave the creatures in peace, I will not allow you to burn them.”At length the three brothers arrived at a castle where stone horses were standing in the stables, and no human being was to be seen, and they went through all the halls until, quite at the end, they came to a door in which were three locks.In the middle of the door, however, there was a little pane, through which they could see into the room.There they saw a little grey man, who was sitting at a table.They called him, once, twice, but he did not hear; at last they called him for the third time, when he got up, opened the locks, and came out.He said nothing, however, but conducted them to a handsomely-spread table, and when they had eaten and drunk, he took each of them to a bedroom.Next morning the little grey man came to the eldest, beckoned to him, and conducted him to a stone table, on which were inscribed three tasks, by the performance of which the castle could be delivered.The first was that in the forest, beneath the moss, lay the princess’s pearls, a thousand in number, which must be picked up, and if by sunset one single pearl was wanting, he who had looked for them would be turned into stone.The eldest went thither, and sought the whole day, but when it came to an end, he had only found one hundred, and what was written on the table came to pass, and he was changed into stone.Next day, the second brother undertook the adventure; it did not, however, fare much better with him than with the eldest; he did not find more than two hundred pearls, and was changed to stone.At last the turn came to Simpleton also, who sought in the moss.It was, however, so hard to find the pearls, and he got on so slowly, that he seated himself on a stone, and wept.And while he was thus sitting, the King of the ants whose life he had once saved, came with five thousand ants, and before long the little creatures had got all the pearls together, and laid them in a heap.The second task, however, was to fetch out of the lake the key of the King’s daughter’s bed-chamber.When Simpleton came to the lake, the ducks which he had saved, swam up to him, dived down, and brought the key out of the water.But the third task was the most difficult; from amongst the three sleeping daughters of the King was the youngest and dearest to be sought out.They, however, resembled each other exactly, and were only to be distinguished by their having eaten different sweetmeats before they fell asleep; the eldest a bit of sugar; the second a little syrup; and the youngest a spoonful of honey.Then the Queen of the bees, which Simpleton had protected from the fire, came and tasted the lips of all three, and at last she remained sitting on the mouth which had eaten honey, and thus the King’s son recognized the right princess.Then the enchantment was at an end; everything was released from sleep, and those who had been turned to stone received once more their natural forms.Simpleton married the youngest and sweetest princess, and after her father’s death became King, and his two brothers received the two other sisters.

zh: 海兔
en: The Sea-Hare

zh: 从前，有一位公主，她在城堡里那高高的城垛下有一个房间，房间共有十二扇窗户，这些窗户尽可能朝向每一个方向。每当公主登上这个房间、环视四周时，她就可以视察她的整个王国。当她从第一个窗户往外看时，她的视觉比其他任何人都要敏锐，从第二个窗户她能看得更清，从第三个就看得更清楚了，就这样以此类推，从第十二个窗户向外望去，她可以看到地上地下的所有东西，没有什么能够逃脱她的眼睛。此外，由于她很高傲且不愿受人支配，只想独自一人统治王国，她宣布，谁要想成为他的丈夫，就得成功地把自己隐藏起来，绝不能让她找到。然而，凡是想要尝试却最终被她找到的人都要被砍头，砍下的头要被钉在一根柱子上。城堡前已经立了九十七根柱子，每根柱子上都有一颗死人头，所以有很长一段时间没人敢来尝试了。公主很高兴，心想：“我活着的时候，就没人管得了我了。”这时有三兄弟来到她面前，宣称他们也想碰碰运气。老大相信只要爬进一个石灰池，他就会很安全，但是公主从第一个窗户就看到他了，差人把他抓了出来，砍了他的头。老二爬进了宫殿的地下室，但是公主也只从第一个窗户就发现了他，他的命运也便成了定局。他的头被钉在了第九十九根柱子上。之后老三来了，他恳求公主给他一天时间考虑，而且如果公主碰巧找到了他的话，希望她能宽恕他两次，但要是他第三次还失败了，他甘愿受死。因为他长得很英俊，又恳求得如此诚恳，公主便说：“好吧，我答应你，但你不会成功的。”
en: There was once upon a time a princess, who, high under the battlements in her castle, had an apartment with twelve windows, which looked out in every possible direction, and when she climbed up to it and looked around her, she could inspect her whole kingdom.When she looked out of the first, her sight was more keen than that of any other human being; from the second she could see still better, from the third more distinctly still, and so it went on, until the twelfth, from which she saw everything above the earth and under the earth, and nothing at all could be kept secret from her.Moreover, as she was haughty, and would be subject to no one, but wished to keep the dominion for herself alone, she caused it to be proclaimed that no one should ever be her husband who could not conceal himself from her so effectually, that it should be quite impossible for her to find him.He who tried this, however, and was discovered by her, was to have his head struck off, and stuck on a post.Ninety-seven posts with the heads of dead men were already standing before the castle, and no one had come forward for a long time.The princess was delighted, and thought to herself, “Now I shall be free as long as I live.”Then three brothers appeared before her, and announced to her that they were desirous of trying their luck.The eldest believed he would be quite safe if he crept into a lime-pit, but she saw him from the first window, made him come out, and had his head cut off.The second crept into the cellar of the palace, but she perceived him also from the first window, and his fate was sealed.His head was placed on the nine and ninetieth post.Then the youngest came to her and entreated her to give him a day for consideration, and also to be so gracious as to overlook it if she should happen to discover him twice, but if he failed the third time, he would look on his life as over.As he was so handsome, and begged so earnestly, she said, “Yes, I will grant thee that, but thou wilt not succeed.”

zh: 第二天，老三想了很久怎样去隐藏自己，但什么办法都没想到。于是，他拿起枪，出门打猎去了。他看到一只乌鸦，正要瞄准它开枪，这时乌鸦大叫：“不要开枪，只要你不杀我，我会报答你的。”他放下枪，继续前行，来到一个湖边，在那里他意外地发现一条大鱼正从湖底深处游上水面。当他用枪瞄着鱼时，鱼大叫起来：“不要开枪，我会报答你的。”他让鱼又潜回了深水中，继续往前走，又遇到了一只瘸了腿的狐狸。他向它开了一枪但没有打中，狐狸叫了起来：“你行行好，过来帮我把脚上的刺拔了吧。”他帮狐狸拔了刺，不过他还是想杀了它、取它的皮，狐狸马上说：“不要杀我，我会报答你的。”小伙子放了它，这时天也黑了，他只好回家了。
en: Next day he meditated for a long time how he should hide himself, but all in vain.Then he seized his gun and went out hunting.He saw a raven, took a good aim at him, and was just going to fire, when the bird cried, “Don’t shoot; I will make it worth thy while not to kill me.”He put his gun down, went on, and came to a lake where he surprised a large fish which had come up from the depths below to the surface of the water.When he had aimed at it, the fish cried, “Don’t shoot, and I will make it worth thy while.”He allowed it to dive down again, went onwards, and met a fox which was lame.He fired and missed it, and the fox cried, “You had much better come here and draw the thorn out of my foot for me.”He did this; but then he wanted to kill the fox and skin it, the fox said, “Stop, and I will make it worth thy while.”The youth let him go, and then as it was evening, returned home.

zh: 第二天，他该把自己藏起来了，但是不管他怎样绞尽脑汁，还是不知道藏在哪里好。他去森林里找到了乌鸦，说：“我放了你一条生路，现在你告诉我，该藏到哪里，好让公主找不到我。”乌鸦低着头思索了很久。最后，它呱呱叫道：“我有办法了！”乌鸦从巢里拿出一颗蛋，切成了两半，把小伙子关在里面，然后把蛋合了起来，自己坐了上去。公主来到第一个窗户，她没能找到他，其他几个里也找不到，她开始有些不安，但是，从第十一个窗户中，她发现了他。她下令射死了乌鸦，并把蛋拿来打碎，小伙子不得不出来了。公主说：“第一次我赦免你，但是下次你不藏好点，你就输定了！”
en: Next day he was to hide himself; but howsoever much he puzzled his brains over it, he did not know where.He went into the forest to the raven and said, “I let thee live on, so now tell me where I am to hide myself, so that the King’s daughter shall not see me.”The raven hung his head and thought it over for a longtime.At length he croaked, “I have it.”He fetched an egg out of his nest, cut it into two parts, and shut the youth inside it; then made it whole again, and seated himself on it.When the King’s daughter went to the first window she could not discover him, nor could she from the others, and she began to be uneasy, but from the eleventh she saw him.She ordered the raven to be shot, and the egg to be brought and broken, and the youth was forced to come out.She said, “For once thou art excused, but if thou dost not do better than this, thou art lost!”

zh: 第二天，他来到湖边把鱼叫了出来，说：“我放了你一条生路，现在告诉我，该藏到哪里，好让公主找不到我。”鱼想了一会儿，最后叫道：“我有办法了！我将把你关进我的肚子里。”鱼吞下小伙子，游到了湖底。公主从她的窗户往外看，可即使到了第十一个窗户还没找到他，公主不由得惊慌起来，但她最后还是从第十二个窗户里发现了他。她下令把鱼捉来杀了，小伙子就出来了。任何人都能想象到他是什么心情。公主说：“第二次我还放过你，但是你的头终究会被钉在第一百根柱子上。”
