en: Next day he went to the lake, called the fish to him and said, “I suffered thee to live, now tell me where to hide myself so that the King’s daughter may not see me.”The fish thought for a while, and at last cried, “I have it!I will shut thee up in my stomach.”He swallowed him, and went down to the bottom of the lake.The King’s daughter looked through her windows, and even from the eleventh did not see him, and was alarmed; but at length from the twelfth she saw him.She ordered the fish to be caught and killed, and then the youth appeared.Every one can imagine what a state of mind he was in.She said, “Twice thou art forgiven, but be sure that thy head will be set on the hundredth post.”

zh: 最后一天，他心情沉重地回到了村里，遇到了狐狸。“你最了解怎样寻找各种藏身的地方，”他说，“我放了你一条生路，现在给我点建议，我该藏到哪里，好让公主找不到我。”“这真是个难题。”狐狸若有所思地答道。最后，它叫道：“我有办法了！”接着它和小伙子一起来到了一个泉水边，狐狸让自己在泉水里泡了泡，出来就变成了一个专门贩卖小动物的集市商贩。小伙子也不得不在水里泡了一下，然后变成了一只小海兔。这个商贩来到了市区，把这只可爱的小动物拿出来展出，很多人都聚过来围观。最后，公主也来了，因为她很喜欢这只小海兔，便给了商贩一大笔钱，把它买了下来。把海兔交给公主之前，商贩对海兔说：“当公主走向窗户时，你就赶紧爬到她的发辫下面去。”现在到了公主搜寻小伙子的时间了。公主依次走过每个窗户，从第一个到第十一个窗户，她都没有看到他。当从第十二个窗户也没能看到他时，公主气急败坏，猛地一把关上窗户，所有的窗玻璃都被震得支离破碎，连整个城堡都在摇晃。
en: On the last day, he went with a heavy heart into the country, and met the fox.“Thou knowest how to find all kinds of hiding-places,” said he; “I let thee live, now advise me where I shall hide myself so that the King’s daughter shall not discover me.”“That’s a hard task,” answered the fox, looking very thoughtful.At length he cried, “I have it!” and went with him to a spring, dipped himself in it, and came out as a stall-keeper in the market, and dealer in animals.The youth had to dip himself in the water also, and was changed into a small sea-hare.The merchant went into the town, and showed the pretty little animal, and many persons gathered together to see it.At length the King’s daughter came likewise, and as she liked it very much, she bought it, and gave the merchant a good deal of money for it.Before he gave it over to her, he said to it, “When the King’s daughter goes to the window, creep quickly under the braids of her hair.”And now the time arrived when she was to search for him.She went to one window after another in turn, from the first to the eleventh, and did not see him.When she did not see him from the twelfth either, she was full of anxiety and anger, and shut it down with such violence that the glass in every window shivered into a thousand pieces, and the whole castle shook.

zh: 她往回走时，发现海兔在她的发辫下面。于是，她一把抓住它扔在地上，大声吼道：“滚开，从我眼前消失！”海兔跑回了商贩那里，他们便一起匆匆赶到泉水边，跳了进去，然后就恢复了他们自己的真实模样。小伙子谢过了狐狸，说道：“和你相比，乌鸦和鱼都太笨了，毫无疑问，你最有办法！”
en: She went back and felt the sea-hare beneath the braids of her hair.Then she seized it, and threw it on the ground exclaiming, “Away with thee, get out of my sight!”It ran to the merchant, and both of them hurried to the spring, wherein they plunged, and received back their true forms.The youth thanked the fox, and said, “The raven and the fish are idiots compared with thee; thou knowest the right tune to play, there is no denying that!”

zh: 小伙子径直来到了宫殿。公主已经在等着他了，她愿意服从命运的安排。婚礼举行得非常隆重，现在小伙子成了国王，统领着整个国家。他从没告诉过公主他第三次藏在了哪里，是谁帮助了他，因此她一直以为他所做的一切都是完全依靠自己的本事，所以她十分钦佩他，心中暗想：“他比我有本事多了。”
en: The youth went straight to the palace.The princess was already expecting him, and accommodated herself to her destiny.The wedding was solemnized, and now he was king, and lord of all the kingdom.He never told her where he had concealed himself for the third time, and who had helped him, so she believed that he had done everything by his own skill, and she had a great respect for him, for she thought to herself, “He is able to do more than I.”

zh: 会唱歌的骨头
en: The Singing Bone

zh: 从前，有一个国家受到野猪的危害，举国悲叹。野猪破坏农民的田地，咬死家畜，还用他那獠牙把许多人都撕碎了。国王许诺会重赏能让这片土地摆脱这一祸害的人；但是野猪肢体庞大，非常强壮，没有人敢靠近它住的森林。最后，国王贴出告示，谁能够将野猪捕获或者杀死，谁就可以娶他唯一的女儿做妻子。
en: In a certain country there was once great lamentation over a wild boar that laid waste the farmer’s fields, killed the cattle, and ripped up people’s bodies with his tusks.The King promised a large reward to anyone who would free the land from this plague; but the beast was so big and strong that no one dared to go near the forest in which it lived.At last the King gave notice that whosoever should capture or kill the wild boar should have his only daughter to wife.

zh: 在这个国家里生活着两兄弟，他们是穷人的儿子，两兄弟声称愿意去冒这个险；哥哥狡诈、精明，做这件事是出于自负；弟弟，单纯、朴实，做这件事是出于善心。国王说：“为了能够确保你们找到野兽，你们俩必须从森林的两边分别进入。”因此哥哥从西边进入森林，弟弟则从东边进入。
en: Now there lived in the country two brothers, sons of a poor man, who declared themselves willing to undertake the hazardous enterprise; the elder, who was crafty and shrewd, out of pride; the younger, who was innocent and simple, from a kind heart.The King said, “In order that you may be the more sure of finding the beast, you must go into the forest from opposite sides.”So the elder went in on the west side, and the younger on the east.

zh: 当弟弟走了一小段路后，一个小矮人走向他。他手里握着一杆黑色的长矛，说：“因为你的心纯洁、善良，我将这把长矛送给你。用这把长矛你就能大胆地袭击野猪，并且不会被它所伤了。”
en: When the younger had gone a short way, a little man stepped up to him.He held in his hand a black spear and said, “I give you this spear because your heart is pure and good; with this you can boldly attack the wild boar, and it will do you no harm.”

zh: 他谢过了小矮人，扛起长矛，勇敢地往前走。
en: He thanked the little man, shouldered the spear, and went on fearlessly.

zh: 不久，他就看到野猪向他冲过来；但是他握紧长矛对准它，野猪发了狂似的朝他猛跑过去，心脏被长矛刺成了两半。于是，他把野猪背在身上，往家走，要把它献给国王。
en: Before long he saw the beast, which rushed at him; but he held the spear towards it, and in its blind fury it ran so swiftly against it that its heart was cloven in twain.Then he took the monster on his back and went homewards with it to the King.

zh: 他从树林的另一边走出来，在入口处有一座房子，人们都在那里饮酒、跳舞作乐。他的哥哥也在这里，哥哥觉得反正野猪也不会逃走，就在这里喝酒来壮胆。但是，当他看见他的弟弟带着战利品从树林里走出来，他那颗满怀妒忌的、邪恶的心使他无法平静。他大声叫弟弟：“快进来，亲爱的弟弟，过来休息一下，喝杯葡萄酒提提神。”
en: As he came out at the other side of the wood, there stood at the entrance a house where people were making merry with wine and dancing.His elder brother had gone in here, and, thinking that after all the boar would not run away from him, was going to drink until he felt brave.But when he saw his young brother coming out of the wood laden with his booty, his envious, evil heart gave him no peace.He called out to him, “Come in, dear brother, rest and refresh yourself with a cup of wine.”

zh: 弟弟从不知道邪恶为何物，走进去告诉他有个好心的小矮人给了他一杆长矛，他就是用那长矛杀死了野猪。
en: The youth, who suspected no evil, went in and told him about the good little man who had given him the spear wherewith he had slain the boar.

zh: 他的哥哥一直留他到了晚上，然后他们就一起走了，黑暗中他们走到横跨小溪的桥上，哥哥让弟弟先过，当他的弟弟刚走到中间的时候，他就从背后重击他，弟弟就摔下去死了。他把弟弟埋在桥下面，拿走野猪，把它献给了国王，装作是他杀死了野猪，就这样他娶了国王的女儿做妻子。他的弟弟没能回来，他就说：“一定是野猪把他杀死了。”大家也都信以为真。
en: The elder brother kept him there until the evening, and then they went away together, and when in the darkness they came to a bridge over a brook, the elder brother let the other go first; and when he was half-way across he gave him such a blow from behind that he fell down dead.He buried him beneath the bridge, took the boar, and carried it to the King, pretending that he had killed it; whereupon he obtained the King’s daughter in marriage.And when his younger brother did not come back he said, “The boar must have killed him,” and every one believed it.

zh: 但是，就像没有什么事可以瞒过上帝一样，这种恶劣的行为也会有暴露的一天。
en: But as nothing remains hidden from God, so this black deed also was to come to light.

zh: 很多年后，一个牧羊人赶着羊群从桥上过，看到下面沙子里埋着一根雪白的骨头。他觉得用它可以做一个很好的乐器吹口，他就爬下去，把它捡起来，修刻成了他的号角的吹口。但是，当他第一次吹的时候，让他感到惊奇的是，骨头开始自己唱起歌来：
en: Years afterwards a shepherd was driving his herd across the bridge, and saw lying in the sand beneath, a snow-white little bone.He thought that it would make a good mouth-piece, so he clambered down, picked it up, and cut out of it a mouth-piece for his horn.But when he blew through it for the first time, to his great astonishment, the bone began of its own accord to sing:

zh: “啊，朋友，你对着我的骨头吹号角！我在水边被放置了很久，我的哥哥为了得到野猪杀了我，还娶了国王年轻的女儿做他的妻子。”
en: “Ah, friend, thou blowest upon my bone!Long have I lain beside the water; My brother slew me for the boar, And took for his wife the King’s young daughter.”

zh: 牧羊人说：“好奇妙的号角啊！自己会唱歌；我一定要带它去见我的国王。”当他带着号角见了国王，号角再次开始唱起那支小歌曲。国王全都明白了，让人挖开桥下的地面，被谋杀的人的整个骸骨重见天日。邪恶的哥哥不能否认这种行为，被缝到一个大口袋里淹死了。但是，被杀的人的骸骨被安葬在教堂墓地中的一个美丽的墓穴里。
en: “What a wonderful horn!” said the shepherd; “it sings by itself; I must take it to my lord the King.”And when he came with it to the King the horn again began to sing its little song.The King understood it all, and caused the ground below the bridge to be dug up, and then the whole skeleton of the murdered man came to light.The wicked brother could not deny the deed, and was sewn up in a sack and drowned.But the bones of the murdered man were laid to rest in a beautiful tomb in the churchyard.

zh: 失窃的两个铜子儿
en: The Stolen Farthings

zh: 一日，夫妻俩和孩子们坐着一块吃午饭，席上还有一位来拜访他们的好朋友。就在他们这么坐着吃饭的时候，时钟敲了十二下，这时客人看见门开了，一个面色苍白、身着白衣的小孩进了屋。小男孩没有环顾四周，也没有说话，径直走进了旁边的一个房间。过了一会儿，他从房间里走了出来，又和来时一样，悄无声息地从大门走了出去。接下来的两天，这个小孩都像第一天那样，悄悄地来，又悄悄地走。终于，这位客人张口询问父亲，那个长得很漂亮、每天正午时分走进旁边房间的小孩到底是谁家的。父亲说：“我从来没有看见过他。”又说他也不知道那小孩是谁家的。又过了一天，小孩再次走进屋里，客人把他指给父亲看，但父亲看不见他，母亲和孩子们也同样看不见。这时候，客人起身走到旁边房间的门口，把门开了条小缝，从门缝往里看。他看见那个小孩坐在地板上，奋力地在地板的裂缝里挖着，好像在寻找什么东西。但是小孩一看见他就消失不见了。然后，客人告诉这家人他看到的情景，并详细描述了这个小孩的样子，这么一来母亲便知道他是谁了，她说道：“唉，这是我的宝贝儿子啊。他一个月前刚过世。”于是他们把地板打开，在地板下找到了两个铜子儿。这是有一次小孩从母亲那得到的，他本想把它们送给一个穷人，可又想到：“你可以用这钱给自己买一个小甜饼。”他就把这钱留下来，藏在地板的缝隙里。因为惦记着这两个铜子儿，小孩在坟墓里不得安息，就每天正午回来找。父母马上把这两个铜子儿给了一个穷人，从那以后，这小孩再也没有回来过。
en: A father was one day sitting at dinner with his wife and his children, and a good friend who had come on a visit was with them.And as they thus sat, and it was striking twelve o’clock, the stranger saw the door open, and a very pale child dressed in snow-white clothes came in.It did not look around, and it did not speak; but went straight into the next room.Soon afterwards it came back, and went out at the door again in the same quiet manner.On the second and on the third day, it came also exactly in the same way.At last the stranger asked the father to whom the beautiful child that went into the next room every day at noon belonged.“I have never seen it,” said he, neither did he know to whom it could belong.The next day when it again came, the stranger pointed it out to the father, who however did not see it, and the mother and the children also all saw nothing.On this the stranger got up, went to the room door, opened it a little, and peeped in.Then he saw the child sitting on the ground, and digging and seeking about industriously amongst the crevices between the boards of the floor, but when it saw the stranger, it disappeared.He now told what he had seen and described the child exactly, and the mother recognized it, and said, “Ah, it is my dear child who died a month ago.”They took up the boards and found two farthings which the child had once received from its mother that it might give them to a poor man; it, however, had thought, “Thou canst buy thyself a biscuit for that,” and had kept the farthings, and hidden them in the openings between the boards; and therefore it had had no rest in its grave, and had come every day at noon to seek for these farthings.The parents gave the money at once to a poor man, and after that the child was never seen again.

zh: 狐狸太太的婚礼
en: The Wedding of Mrs. Fox

zh: 故事之一
en: FIRST STORY

zh: 很久以前，有一只九条尾巴的老狐狸，他认为太太对他不忠，想要试探一下她。他四肢伸展，躺在长凳下，一动不动，表现得像是完全死了一样。狐狸太太走到她的房间里，把自己关起来，她的侍女，猫小姐坐在火旁烧饭。当大家都知道老狐狸死了，求爱者便纷纷而至。侍女听到有人站在房门前敲门。她走过去，把门打开，是个年轻的狐狸，他说：
en: There was once upon a time an old fox with nine tails, who believed that his wife was not faithful to him, and wished to try her.He stretched himself out under the bench, did not move a limb, and behaved as if he were stone dead.Mrs. Fox went up to her room, shut herself in, and her maid, Miss Cat, sat by the fire, and did the cooking.When it became known that the old fox was dead, wooers presented themselves.The maid heard some one standing at the house-door, knocking.She went and opened it, and it was a young fox, who said,

zh: “猫小姐，你在忙些什么？是睡着呢，还是醒着呢？”
en: “What may you be about, Miss Cat.?Do you sleep or do you wake?”

zh: 她回答：
en: She answered,

zh: “我没睡觉，我醒着呢，你想知道我在做什么吗？我在热啤酒，再加些奶油，味道好极了，先生也要进来喝点吗？”
en: “I am not sleeping, I am waking, Wouldst thou know what I am making?I am boiling warm beer with butter so nice, Will the gentleman enter and drink some likewise?”

zh: “不，谢谢你，小姐。”狐狸说，“狐狸太太正在做什么？”侍女回答道：
en: “No, thank you, miss,” said the fox, “what is Mrs. Fox doing?”The maid replied,

zh: “她自己坐着，呜咽，把她的小眼睛哭得通红，因为老狐狸先生死了。”
en: “She sits all alone, And makes her moan, Weeping her little eyes quite red, Because old Mr. Fox is dead.”

zh: “一定要告诉她，小姐，有个年轻的狐狸在这儿，想向她求爱。”“一定，年轻先生。”
en: “Do just tell her, miss, that a young fox is here, who would like to woo her.”“Certainly, young sir.”

zh: 猫蹑手蹑脚地上了楼，她轻轻地敲门：“女主人，你在里面吗？”“噢，是的，我的小猫。”她叫道。“一个求爱者站在门口。”
en: The cat goes up the stairs trip, trap, The door she knocks at tap, tap, tap, “Mistress Fox, are you inside?”“Oh yes, my little cat,” she cried.“A wooer he stands at the door out there.”

zh: “亲爱的，告诉我他长得什么样？”
en: “Tell me what he is like, my dear?”

zh: “可是他有像老狐狸一样的九条美丽的尾巴吗？”“噢，不，”猫答道，“他只有一条尾巴。”
en: “But has he nine as beautiful tails as the late Mr. Fox?”“Oh, no,” answered the cat, “he has only one.”

zh: “那么我不愿意。”猫小姐下楼把求爱者送走了。过了一会儿，又有人敲门，另外一只狐狸也想向狐狸太太求爱。他有两条尾巴，但是他的结果比第一个好不了多少。这之后来了更多狐狸，每只都比前一个多一条尾巴，但是他们全都被谢绝了，直到最后来了一个像老狐狸似的长着九条尾巴的。当寡妇狐狸听到后，她高兴地对猫说：
en: “Then I will not have him.”Miss Cat went downstairs and sent the wooer away.Soon afterwards there was another knock, and another fox was at the door who wished to woo Mrs. Fox.He had two tails, but he did not fare better than the first.After this still more came, each with one tail more than the other, but they were all turned away, until at last one came who had nine tails, like old Mr. Fox.When the widow heard that, she said joyfully to the cat,

zh: “现在把所有的门窗都大敞开，把老狐狸带到外面去。”
en: “Now open the gates and doors all wide, And carry old Mr. Fox outside.”

zh: 但是恰到婚礼举行的时候，凳子下的老狐狸活过来了，用棍子把所有的乌合之众和狐狸太太都赶出了房子。
en: But just as the wedding was going to be solemnized, old Mr. Fox stirred under the bench, and cudgelled all the rabble, and drove them and Mrs. Fox out of the house.

zh: 故事之二
en: SECOND STORY

zh: 老狐狸死了之后，狼来求爱，他敲门，狐狸太太的仆人猫给他开了门。狼向她打招呼，说：
en: When old Mr. Fox was dead, the wolf came as a wooer, and knocked at the door, and the cat who was servant to Mrs. Fox, opened it for him.The wolf greeted her, and said,

zh: “你好，打扫卫生的猫太太，你怎么一个人坐着呢？你在做什么好东西呢？”
en: “Good day, Mrs. Cat of Kehrewit, How comes it that alone you sit?What are you making good?”

zh: 猫回答道：
en: The cat replied,

zh: “我在牛奶里掰了些味道特别甜美的面包，先生请进来吃点吧？”
en: “In milk I’m breaking bread so sweet, Will the gentleman please come in and eat?”

zh: “不了，谢谢你，猫太太。”狼回答道，“狐狸太太不在家？”
en: “No, thank you, Mrs. Cat,” answered the wolf.“Is Mrs. Fox not at home?”

zh: 猫说：
en: The cat said,

zh: “她在她楼上的房间里坐着，她正在叹息她那令人伤心的命运，
en: “She sits upstairs in her room, Bewailing her sorrowful doom,

zh: 叹息她那无比痛心的苦恼，因为老狐狸先生已经不在了。”
en: Bewailing her trouble so sore, For old Mr. Fox is no more.”

zh: 狼回答：
en: The wolf answered,

zh: “如果她现在需要一个丈夫，那么能不能请她下楼来？”猫很快跑上楼，尾巴来回摆动，一直跑到客厅门口。
en: “If she’s in want of a husband now, Then will it please her to step below?”The cat runs quickly up the stair, And lets her tail fly here and there, Until she comes to the parlour door.

zh: 用她那戴着五个金戒指的手敲了敲门：“你在里面吗，善良的女主人？如果你现在需要一个丈夫，那么请你下楼来好吗？”
en: With her five gold rings at the door she knocks, “Are you within, good Mistress Fox?If you’re in want of a husband now, Then will it please you to step below?”

zh: 狐狸太太问道：“那位先生是不是穿着红色的袜子，长着尖尖的嘴巴？”“不是。”猫回答。“那么他不适合我。”
en: Mrs. Fox asked, “Has the gentleman red stockings on and has he a pointed mouth?”“No,” answered the cat.“Then he won’t do for me.”

zh: 狼走了以后，来了一条狗，一只雄鹿，一只野兔，一只熊，一头狮子，还有森林里所有的野兽都相继来向她求爱。但是，他们都缺少老狐狸先生身上的一个优点，猫就相继把求爱者都赶走了。最后来了一个年轻的狐狸。狐狸太太说：“那位先生是不是穿着红袜子，还长着尖尖的嘴巴？”“是的，”猫说，“他是。”“那么让他上楼来。”狐狸太太说，并令仆人准备婚宴。
en: When the wolf was gone, came a dog, a stag, a hare, a bear, a lion, and all the beasts of the forest, one after the other.But one of the good points which old Mr. Fox had possessed, was always lacking, and the cat had continually to send the wooers away.At length came a young fox.Then Mrs. Fox said, “Has the gentleman red stockings on, and has he a little pointed mouth?”“Yes,” said the cat, “he has.”“Then let him come upstairs,” said Mrs. Fox, and ordered the servant to prepare the wedding-feast.

zh: “把屋子尽可能地打扫干净，从窗户那儿把老狐狸扔出去！因为他带回来很多美味的肥老鼠，但他从未考虑过他的妻子，自己全都吃光了。”
en: “Sweep me the room as clean as you can, Up with the window, fling out my old man!For many a fine fat mouse he brought, Yet of his wife he never thought, But ate up every one he caught.”

zh: 于是，狐狸太太和年轻狐狸先生的婚礼举行了，他们非常高兴，跳起舞来；如果他们一直没有停下来，那么到了今天他们还在跳着呢。
en: Then the wedding was solemnized with young Mr. Fox, and there was much rejoicing and dancing; and if they have not left off, they are dancing still.

zh: 任性的孩子
en: The Wilful Child

zh: 从前，有个任性的小孩，从不做妈妈让她做的事情。因为她太不听话，上帝一点也不喜欢她，就让她生重病，任何医生都治不好她。很快地，这个孩子便不治而终了。当人们将她下葬入墓，为她撒上尘土时，孩子的手突然伸了出来，而且还直直地向上举着。人们想把它放进去，再撒些土，可根本不管用，因为她的手臂总是再次从里面伸出来。后来，只有让孩子的妈妈亲自到她的坟墓边用荆条抽打她的手臂，果然，在妈妈打了她的手臂后，她终于把手收了回去，并安静地在地下长眠。
en: Once upon a time there was a child who was willful, and would not do what her mother wished.For this reason God had no pleasure in her, and let her become ill, and no doctor could do her any good, and in a short time she lay on her death-bed.When she had been lowered into her grave, and the earth was spread over her, all at once her arm came out again, and stretched upwards, and when they had put it in and spread fresh earth over it, it was all to no purpose, for the arm always came out again.Then the mother herself was obliged to go to the grave, and strike the arm with a rod, and when she had done that, it was drawn in, and then at last the child had rest beneath the ground.

zh: 机智的仆人
en: The Wise Servant

zh: 如果一个主人能有一个听从命令却不拘泥于命令，善于运用自身智慧的聪明仆人，那他该是多么幸运，他的家务该被处理地多么井井有条啊。聪明的约翰就是这类仆人，他的主人曾经派他去寻找一头走失的奶牛。他离开了很长时间，他的主人想：“忠实的约翰工作太努力了！”然而，因为他始终没有回来，主人开始担心他遇到危险，于是自己出去找他。他找了很久，最终却发现这个男孩正在一大块田野里跑来跑去。“现在，亲爱的约翰，”当主人走向他的时候，主人说，“你找到我让你找的奶牛了么？”“没有，主人，”他回答，“我没有找到奶牛，于是我就没有再找它。”“那你在找什么，约翰？”“更好的东西，而且我已经幸运地找到了。” “是什么，约翰？”“三只画眉鸟。”男孩说。“那它们在哪儿呢？”主人问。“我看到了一只，听见了第二只，我正在追第三只。” 这个机智的男孩答道。
en: How fortunate is the master, and how well all goes in his house, when he has a wise servant who listens to his orders and does not obey them, but prefers following his own wisdom.A clever John of this kind was once sent out by his master to seek a lost cow.He stayed away a long time, and the master thought, “Faithful John does not spare any pains over his work!”As, however, he did not come back at all, the master was afraid lest some misfortune had befallen him, and set out himself to look for him.He had to search a long time, but at last he perceived the boy who was running up and down a large field.“Now, dear John,” said the master when he had got up to him, “hast thou found the cow which I sent thee to seek?”“No, master,” he answered, “I have not found the cow, but then I have not looked for it.”“Then what hast thou looked for, John?”“Something better, and that luckily I have found.”“What is that, John?”“Three blackbirds,” answered the boy.“And where are they?” asked the master.“I see one of them, I hear the other, and I am running after the third,” answered the wise boy.

zh: 以此为例，不要为你的主人或他们的命令而劳神费力，做你想做的、高兴做的事，那样你就会和聪明的约翰表现得一样机智了。
en: Take example by this, do not trouble yourselves about your masters or their orders, but rather do what comes into your head and pleases you, and then you will act just as wisely as prudent John.
